IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative This study aims to test PATH (Peer Advanced Training in Harm reduction) as a system-level workforce intervention for reducing burnout among peer recovery support specialists (PRSSs) who provide harm reduction (HR) services, as well its ability to improve service quality and service system-level outcomes. PATH addresses a recognized need to support the national expansion of PRSS and HR services to support people with substance use disorders and reduce overdose rates. If successful, PATH can serve as a model program to be scaled nationally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and opioid use disorder (OUD) often co-occur, but treatment for PTSD is rarely available in residential substance use disorder (SUD) treatment settings. Written Exposure Therapy (WET) is a brief, evidence-based intervention for PTSD that shows promise for treating people with OUD in residential SUD care. With stakeholder collaboration, we will create and test a theory-driven adaptation of WET to address PTSD-OUD in residential SUD care, thereby advancing knowledge of practical strategies that are crucial for addressing the opioid use crisis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will contribute to our understanding of the ways in which non-congregate forms of housing shelter may improve the mental health outcomes of people through service delivery by healthcare-community housing partnerships. Traditionally, shelter options provided for this population have been congregate, but during the early years of the COVID-19 pandemic, congregate shelter residents were moved to non-congregate spaces like hotels to minimize the spread of the disease. As those policies expand and evolve, it is essential that we learn about the impact they had on mental health, to inform future housing policies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The biogenesis of the immunogenic SARS-CoV-2 spike (S) protein involves its trafficking between endoplasmic reticulum, Golgi network, and plasma membrane (PM), which provide the enzymatic machinery for post- translational modifications, remodeling, and maturation including of N-glycans that modulate S immunogenicity. Atomic-level insights into how S trafficking modulates N-glycan maturation and subsequent interactions with the immune system will substantially enhance our understanding of COVID-19 infection mechanism, genetic vaccine design, and provide a platform to understand the fundamental principles of viral glycoprotein biogenesis. The investigations proposed in this grant will employ structural, computational, and biophysical tools to generate atomic level details underlying the modulation of S conformations and epitope exposure by N-glycans, thus providing new approaches to vaccine design against existing and emerging coronaviruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cerebellar nuclei (CbN), the main output from the cerebellum, play the key role in the regulation of movement, and have well-demonstrated pathology in patients suffering from spinocerebellar ataxia type 1 (SCA1). Currently, very little is known about the disease pathogenesis in CbN in any of the spinocerebellar ataxias (SCAs), including SCA1. The research described in this proposal will fill these gaps in our knowledge by determining how function of CbN is altered throughout SCA1 progression, how changes in CbN contribute to SCA1-like motor deficits, and how mutant ATXN1 (mATXN1) impacts CbN in SCA1.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Poor medication adherence in heart failure can lead to poor health, but many clinicians are unable to determine who would benefit from interventions to address adherence. We will build machine learning models to identify patients at risk of not taking their medicines using an approach that minimizes potential biases. Electronic health record data will be used in these models, allowing them to be incorporated into interventions to improve medication adherence and reduce the disease burden of heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Children with juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) experience periods of disease flare, and it has been theorized that infections trigger flares, but the theory has not been well-studied. This study aims to describe the frequency and character of acute upper respiratory infections in young children with JIA, evaluate the effects of infection on the nasopharyngeal microbiome in these children, and assess the relationship between viral infections and JIA disease activity. The study may identify novel pathways of pathogenesis in JIA, which may lead to new treatments and prevention strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Restoration of function after tendon injury is elusive due to the formation of disorganized scar tissue rather than the hierarchical, anisotropic tissue that enables force transmission. This research leverages anisotropic hydrogels as an instructive scaffolds for tenocytes, designing a pro-regenerative environment that recapitulates the structural organization of native tendon.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Asthma is a chronic lung disease affecting millions worldwide. We currently have a limited understanding of how the changes to mucus observed in disease contribute to its function. The proposed research aims to provide a new, highly valuable means to understand the impact of disease-associated changes in mucus composition to lung airway dysfunction in asthma and other related muco-obstructive lung diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Child developmental and learning problems like ADHD, place heavy, often lifelong burdens on families, as well as on the nation's educational, health care, and justice systems. Early identification of risk and cause of ADHD would enable solutions to restore full child health and prevent onset of ADHD before problems become entrenched. This study will test key possibilities for early life prediction in areas that could be reversible with low-risk intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: The identification of molecular and cellular mechanisms involved in primate cortical development and evolution is essential if we are to understand the origins of, and devise prevention and/or treatments for, genetic and environmentally caused cortical abnormalities in humans. Thus, the expected set of unique data are not only of theoretical significance, but also of considerable clinical importance as they may be relevant to disorders of our highest cognitive functions as well as our response to drugs of therapy and abuse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Profiling the spatial proximity of genes and their regulatory elements is one of the critical steps towards developing a fundamental understanding of regulatory processes as well as defining nuclear disorders. Microscopy-based methods have the potential to be applied in research and clinical settings to directly identify healthy and abnormal DNA-DNA contact patterns at the single-cell level, but their robustness and utility are presently limited due to the lack of strategies that simultaneously enable multiplexing (i.e. identifying multiple genomic targets within the same sample), high-throughput (i.e. fast image acquisition), and high-specific target labeling (i.e. low false positives). This project focuses on developing novel DNA-based imaging probes and new experimental approaches to address existing challenges of imaging-based detection of DNA-DNA contacts at the single-cell level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Bone marrow aspirates are critical to the diagnosis, staging, and monitoring of hematologic conditions and cancers (e.g., leukemia, aplastic anemia, sickle cell disease, and metastasis of solid tumors), but 8-50% of aspirations are unsuccessful due to operator technique, hemodilution, or underlying pathology. Cellia Science will enable improved quality and reliability of bone marrow aspiration procedures by developing an automated point-of-care instrument for assessment of sample adequacy. Cellia is applying for TABA funding to support the development of a strategic plan for improving the protection of our adequacy assessment technology and the drafting of a filing consistent with the strategic plan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Nucleic acids exhibit inherently unfavorable biopharmaceutical properties due to specific and non-specific interactions with proteins (enzyme stability, immunostimulation, coagulopathy, etc.), which hamper their development as therapeutic agents. Herein, we will investigate a novel mechanism for nucleic acid delivery based upon entropic protection (termed pacDNA), which facilitates duplex formation but disfavors protein binding (generally the first step leading to undesirable non-hybridization side effects). We will investigate and understand the molecular parameters that give rise to the unique properties of the pacDNA and probe its in vivo characteristics in mouse for gene regulation.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Even young infants use race to categorize people, yet it is unclear how these perceptual tendencies translate to later social prejudice and stereotypes. The current project aims to examine the precursors of social biases across infancy to childhood by investigating infants’ cognitive inferences about racial groups and stranger fear toward people from different races. This work will elucidate the developmental trajectory of racial biases and how early social experience with racial diversity shapes infants’ emerging understanding of race.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Among older adults, about two-thirds of medical marijuana users indicate chronic pain as the major reason for the treatment. In this study, we will analyze how genetic, sociodemographic, and psychological/behavioral factors are associated with differing responses to medical marijuana. Findings will provide a foundation for understanding the complex array of factors contributing to the varying responses to medical marijuana and informing and monitoring patient care through a personalized medicine approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative This study builds on a larger parent R01 project to study how motor-speech characteristics contribute to the social communication differences that characterize autism and have been linked to a specific autism candidate gene, FMR1. The project focuses on carriers of the FMR1 premutation, to understand the different skills that contribute to social communication impairments in autism, and how they may be linked to neurobiological and molecular genetic factors. Outcomes of the study may have significant clinical-translational implications, benefiting both the autism and FMR1 communities and paving the way for more effective interventions and precision medicine approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Nearly 7 million undergraduate college students live in states where recreational cannabis use has been legalized, yet few, if any, interventions have been created to convey accurate information about cannabis products, cannabis marketing, and cannabis risks to young adults in an effort to reduce use and misuse. We have developed an intervention that positively impacts college students' knowledge of cannabis products and laws, efficacy in navigating cannabis products, and risk perceptions. The proposed study will refine and assess the feasibility and acceptability of this technology-based intervention that will increase college students’ awareness of the risks associated with cannabis use while also empowering young adults who choose to use cannabis to do so in an informed manner, which will ultimately help reduce cannabis misuse among U.S. college students.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acetaminophen (APAP) exposures are ubiquitous use during pregnancy and early life during lung development. Alarmingly, clinical data support the hypothesis that the developing lung may be adversely affected by APAP exposure due to the developmental ontogeny of pulmonary CYP2E1 expression. These pre- clinical studies will be the first to interrogate the mechanisms underlying the unique susceptibility of the developing lung to APAP exposure and help determine its safety profile in this understudied population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The cell employs a degradation system known as the ESCRT (Endosomal Sorting Complexes Required for Transport) machinery to prevent the accumulation of signaling molecules and their receptors. We discovered that mouse models with loss of ESCRT encoding-genes exhibit shorter jaw and clefting of the secondary palate, suggesting that this machinery controls craniofacial development by regulating the cellular levels of specific signaling molecules. Using multiple mouse lines we engineered that lack one of the ESCRT encoding-genes we will identify ESCRT-dependent genetic pathways that are required for normal face and mouth development, enriching the current molecular diagnostics toolkit for craniofacial birth defects.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Nearly 350,000 United States Military Servicemembers have been diagnosed with a mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI) since the year 2000. Recent surveys suggest that half or more of Veterans with mTBI will report problems with their vision, but visual deficits are often not detected in this population using standard clinical tests. Failure to diagnose and treat these visual deficits may exacerbate or prolong the everyday difficulties experienced by Veterans with mTBI (e.g., reading, driving, or following a visual presentation), presenting a critical barrier to successful rehabilitation and reintegration. In other acquired visual disorders, changes in color vision are often the earliest sign of vision loss. This study develops a new test of color vision designed to capture subtle differences in the processing of color signals at peripheral and central stages of the visual system. This “mutli- stage” approach is geared toward characterizing the complex profile of visual deficits associated with mTBI and can easily be extended to other domains of visual function such as motion or luminance contrast.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: Project Narrative Representing almost 12% of all cases worldwide, female breast cancer was the most commonly diagnosed cancer in 2020 and accounted for 1 in 6 cancer-related death among women, indicating an increasingly urgent need for novel therapeutic strategies targeting both disease onset and tumor progression. 15% of women globally, and more than forty percent of women in the US are obese, and while it is known that obesity increases a woman’s risk of breast cancer, the potential for targetable mechanisms mediating this relationship remains unclear. The findings from this proposal will inform alternative approaches for triple negative breast cancer patients- as first-line interventions themselves, or as additions to improve efficacy of traditional treatment regimens.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA NORTH TEXAS HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Kidney failure has been recognized as one of the most costly chronic conditions among United States Veterans. Approximately 13,000 Veterans develop kidney failure each year, and most require hemodialysis initiation. Hemodialysis patients suffer significantly increased risk of death and hospitalizations, and excessive body fluid is a major cause of this. While empiric aggressive fluid removal during dialysis is one approach to limit fluid overload, this can cause dangerous decreases in blood pressure during dialysis that independently contribute to the high death rate. In this study, I aim to test a new strategy that prescribes fluid removal based on a patient’s recent blood pressure patterns during dialysis. This clinical trial will compare my strategy to standard care and assess the outcomes of overall blood pressure change between dialysis treatments in addition to the number of times the blood pressure becomes dangerously low during dialysis. Another aim is to determine how differences in the structure and function of the heart influence blood pressure during dialysis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The strongest genetic risk factor for developing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease is carrying the E4 allele of APOE, which codes for the protein apoliprotein E (APOE). We are testing the function of APOE in the fat metabolism of brain cells called astrocytes and microglia. These studies will lead to increased understanding of the mechanism by which APOE4 causes increased risk of neurodegeneration and could lead to the identification of new drug targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Relevance to human health Sleep disorders, mood disorders, obesity, and diabetes are global health hazards, and in recent years there has been a growing realization that these conditions are all linked. The goal of the proposed investigations is to provide new insights into the circadian clock, a biological timekeeping system that controls the sleep-wake cycle, feeding behavior, and metabolism. Deeper understanding of the circadian system could ultimately lead to improved diagnosis and treatment of sleep disorders, bipolar disorder, obesity, and diabetes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Virtually all vaccines rely on antibodies to protect us from infections. The proposal seeks to develop novel vaccine immunogens and strategies that can induce protective broadly neutralizing antibody responses. An effective vaccine could be a powerful intervention to slow and eventually eliminate new HIV infections, and thus the application is highly relevant to human health and welfare.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The relevance of the proposed studies to public health is that they will define mechanisms by which the Heat Shock Protein molecular chaperones and protein unfoldases function as cell stress responders that dissolve toxic protein aggregates and amyloids. These studies propose to use cryo-electron microscopy and biochemical/biophysical approaches to determine structural snapshots which identify how these proteins interact and mechanically unfold their substrates. The resulting information will provide insight into mechanisms that protect cells from deleterious protein misfolding and aggregation, events that underlie the cause of many neurodegenerative diseases including Alzheimer's and Parkinson's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will provide definitive evidence about whether treating prenatal insomnia with digital cognitive behavior therapy for insomnia prevents depression during the perinatal period (i.e., pregnancy and the postpartum period). Currently, there are few intervention options for preventing perinatal depression, none focus on women with prenatal insomnia, and the accessibility of existing interventions is limited. Several attributes of our approach will facilitate its broad dissemination, including focusing on the low stigma target of insomnia and using a scalable intervention, with significant public health impact for reducing the burden of perinatal depression for mothers, children, families, and society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Little is known about how the social determinants of health (SDoH), the arrangement and quality of neighborhoods alcohol outlet hours of operation influence gun violence events and risk. This project will utilize cutting-edge spatial science approaches to understand the spatial and temporal dynamics of gun violence in Washington, D.C. at the neighborhood level from 2014-present. Results from this research could improve our understanding of the SDoH, segregation, spatial and temporal interaction, and relationships with other factors that are necessary to improve gun violence reduction programs and policy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research proposal seeks to define how vaccination alters the course of gammaherpesvirus infection in immunocompetent mice, using the murine gammaherpesvirus 68 model system. While there is clear evidence that the immune system can limit gammaherpesvirus-induced infection, the stage at which infection is disrupted and the cell type(s) involved in protection remain poorly defined. By analyzing viral infection and immune parameters associated with control of gammaherpesvirus infection in the context of vaccination, these studies seek to address this gap in knowledge of gammaherpesvirus infection and disease in susceptible populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We recently published an easy-to-use battery that can predict upcoming reuse events in patients being treated for opioid use disorder (OUD), and we then migrated that battery to a smartphone platform and demonstrated retention and compliance of over 85% in an OUD population. Our analysis of existing clinical trial data suggests that adjusting buprenorphine dosing in response to reuse events reduces relapse rates. Here we propose to: (1) test the hypothesis that our battery can be used to trigger dose adjustments before reuse events and that this has the effect of reducing reuse and relapse in medication-based OUD treatment; (2) examine the willingness of clinicians to employ this strategy; and (3) examine the cost-effectiveness of these adjustments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Narrative: Social stress in humans increases the risk for depression resulting in anhedonia—a loss of interest in pleasurable stimuli—which can manifest within social domains and lead to severe social impairments. Mouse models of social stress are useful to better understand the biological underpinnings of stress-impaired social behavior deficits. Our results show that activation of lateral septum in susceptible mice following social defeat occludes social reward and preference promoting social avoidance behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Radiation therapy (RT), a key pillar of cancer management, causes a common, yet often ignored, side effect – immune system suppression (i. e., radiation-induced lymphopenia [RIL]). Severe RIL has been linked to poor cancer treatment outcomes, presumably due to the reduced tumor surveillance by the immune system, thereby increasing disease recurrence and distant metastasis after RT. We propose approaches, strengthened greatly by the Digital Twins for Radiation Oncology supplement, to identify clinical and dosimetric factors that predict the risk and severity of RIL and understand the impact of RIL on the immune diversity and profile as it affects clinical outcomes; to develop models that can accurately predict the risk of RIL line clinical factors; and to use such models in the optimization of radiation dose distributions to mitigate RIL and its impact on outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The proposed research uses ecological momentary assessment (EMA) to characterize patterns of cannabis and tobacco use and co-use in a sample of 150 sexual minority young adults (SMYAs), and the indirect effects of daily minority stressors on associations between sexual orientation sub-groups (bisexual/bisexual+ vs monosexual SMYAs) on single and co-use patterns. Research aimed at understanding the processes and consequences related to cannabis and tobacco use and co-use in this vulnerable group has very high public health significance given the elevated rates of single use of cannabis and tobacco in SMYAs versus their heterosexual peers, the rising ubiquity of cannabis use and co-use with a variety of tobacco products in this age group, and significant changes in cannabis policies (including legal marketing of cannabis products).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative We discovered a robust anabolic response in human cartilage that follows a distal-proximal axis gradient (high in the ankle joint and low in the hip joint); this response was modulated by the same master regulators that regulate limb regeneration in animals capable of limb regeneration. This project investigates the origins of these master regulators in synovial cells, the mechanisms involved, and how aging effects these mechanisms in human joint tissue.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women in South Asia, including India, often migrate from their husbands’ home back to their parents’ home in pregnancy and for delivery, which may have implications for maternal and child heath, yet this phenomenon is understudied. We will conduct a multisite longitudinal study in India to understand and describe this phenomenon (which we call temporary childbirth migration) and measure its impact on infant and maternal health, with a primary outcome of preterm birth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Osteoporosis is a prevalent disease in the aging population affecting more than 10 million Americans. Vertebral fractures from osteoporosis have debilitating consequences such as pain and immobility, resulting in substantial socioeconomic burden. This proposal aims to develop a novel quantitative imaging methodology using a clinical photon-counting detector CT system to comprehensively characterize trabecular and cortical bone in the spine, and enable the early detection of compromised bone quality and subsequently facilitate a timely initiation of pharmacologic therapies and monitor patient’s response to such therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Meniscus injuries are very common and frequently lead to early onset osteoarthritis, a leading cause of disability. This project will identify biomechanical and biological predictors of cartilage degeneration after meniscus injury and partial meniscectomy. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative This project will be the first to prioritize the daily experiences of bisexual and multigender-attracted (bi+) young adults and their partners when examining the proximal and prospective association between alcohol use and intimate partner violence (IPV) perpetration. In doing so, this study will enhance the scientific knowledge of alcohol use and IPV disparities among bi+ young adults and their partners – a population at high risk for heavy drinking and IPV – while addressing methodological limitations of existing alcohol-related IPV research that hinders the development of inclusive interventions. By identifying theoretically-informed daily experiences unique to bi+ young adults and their partners that potentiate (e.g., bi+ minority stress) or mitigate (e.g., partner support) alcohol-related IPV, results will provide critically-needed evidence of specific factors that should be targeted in alcohol-related IPV interventions for this priority population.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE In this proposal, we demonstrate the development of a therapeutic pipeline for preterm WMI in which pro- myelinating compounds are identified using a novel high-throughput screening method, followed by in vitro and in vivo validation and testing. Using our fabricated micropillar arrays, we propose to screen naturally occurring nutritional compounds found in breast milk to identify/confirm/validate compounds and pathways that promote myelination. We believe that our extensive experience with myelination and oligodendrocyte lineage cells and the strong preliminary data with the identification of N-acetylneuraminic acid (NANA) as a promyelinating compound, place us in a unique position to spearhead a novel approach for the development of therapeutics for WMI in premature infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Astrocyte border formation is a conserved feature of many CNS disorders but there are fundamental gaps in our understanding of the context specific functions of astrocytes borders across different CNS disorders because of the lack of robust bioassays to evaluate these cells. Here, we will advance a new bioassay to study the diverse states of astrocyte borders by using injectable biomaterials that controllably release small molecules and viral vectors to stimulate the formation and characterization of astrocytes borders. Successful completion of this project will lead to identification of conserved- and context-dependent functions of astrocyte borders and provide the foundations on which to explore therapeutic targeting of astrocyte border cells.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Primary care consolidation under health system ownership is increasing, but it is unclear how this will impact clinicians’ ability to achieve the National Academy of Medicine’s vision of High- Quality Primary Care and Whole Health. We will use multimedia elicitation surveys and focus group interviews to assess the impact of ownership on the delivery of high-quality care and to describe how contextual factors may help or hinder care. This information will inform national efforts and practice interventions to advance high-quality primary care and whole health.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Assessing the Impact of Health System Ownership on Fulfilling the Vision of High-Quality Primary Care and Whole Health

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Columbia University Department of Ophthalmology proposes to serve as the Coordinating Center for SIGHT STUDIES Evaluating the Effectiveness of Telehealth-Based Programs to Detect Glaucoma Among High-Risk Populations in Community Health Settings. The Coordinating Center will support Component A Awardees by providing scientific and logistical support to study the community-based interventions designed by Awardees. By serving as the administrative hub, the Coordinating Center will facilitate the development of a common, standardized protocol, coordinate the process to support communication, provide the website infrastructure for information exchange, and assist with the dissemination and translation of research findings.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The interpretation of new variants, especially those revealed by genetic testing in the clinic, is difficult and hampers the use of genetic information to improve the diagnosis and treatment of disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Weather extremes and air pollution impact birth outcomes, but the role of combinations of temperature, humidity, and air pollution together is not well understood. We propose to improve methods to estimate local temperature, humidity, and air pollution patterns at residential addresses, and investigate their acute association with spontaneous preterm birth in large datasets. Improving the ability to construct complex spatio- temporally varying environmental exposure estimates will inform future weather and air quality warning systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Hypertension is an important modifiable risk factor for Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (AD/ADRD), but the optimal blood pressure (BP) treatment target in older adults remains unclear, and intensive BP treatment may increase the risk of serious adverse events. By pooling individual data from multiple trials and employing advanced statistical methods, this proposal aims to identify subgroups that would benefit the most from intensive BP control for preventing cognitive decline and those at risk of serious adverse events. The findings will inform personalized BP targets and precision medicine strategies aimed at preventing AD/ADRD and promoting healthy aging.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Traumatic injury contributes to more deaths among children and adolescents in the United States than all other causes combined, and is the leading cause of preventable morbidity in pediatrics with over 100,000 children a year at risk of experiencing long-term impairments after severe injury. The goal of this proposal is to identify potentially modifiable post-injury clinical factors that contribute to poor long-term outcomes after pediatric trauma. Improving clinical management after an injury has occurred in order to optimize recovery may complement injury prevention efforts to reduce the overall burden of severe traumatic injury in children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: To ensure effective communication between basic and clinical researchers, practicing clinicians and patients, there has to be a consistent well managed set of names for all human genes, which HGNC has provided since 1979. Having these names enables new discoveries, avoids confusion and prevents patient harm, by helping to ensure that everyone refers to a given gene using the same name.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The olfactory system allows humans to evaluate the quality of food sources and to avoid harmful chemicals, thereby promoting overall health and quality of life. Relatively little is known about how higher order brain structures process olfactory information in mammals. The proposed experiments will further decipher the pattern of neural activity that underlies odor features in the olfactory cortex.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project NARRATIVE Cellular properties can be altered by expression of a variant form of a protein. A particularly egregious situation arises from expression of a mutant transcription factor that exerts a dominant effect on the wild type form co-expressed in the same cell. The proposal is directed at establishing a new tool that selectively removes the mutant factor, leaving the wild type form intact and thus restoring a normal phenotype to the cell.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Microglia is a specialized cell type in brain that eliminates debris and dying neurons. Our recent data show that microglia cells, in a rare human early-onset dementia disease, known as Nasu-Hakola Disease, due to mutations in genes that control microglia activation and waste removal properties, have a specific dysregulated signature. We propose to investigate two crucial molecular pathways that could lead to these dysfunctional responses in vitro using microglia derived from pluripotent stem cells and in vivo in mouse models to understand how they impact microglia function. We believe that this research may advance our understanding of brain alterations in multiple neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The findings from the proposed Supplement will enhance the activities of the parent award (Project SMART; R01DA054236) and a previous supplement by yielding research findings from the perspectives of social media influencers (SMIs) who would potentially collaborate on increasing the reach and impact of the intervention currently evaluated in the parent award. While the parent project focuses on effectiveness of tailoring of health messages to SGM youth, the supplement study will add crucial information to explore strategies to successfully partner with SMIs in future health communication interventions. Together, these findings would lead to the intervention being more likely to be integrated in the community, narrow the research-practice gap, ensure intervention approaches arising from this research are appropriate and sustainable for real-world settings, and ultimately reduce vaping among SGM youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Continuous monitoring of nocturnal blood pressure can help early diagnosis of developing cardiac conditions, reveal short term blood pressure variations, and also help the physician monitor differences in variations in response to medication for hypertensive patients. Moreover, the comfort and convenience of a wearable monitor would allow measurement in the natural context of daily life, including important nocturnal measurements, and reduce the burden of adherence on the user. The system will also provide feedback on quality of measurements to allow the users or care-givers to gauge reliability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Contact PD/PI: Pluciennik, Anna Public health relevance Genome instability is a hallmark a wide range of disease-states including cancer and neurologic conditions. Over two dozen neurodegenerative, musculoskeletal, and neurological disorders are caused by triplet repeat expansions, the mechanisms of which are not well understood. The studies proposed here will provide a deeper understanding of the crosstalk between DNA repair pathways and the impact of this crosstalk on repeat expansion and will also yield novel mechanistic insights into the function of enzymes that modulate repeat expansion, and will thus have wide-ranging biomedical implications. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The nature of Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) suggests genetically susceptible individuals are persistently colonized with mildly pathogenic microbial strains or lack colitoprotective strains. The majority of human gut microbiota strains remain stably colonized in our gastrointestinal tract from years to decades. Using microbial strain tracking methods and gnotobiotic mouse models of colitis, we will assess if colitogenic and colitoprotective human gut microbes stably or transiently colonize the human gut microbiota and explore the practical implications for this stability in the context of fecal microbiota transplantation for ulcerative colitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE FOR PARENT AWARD R01AI164690 Influenza virus engages cellular factors that are necessary for successful infection. Here we study the function of RNA:protein complexes formed during infection by both viral and host components. These studies will provide insight into the viral and host factors that regulate viral replication and host innate immune responses, and may ultimately identify new targets for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: NARRATIVE To address public concern about high prescription drug prices and access to medications, legislators have adopted price ceiling control policies, such as monthly out-of-pocket caps for insulin, annual out-of-pocket caps for prescription drugs, and drug affordability boards with the power to set payment ceilings for high-cost prescription drugs. While price ceiling control policies are promising tools to improve access to and utilization of the targeted medications, they may have broader market effects. Using state-level insulin out-of-pocket caps as a case study, we examine whether price ceiling control policies lead to changes in the use of clinically preferred products to manage diabetes.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Measuring the Impact of Price Ceiling Controls: A Case Study of Insulin Out-of-Pocket Caps

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We engineered the first viable pre-clinical mouse model (termed Vac14ducky) of the pediatric VAC14-associated neurodegenerative disease, and using this new model, we have developed and completed preliminary analyses of a novel gene therapy (AAV9-hVAC14opt) for this disease. Following a single neonatal intrathecal injection of AAV9-hVAC14opt, the overall health and motor function of adult Vac14ducky mice was successfully rescued compared to vehicle-treated mice, with no detectable toxicities in control mice. Building on these exciting and promising results, the study proposed here will 1) define a minimal effective dose and 2) test post-symptomatic efficacy of AAV9-hVAC14opt in anticipation for IND application to the FDA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Individuals with opioid use disorder are more likely to smoke cigarettes and have more difficulty quitting smoking than the general population, and they are also more likely to have problems with chronic pain. This research will examine whether switching to very low nicotine content cigarettes for four weeks can reduce symptoms of withdrawal, dependence, and pain-related urge to smoke in this population—factors that present significant barriers to quitting smoking. This research represents an important first step toward developing and testing an intervention to help people with opioid use disorder and chronic pain quit smoking and improve their health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Impaired oral and systemic health associated with adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) disproportionately impacts children, especially those who belong to racial or ethnic minority groups. A strong epidemiological association has been identified between ACEs and dental caries, but the limited understanding of the biological factors underlying ACE-associated dental caries remains an essential knowledge gap. Given the substantiated role of the brain–gut–microbiome axis in ACE-associated systemic diseases and the induction of stress response molecules in saliva, the brain–oral microbiome (BOM) axis may serve as a plausible mechanism through which ACE-associated dental caries impact the oral microbiome, and studying the BOM axis may generate knowledge to inform clinical management and future policies to mitigate caries disparity in children with early-life adversities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Dysfunction of the blood-nerve barrier (BNB) has been implicated in many peripheral nerve pathologies, including diabetic peripheral neuropathy, but has remained vastly understudied especially in comparison to the blood-brain barrier (BBB). In this proposal, we will investigate the transcriptomic differences between the blood- nerve barrier (BNB) and the blood-brain barrier (BBB) through single cell RNA sequencing in order to better understand the fundamental biology of the BNB. We will also use scRNA-sequencing to investigate the transcriptomic changes to BNB in a mouse model of diabetes, allowing for analysis of the progression of BNB changes leading to its dysfunction during disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channel CaV2.1 drives synaptic transmission, however we lack fundamental understanding of the mechanisms that direct CaV2.1s to the presynaptic terminal. The CaV2.1 C- terminus has emerged as a major regulator of presynaptic CaV2.1 trafficking. This proposal aims to characterize the trafficking functions of key sequences within the CaV2.1 C-terminus, providing insight into the cellular mechanisms of synapse formation and maintenance and the treatment of neuropathies that stem from failures in calcium channel trafficking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE A key goal of “Healthy People 2030” is to improve health of adults through aerobic physical activity, and soccer, which is the most popular sport on earth, is an aerobic outlet for more than 25 million Americans of all ages that provides significant benefits for brain health. However, we and others have shown that repetitive subconcussive head impacts from soccer heading are associated with signs of subclinical brain injury among young adults, which impact function and may pose risk for neurodegeneration. Delineating the risk vs. benefit to cognitive performance from soccer, based upon a robust scientific foundation, can transform perception of risk by stakeholders and facilitate guidanceon soccer participation for young adult players with decades of future needs, and potential to impact their wellbeing, healthcare footprint and productivity for decades.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative Stroke can cause permanent learning, memory, and motor deficits. Adult neural stem cells have the capacity to home to the brain injury and are thought to be an important part of the repair process after stroke. This proposal aims to gain a better understanding of processes that influence adult neural stem cells following stroke and to identify future strategies to increase brain repair following stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pontocerebellar Hypoplasia Type 1b (PCH1b) is a devastating inherited neurological disorder that preferentially affects specific regions of the brain, the pons and the cerebellum, causing children born with this condition to have dramatically reduced lifespans. The mutations that cause PCH1b occur in a gene that encodes a critical component of a molecular machine that is important for the regulation of gene expression. The proposed studies exploit the fruit fly (Drosophila) as a model system to provide insight into molecular mechanisms underpinning PCH1b.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This project studies how cells that die, in particular those neurons dying of necrosis after injury, are recognized by engulfing cells, an event that leads to the internalization and digestion of these dying neurons. During stroke, cancer, and other traumatic situations, many cells undergo necrosis and apoptosis after injury; the swift removal of these cells prevents tissue injury, inflammatory responses, and auto-immune responses, clears the wounded area, and promotes tissue repair. Understanding the mechanisms controlling the recognition of necrotic neurons will have important therapeutic implications in fighting chronic inflammatory and auto-immune diseases, and in treating neurodegenerative diseases and stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Domestic violence incidents are highly under-identified which requires healthcare providers to be able to detect potential domestic violence-related visits by the structure of traumatic injuries, health problems (e.g., migraines, cardiovascular disease, abdominal pain), and verbal cues. We propose to analyze electronic health records associated to domestic violence related visits to emergency department, use data science techniques to identify injury and health problem patterns that frequently co-occur and apply deep learning-based natural language processing methods to learn verbal cues embedded in patient and provider narratives. Moreover, we will conduct semi-structured interviews with emergency department health providers to investigate the barriers to screen for domestic violence among women during patient-provider encounter. 1

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative Reproduction is a tightly regulated function of an organism that is crucial to the perpetuation of a species. The regulation of pituitary gonadotropins, luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), plays an essential role in this reproductive process. The objective of this proposal is to delineate the precisely coordinated pathways by which hormonal signals direct appropriate LH and FSH gene expression, protein synthesis, and secretion to promote sexual maturation and control normal reproductive function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of the proposed research is to investigate how clinical genomic sequencing impacts families of pediatric patients. This research will develop an empirically informed framework of normative values important to families of pediatric patients, including ethical, legal, and social implications (ELSI), which will then be used to elicit preferences for features of sequencing from a nationally representative sample of parents in the US. The results of this work will lead to a measure of family utility that integrates ELSI and can be used in a decision analytic model to assess the impact of genomic sequencing and the importance of including family- level ELSI considerations in such analyses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The LT-CARE (Liver Transplant-Community Access for Referral Equity) Pilot Study aims to address disparities in liver transplantation (LT) access for patients with decompensated cirrhosis by developing a multicomponent referral toolkit. Through engaging a diverse group of community partners, including providers and patients/caregivers, LT-CARE seeks to improve equity in LT referral by addressing barriers at the health system, provider, and patient levels. By implementing and pilot testing LT-CARE in community gastroenterology (GI) practices across urban and rural settings, the project aims to evaluate its feasibility, acceptability, and effectiveness in enhancing equitable LT access.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although progress has been made in oral cavity squamous cell carcinoma (OCSCC), the mainstays of treatment continue to be surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy, with metastasis and poor responses to treatment representing the most common reasons patients die from this disease. The study will use advanced imaging and sequencing approaches to determine how architectural features of tumors and other cells in the tumor ecosystem influence a state called hybrid epithelial/mesenchymal (HEM), which we have shown to adversely affect patient outcomes. This ReWARDS R01 proposal will integrate our overarching research goals (predicting response to treatments such as immunotherapy) with our DEIA goals of incorporating more diverse voices in head and neck cancer research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research aims to address health disparity issues prevalent among Asian Americans, the fastest growing racial group in the US, using culturally targeted anti-smoking messages, with focus on high-risk subgroups of Filipino, Korean, and Vietnamese Americans. In the long-term, the findings will inform effective and efficient intervention development in culturally targeted tobacco control by assessing the effect and relative effectiveness of various targeting strategies. The project is relevant to NIMHD’s mission because it will contribute to improving minority health and reduce health disparities by examining how to design effective anti- smoking messages reflecting unique characteristics and cultural values of Asian Americans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because a better understanding of how various microbiome niches increase the risk for osteoarthritis (OA) and/or the development of microbiome-based predictive models for OA clinical care is likely not only to give insights into the causes of OA, but also to give rise to new treatments for OA patients. Thus, this proposal is relevant to the part of the NIH's mission that pertains to fostering fundamental creative discoveries, innovative research strategies, and their applications as a basis for ultimately improving health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The purpose of this project is to investigate voice changes associated with speaking in challenging acoustic environments to better inform clinical care for individuals with voice disorders. Many real-life communicative environments include background noise, which poses an obstacle for monitoring and regulating of voice production, especially for those with muscle tension dysphonia. This project, therefore, will fill a crucial theoretical knowledge gap of the underlying mechanisms of the Lombard effect and inform development of individualized clinical assessment and treatment for individuals with sensorimotor deficits underlying their voice disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nearly 1 in 2 suicide deaths among Hispanic adults involves a firearm, the most lethal suicide method. However, there are critical gaps in characterizing Hispanic firearm suicide deaths and identifying opportunities for preventing firearm suicide among Hispanic adults. Identifying the circumstances preceding firearm suicides among Hispanic adults and generating new information on different typologies of Hispanic adult firearm suicide decedents are critical steps toward developing population-informed and targeted firearm suicide interventions.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: The overarching goal of the proposed experiments is to create a gene editing method to efficiently introduce small DNA changes into the zebrafish genome for modeling human health. The strategy builds on using homology surrounding CRISPR/Cas9 double-strand breaks for efficient introduction of cargos into the genome. This strategy is expected to have broad utility and function in with high efficiency in other organisms, and thus be broadly applicable to animal models used by the NIH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE:  Emotion-regulatory failures are central to mood and anxiety disorders, which afflict over 20% of the adult population in the United States and are challenging to treat. Extant evidence implicates altered function of the lateral prefrontal cortex (LPFC) in these disorders, but the specific contributions of LPFC to adaptive emotion remain poorly understood. The proposed studies harness a combination of state-of-the-art brain imaging analyses and methods that permit causal inference to uncover the roles of distinct LPFC regions in emotional responding and regulation, thereby advancing the development of a model that can be applied to optimize treatment for individuals who suffer from mood and anxiety disorders associated with LPFC dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: NARRATIVE Minority groups including children identified as Black or African American and as Hispanic or Latino, and children who come from low-income families, continue to have lower adherence to the recommended Well- Child preventive care schedule. Focusing on patients who did not attend a scheduled Well-Child visit (“no- showed”), we propose to test and compare text messaging and community health worker outreach as strategies for quickly re-engaging families in care after no-show, and to assess impact for minority groups including families whose preferred language is Spanish. Evaluating effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of both interventions will inform clinical practice and decision-making in healthcare to help ultimately reduce disparities in preventive care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aging makes the heart more susceptible to abnormal heart rhythms (arrhythmias) like atrial fibrillation (AF). Despite men and women developing AF at different ages and having different outcomes, little is known about whether there are sex differences in the changes to the atria that happen in aging that predispose to arrhythmias. The goal of this project is to determine sex differences in the atria in aging which may inform future sex-specific strategies for the prevention and treatment of abnormal atrial rhythms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Catalytic C-H bond functionalization has emerged as a powerful approach in organic synthesis for the discovery and production of new pharmaceuticals. The next generation C-H bond functionalization methods described in this proposal will enable the rapid assembly of pharmaceutically relevant compounds, including complex architectures, from simple and readily available inputs. As they are developed, these synthetic methods will be applied to the discovery and optimization of potent and selective ligands to challenging biomolecular targets relevant to the treatment of unmet medical conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is a life-threatening disease that afflicts ~1.5 million Americans. The progressive dilation of AAA culminates in its fatal rupture, yet there are still no effective therapies other than the risky surgical repairs. For the first time, our study discovered the therapeutic potential of dietary restrictions of single amino acid in preventing AAA in rodents. We further identified a molecular “brake” triggered by such dietary intervention and hence exerted its protection against AAA. The ultimate outcome of this project will lead to the establishment of new paradigms for AAA treatment — through dietary intervention or even drug therapies to activate this molecular “brake”.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Title: Characterizing Information Needs and Peer Engagement Regarding Medication for  Opioid Use Disorder on social media Although medications for opioid use disorder (MOUD) are the most effective, evidence-based treatment for OUD, there remain significant knowledge gaps and misperceptions regarding these medications that adversely impact treatment initiation, adherence, and retention. Social media platforms like Reddit contain millions of self-reported narrations on critical MOUD-related treatment information needs and how thousands of individuals with lived experiences address them. By utilizing advanced natural language processing and novel mixed-method solutions on large-scale, population-level Reddit data, this exploratory project aims to characterize clinically relevant MOUD treatment information needs to inform the design of tailored communication programs and interventions (e.g., chatbot) and ultimately improve MOUD treatment access and quality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE Substance us disorder (SUD) and overdose is a national top-three leading cause of pregnancy-associated death, and historically marginalized patients are at greatest risk of overdose or death due to inequitable barriers to treatment retention. Contingency management is one of the most effective incentive-based interventions to improve SUD outcomes, but is understudied and rarely used in the obstetric population. We propose to design and conduct a hybrid efficacy-implementation randomized control trial to test the efficacy of CM after standardized assessment and management of social needs within a SUD-specific prenatal clinic, to improve treatment retention and other SUD/obstetric outcomes and moderate the relationship between social determinants of health and SUD outcomes; implementation outcomes will additionally be assessed for scalability and sustainability in health policy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Craniofacial fibrous dysplasia (FD) is one of the more common genetic skeletal dysplasias and is associated with significant morbidity, including vision loss, hearing impairment, dysmorphic facies, fractures and pain. In this proposal, we aim to elucidate the role of TGF-b signaling in driving the fibrotic and excessive bone phenotype associated with FD. The knowledge gained through this proposal can be used to shed light on the pathogenesis of craniofacial FD and identify treatment targets for this disease as well as other diseases of impaired bone growth, including osteoporosis and delayed fracture healing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NATHAN S. KLINE INSTITUTE FOR PSYCH RES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This project aims to understand the role of a new type of abnormal electrical activity in Alzheimer’s disease (AD): high frequency oscillations (HFOs). HFOs are known to occur in epilepsy but their role in AD remains unknown. Based on pilot data, we hypothesize that HFOs in AD start as a local electrical disturbance in the hippocampus, and as disease progresses, they progressively expand into superficial cortex. We will address this hypothesis using multi-electrode arrays and longitudinal recordings as the animal ages. Finally, we will test whether HFOs contribute to impaired memory, a major AD symptom as well as to AD neuropathology. To that end, we will use two novel strategies that our preliminary data suggest we can disrupt HFOs in vivo either by employing closed-loop optogenetics or by overexpressing a specific K+ channel to also gain novel insights about mechanisms contributing to HFOs in AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Mild post-stroke aphasia (operationally defined as a Western Aphasia Battery – Revised Aphasia Quotient > 85) is often disabling but proven treatments are lacking. We propose to use electrical field modeling to optimize TMS stimulation intensity in a double-blind study of continuous Theta Burst Stimulation combined with modified Constraint Induced Language Therapy to treat chronic mild post-stroke aphasia. As a secondary aim, we will explore the effects of the treatment on non-linguistic cognitive functions and assess their role in the genesis of the communication impairment in mild aphasia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: R21: Human Craniosynostosis Atlas (HuCA) : Standardizing & Establishing a Public Repository for Genomic and Imaging data. Project Narrative: The Human Craniosynostosis Atlas (HuCA) ultimately seeks to create a standardized data resource for unparalleled characterization of craniosynostosis in humans including multi- modality neuroimaging (CT, multi-contrast MRI) and genotyping, all housed in an established NIH repository and made publicly available. By establishing the standardized data protocols, other craniofacial centers will be able to contribute data that can be analyzed in concert across sites, allowing comprehensive sampling of patients across phenotypic presentations. HuCA is a critical step in deeper characterization of a disease that can lead to discovery of clinically relevant associations between head shape, brain health & genotype which will fundamentally impact how we treat craniosynostosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Terpenoids and carotenoids are naturally occurring small molecules with diverse structures and a growing appreciation of their health impacts. Computer algorithms predict that human gut bacteria can produce these molecules, but their impacts on human health are unknown. This work will use high-throughput screening to reveal whether gut bacteria can make terpenoids and carotenoids, and measure their effects on human colon cells.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pediatric transplant cardiologists have minutes to decide if a donor heart is a good fit for their patient, a process that involves analyzing over a hundred interconnected variables without the help of data-driven guidelines or risk calculators. We are developing machine learning–based models and an easy-to-use interface to help clinicians predict individualized risk and make informed decisions under severe time constraints. This new approach could increase transplant efficiency and revolutionize transplant acceptance practices.

PROJECT_TITLE: Improving Pediatric Donor Heart Utilization with Predictive Analytics

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Intake of excessive amounts of alcohol over a prolonged period is detrimental to health with skeletal muscle commonly being affected. The goal of this research is to determine whether alcohol causes muscle weakness through its dysregulation of the skeletal muscle clock and circadian rhythms. Determining how alcohol influences circadian rhythms in the muscle could lead to the discovery of novel targetable pathways to prevent or remediate the negative effects of alcohol on skeletal muscle, which is functionally important for movement, metabolism, and overall quality of life.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The escalating use of kratom, an herbal substance with opioid-like properties, has raised significant public health concerns due to its potential for abuse and dependence. Preclinical studies report inconsistent effects of the psychoactive constituents of kratom in models of reward. The current human abuse potential study will provide foundational data in determining the risks and dose range of kratom to be evaluated for possible benefits.

PROJECT_TITLE: A human abuse potential study of kratom

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Type 2 Diabetes (T2D) is characterized by defective adaptation of β-cells to insulin resistance. Most of the research effort has focused on elucidating the physiological, molecular, and genetic components that regulate β-cell mass and insulin secretion, presenting diabetes as a unihormonal disorder. Contrary to this approach, clinical data and animal experiments have shown that alterations in glucagon secretion and α-cell mass play a role in the pathogenesis of hyperglycemia in diabetes and responses to hypoglycemia in patients with diabetes. The goal of this application is to understand how nutrient signaling regulates glucagon secretion and α-cell mass in an effort to develop novel therapies for diabetes and control the incident of hypoglycemia, a limitans factor for optimal diabetes control. These agents could be used in translational experiments to treat diabetes and hypoglycemia by controlling glucagon secretion.

This new knowledge will position us to develop impactful, rational treatment approaches to address the neural signaling responsible for the suppressive modulation of immune system and reestablish healthy equilibrium of oral tissues.

PHR: Project Narrative Cervical cancer incidence has increased among Puerto Rican women in recent years. This study will evaluate the impact of patient reminders, patient navigators, and self-collection on cervical cancer screening and follow- up care among Puerto Rican women. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Harnessing a patient’s immune system to attack melanoma is remarkably successful. In one promising approach T cells are harvested directly from the patient’s tumor, expanded to very high numbers in the laboratory where they can be rejuvenated, and returned to the patient to fight their cancer. As this is only effective in approximately half of patients with advanced disease, here we develop a novel, safe and efficient method to further boost these tumor-reactive T cells by mRNA reprogramming.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although diverse perspectives and expertise are needed to solve current, complex health problems, individuals from underrepresented racial/ethnic groups, disadvantaged backgrounds, and individuals with disabilities are significantly less likely to end up in science careers. Evidence suggests that targeted undergraduate research programs substantially improve persistence and conceptualization of a future career in research. This proposal continues an intensive summer research experience in the study of alcohol and related behavioral health outcomes for undergraduates from underrepresented groups in order to develop a pipeline for increasing diversity in biomedical and behavioral research.

PHR: All humans and other mammals acquire their gut bacterial communities throughout life from a variety of sources, including family, social contacts, and the external environment. Despite the significance for public health of transmission of gut bacteria, we do not understand the modes by which individual members of the gut microbiota are transmitted, and the genes that determine these transmission modes have not been discovered. The proposed work will combine methods from microbiology, animal experiments, and functional genomics to discover the transmission modes of the mouse gut microbiota and uncover the underlying genetics of bacterial transmission traits.

PROJECT_TITLE: Uncovering the modes and genetics of gut bacterial transmission

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An estimated 3.9 million fractures occur in the US with an annual economic burden of $116.9 billion in combined medical expenses and work loss. Management of pain arising from orthopedic fractures remains a challenge, as common analgesic medications either interfere with healing or possess potential for addiction. Completion of this proposal will establish a new therapeutic strategy for the care of pain due to orthopedic surgery and fractures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetic defects in the cohesin complex member Stag2 are recurrently mutated in various human cancers and lead to disruption of tissue-specific gene expression through DNA looping. Using cutting-edge epigenomic techniques, primary patient samples, and a reversible in vivo Stag2 mouse, we will map Stag2-specific chromatin looping in hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells and functionally assess their contribution to the lineage fate and self-renewal. Using these techniques in combination with sequential mutagenesis of the AML driver mutations NPM1c and FLT3ITD, we will determine the effects of altered chromatin structure on leukemogenesis, the effects on therapeutic response, and the requirement of Stag2 for leukemia maintenance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While the human body is composed of ~200 different cell types and chronic diseases stem from dysfunction of multiple cells types in specific organs, most human environmental studies have overlooked such complexity. By capturing cell type-specific signals in easily obtainable biospecimens (i.e., standard blood draw) I propose to identify early biological responses to environmental exposures that are predictive of future health-related conditions, specifically of the effects of air pollution on accelerated brain aging—a primary focus of my laboratory. Due to the central roles that extracellular vesicles have in aging and chronic disease, this work will provide a model that can be applied to many other types of exposures and various chronic diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE During development, genetic patterning instructs tissues to form complex shapes that are crucial for proper function. Using whole-organ live imaging and approaches from physics, this study will analyze how gene expression patterns and cell-scale chirality govern tissue-scale mechanical forces to sculpt visceral organs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The mission of the Harvard/MIT MD-PhD Program is to “train the next-generation of premier and diverse physician- scientist leaders” who embody the dual-calling to make a difference today by touching the life of a patient in need and make a difference tomorrow by achieving scientific breakthroughs that will change our world. By harnessing the educational, clinical, and scientific resources of Harvard Medical School, Harvard University, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and its world-class hospitals and affiliated institutes, we aim to provide our students with unparalleled depth and breadth of clinical and research opportunities supported by a profoundly caring and invested community of student colleagues, faculty mentors, and program staff. Our dynamic training program is based on a series of academic and integrative objectives, girded by principles of rigor, integrity, responsibility, self-evaluation, inclusivity, diversity, and empathy, with the ultimate goal of contributing to a much-needed, multidisciplinary MD-PhD workforce to serve the critical health care and biomedical technology needs of the United States and beyond.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Good quality sleep is essential for the beneficial and restorative effects of sleep, while sleep disturbances negatively impact our mental and physical health. The proposed study will reveal how the neural dynamics and functional connectivity of preoptic neurons with stress-regulatory noradrenergic neurons in the locus coeruleus and corticotropin-releasing hormone neurons in the paraventricular nucleus regulate the duration and quality of sleep after stress. The results will provide a comprehensive framework enhancing our understanding of the regulation of sleep when disturbed by stress and the benefits of improving sleep in attenuating stress-related cognitive symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The mechanisms by autism spectrum disorder (ASD)-linked genes cause sex-specific differences in behavior and brain function are relatively unknown. We have discovered a female-specific dysfunction of neocortical circuits and sensory processing in mouse models of ASD caused deletion of Pten. The proposed work will determine the sex-specific brain mechanisms, focusing on metabotropic glutamate and Estrogen receptor α signaling, to understanding the interaction of sex and a high confidence ASD risk gene in regulation of brain function and sensory processing.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to leverage widespread smartphone use in urban Ghana together with accessible technology adapted to the Ghanaian setting to overcome barriers to home blood pressure monitoring in pregnancy. The proposed study will adapt and measure feasibility and acceptability (R21 Phase) and evaluate adherence and clinical response (R33 Phase) of a Bluetooth blood pressure monitor and smartphone app-enhanced home blood pressure monitoring intervention among pregnant women in Ghana. Implementing home blood pressure monitoring in a low-and-middle-income country setting will provide a critical step toward frequent assessment of blood pressures, earlier diagnosis of hypertensive disorders of pregnancy, and prevention of serious maternal morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Our project explores the intricate interplay of genomic instability and chromatin dynamics in C9orf72-associated ALS with frontotemporal dementia (C9-ALS/FTD). Through mapping cell-specific patterns of transposable element (TE) mobilization, elucidating the c-JUN/TE/cGAS/STING pathway activation, and investigating therapeutic interventions, we aim to shed light on the pathogenesis of C9-ALS/FTD and unveil potential treatment strategies. Ultimately, our endeavor seeks to unravel the mechanisms of neurodegeneration.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Latine sexual and gender minority (SGM) adolescents and young adults (AYA) have been shown to have worse mental, physical, and sexual health outcomes than non-SGM AYA, but research is lacking on the experiences of Latine SGM AYA who reside in rural settings who may have increased concerns around confidentiality and stigma in their communities. This research supplement adds additional quantitative and qualitative data collection with SGM AYA to an ongoing study that has been designed to examine the effects of multiple social determinants on sexual health in Latine AYA in an agricultural setting in California. The proposed research will fill a critical gap in literature regarding disparities in sexual health outcomes for Latine SGM AYA residing in rural areas and by deepening our understanding of structural factors that limit or promote sexual health in this population to ultimately increase Latine SGM AYA’s well-being and positive sexual health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: The proposed studies will elucidate the contribution of specific engineered nanomaterial properties that determine in vitro and in vivo toxicity, as well as provide mechanistic information to help develop therapeutic interventions to block their inflammation when inhaled. These results will also be used to help develop treatments to block inflammation caused by various particles including silicates. Finally, this information will be used to develop safer materials to protect workers and end users.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glioblastoma is an incurable primary malignant brain cancer and is characterized by a profound immunosuppressive microenvironment which renders this cancer highly resistant to immunotherapy. The proposed studies will exert a profound effect in the field by dissecting targetable metabolic and molecular mechanisms regulating the function of tumor associated macrophages, which are instrumental for the maintenance of immunosuppressive state of glioblastoma. This mechanistic understanding will be critical to provide our clinical partners with novel therapeutic approaches to overcome immunosuppression and to enhance the efficacy of immunotherapy in GBM patients, which will be tested in subsequent clinical trials.
