IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose a novel healthcare-community partnership between medical clinics and food banks, called Nutrition OUtReach In Systems of Healthcare (NOURISH), to address food insecurity (lack of consistent access to food) by directly delivering bags of food to patients in clinic. We will evaluate NOURISH in a multicenter randomized controlled trial in food insecure patients with hematologic malignancies receiving transplant and cellular therapy (TCT). We focus on this patient population because of their significant need – most relocate to a cancer center for their care, away from their home support network, and struggle with malnutrition, depression, and other adverse outcomes – and potential for long-term sustainability: bundled payments for TCT give health systems an incentive to support NOURISH and similar collaborations with food banks if we can demonstrate improved outcomes and lower healthcare costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Research suggests that synaptic activity and signaling can regulate social behavior that is essential to survive for many species. However, the links between synaptic regulation and social behavior are not completely understood. As δ-catenin is involved in the regulation of synaptic function and linked to autism, the proposed work will investigate the δ-catenin-mediated link of synaptic, cellular, and neural substrates to social behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bereaving a drug overdose death is more common than ever before and this special grief is compounded by guilt, shame, stigma, isolation, and adverse substance use and mental health outcomes. In the proposed practice-research partnership, we aim to increase access to peer grief support for those bereaving an overdose death to help improve outcomes and mitigate downstream consequences that impact both the individual and the community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The internal sensory nervous system maintains bodily homeostasis by monitoring the status of organs and controlling behavior and physiology. Using genetic tools to dissect neural circuits, I will determine the sensory properties and behavioral/physiological role of brainstem efferent pathways, focusing on neural control of appetite. This proposal will build a neuroanatomical and functional roadmap of the viscerosensory neural circuits in the brainstem, providing insights into developing targeted strategies for treating obesity, diabetes, eating disorders, and other diseases.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Women are the fastest growing subgroup of United States Veterans and policy makers are cognizant of the demand on resources for the health and well-being of women Veterans. While some cancers that affect women, such as cervical and breast cancer, have seen a dramatic reduction in mortality due to advances in prevention and early detection, the cure rate for ovarian cancer has not changed in four decades and remains below 40%. The results of this project will lead to a better understanding of the microenvironmental changes that precede ovarian cancer initiation. Such information is necessary to develop strategies for ovarian cancer prevention and early detection, which are urgently needed in clinical practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Progressive aging is a major risk factor for developing degenerative retinal diseases, however molecular mechanisms that regulate cellular aging in the retina are poorly understood. This work seeks to use approaches that have been previously applied to studying retinal development and regeneration to uncover gene regulatory networks that control retinal aging and identify putative molecular targets that can induce retinal rejuvenation. This work will produce many broadly applicable datasets that will be both expand our understanding of retinal aging and central nervous system aging more generally. We anticipate that this work will provide great insight into the mechanisms controlling aging and identify potential targets for intervention to slow or reverse retinal aging and thus delay the onset of age-related blinding diseases.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Over the past 10 years, we have identified that a specific enzyme system that degrades structural proteins within the heart muscle is upregulated following a heart attack. This study will determine how interruption of this enzyme system by local injection of specifically designed molecules will improve heart structure and function following a heart attack. This study is the first to use these new local target approaches, which will provide specific treatment to the heart but not cause side-effects – a problem with medications that are given by mouth or injection. These studies will directly demonstrate the utility of a new strategy for preventing patients from developing heart failure. These results will set the stage for an entirely new treatment approach for patients suffering from heart failure after a heart attack.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many cancer treatments are gonadotoxic and have a high likelihood of subsequent infertility, placing comprehensive fertility care at the forefront of quality care delivery to ensure that adolescent and young adult (AYA) patients are not disproportionately affected by their cancer experience. Understanding the multilevel influences across the cancer care continuum, including patient-, provider-, system-, and policy-level factors, is critical to effectively improve oncofertility care and create optimal long-term outcomes. My dissertation research will use cancer-registry data to characterize the fertility experiences of ethnically diverse AYAs and will qualitatively explore barriers/facilitators to guideline-concordant fertility discussions among cancer care providers, while my postdoctoral research will extend this work to investigate provider implementation and perceived actionability of fertility guidelines and insurer adherence to legislative mandates and barriers to covering fertility preservation through insurer perspectives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Project 2  Women of minority race/ethnicity, lower income, lower education, and rural residence have limited access to  higher quality breast cancer screening and newer technologies that can detect more cancer and reduce  unnecessary diagnostic follow-up. The proposed study will comprehensively evaluate how targeted facility-  level changes, including the use of artificial intelligence for automated mammography interpretation, can  promote greater equity in breast cancer screening outcomes. This study will generate evidence to guide  practitioners and policymakers in optimizing the quality of care in cancer screening and reducing  the unequal  burden of cancer in our society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Overall This Program renewal will provide evidence to improve the equity and effectiveness of breast cancer screening and surveillance. We will create risk prediction tools that perform well for all racial and ethnic groups and examine factors that influence the quality of breast imaging across radiology facilities to identify opportunities to improve care. Our findings will provide timely information to inform decision making about the frequency and type of breast cancer screening and surveillance for women, healthcare providers, and policymakers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Modified Public Health Relevance Section We propose to establish the Midwest Center for Cryo-Electron Tomography (MCCET) at the University of Wisconsin, Madison, a National Service Network Hub for Cryo-Electron Tomography. The MCCET will provide national and international access to state-of-the-art equipment and well-trained technical staff to support the growing need for cryo-ET of biomedically-relevant specimens from isolated macromolecules to tissue from organisms. The MCCET will enable researchers, inside and outside of the national network of service centers, to prepare specimens suitable for on-site cryo-ET data acquisition and data processing, and to train and cross-train in a broad-range of cryo-ET workflows.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Hepatitis B virus (HBV) is a common cause of chronic liver diseases such as chronic hepatitis, cirrhosis, and hepatocellular carcinoma, affecting 1.25 million people in the United States and 240 million worldwide. The overall goal of this application is to determine the importance and underlying molecular mechanisms of apolipoprotein E in HBV infection and morphogenesis. The outcomes of this application will provide novel targets for discovery and development of new classes of antiviral drugs towards elimination of chronic HBV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The escalating drug overdose crisis in the US, exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic, disproportionately affects African American and American Indian/Alaska Native populations. The proposed project seeks to optimize harm reduction strategies through mathematical modeling and decision tools developed in collaboration with health departments and community stakeholders. By assessing the effectiveness and health equity outcomes of these interventions and tailoring strategies to local contexts in six jurisdictions, we aim to provide actionable insights to guide resource allocation and the implementation of evidence-based interventions to address the overdose epidemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a prevalent and progressive obstructive lung disease caused by cigarette smoke exposure with few effective therapies. The role of mitochondrial dysfunction and cellular senescence, a state of cell arrest, in COPD pathogenesis remain unknown and an area of high scientific interest. This work will define how adenine nucleotide translocase (ANT2), a mitochondrial ADP/ATP translocase, influences mitochondrial dysfunction that drives cellular senescence and abnormal repair of the lung epithelium, thus opening the potential for ANT as a therapeutic target for COPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Housing instability — a lack of stable, secure, and adequate housing that results from poverty and structural racism — is a major social determinant of health for HIV and one of the reasons for the striking lack of progress toward goals to end the HIV epidemic in the US. In this study, we will rigorously evaluate a potentially transformative city-level transitional housing program for people with HIV experiencing housing instability, leveraging lottery drawings from a waitlist to estimate causal effects and conducting an implementation evaluation. This approach could significantly impact both HIV- and non-HIV-related outcomes, and this study will provide critical evidence to policymakers at a time when many cities are considering housing support programs and various other anti-poverty interventions (e.g., guaranteed income).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE This project aims to create a "digital twin" of cancer tumors, specifically focusing on a treatment called radiopharmaceutical therapy, which targets cancer cells with precision. Using advanced computer models, our goal is to understand better and predict how cancer treatments work in individual patients, leading to more effective and personalized care. This research holds the promise of significantly improving the outcomes for children with neuroblastoma by offering insights that could lead to treatments that are both more effective in battling the disease and less harmful to the patient's overall health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Opioid overdose deaths have reached historically high records in the United States and are particularly concentrated among patients after emergency department (ED) discharge. Evidence-based treatment modules to reduce repeat opioid overdose and mortality are lacking in this patient population. We propose to test a bundled intervention, including telehealth, peer support specialist, buprenorphine, and linkage for definitive care, that is designed to increase treatment uptake in this patient population post-ED discharge, reduce repeat opioid overdoses, and end overdose deaths.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Contact PD/PI: Barcellos-Hoff, Mary H NARRATIVE The type and pattern of immune cell infiltrate in breast cancer is of growing clinical importance as they associate with response to therapy and are the specific target of immunotherapy. However, the factors that influence the genesis of the type of tumor immune microenvironment (TiME) have yet to be defined. Our proposed systematic, mechanistic, high content analysis and modeling of the cellular and molecular mechanisms by which breast cancers evade the immune system focuses on will elucidate key factors that govern the origins of the TiME. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Contact PD/PI: Brakenridge, Scott Charles NARRATIVE Rather than acute mortality, a significant proportion of severe trauma and sepsis patients develop chronic critical illness (CCI), primarily characterized by recurrent infections, a failure to physically rehabilitate and dismal long- term outcomes. The overarching goal of our laboratory’s research program is to define distinct immunologic endotypes after severe injury or sepsis, to determine their role in the chronic inflammation, immunosuppression and muscle wasting, and to delineate their interactions, such that therapeutic interventions may be identified. IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Occupational accidents and work-related diseases still occur on a tremendous scale with over 90% of worker injuries and deaths occurring in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs). Many occupational safety and health interventions have been developed and implemented in high-income countries which significantly improve employees’ safety and health; however, their established methods often use in-person training that is impractical in LMICs due to limited resources and budgetary restrictions. Using an mHealth (mobile-based technology for improving health) approach as a foundation, an evidence- based Safety Climate intervention program (which incorporates effective instructional methods and training strategies developed by our team and delivered via mobile methods) will be created and tested in Malaysian companies to address the significant knowledge gap regarding the impact of Safety Climate interventions on workers’ health and safety in LMICs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative Over 300 different inherited mutations have been found in IKs channels that decrease the activity of IKs channels and cause a prolonged cardiac action potential (i.e. Long QT Syndrome), which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias in patients. We have identified a family of compounds that activate IKs channels, shorten the cardiac action potential, and are antiarrhythmic when applied to cardiomyocytes. We will here test variants of these compounds in order to develop a drug that will shorten the cardiac action potential to prevent cardiac arrhythmias and sudden cardiac deaths in Long QT Syndrome patients.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Persons with COPD have significant functional disability but cannot access rehabilitative treatment at hospital-based conventional pulmonary rehabilitation (PR) programs. This project will determine whether an Internet-mediated, pedometer-based walking program can increase physical activity in persons with COPD who cannot access PR, compared to usual care. This proposal has high potential to deliver an immediate solution to a pressing clinical need. The proposed research addresses Rehabilitation R&D Service's current priority area of improving disabled Veterans' health-related quality of life by reducing disease burden and maximizing functional recovery.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Minimal information is available on the health care experiences and needs of Veterans with spinal cord injury or disorders (SCI/D) who identify as lesbian, gay, bisexual or transgender (LGBT). Veterans and Active Duty Service Members with SCI/D have access to a large comprehensive system of specialty care within the VA health care system for physical and mental health care across their lifetime. The mission of the VA SCI/D Centers is to maximize function and independence and promote quality of life, and SCI/D care covers physical functioning, wellness, medical and surgical needs, and psychosocial care provided via inpatient, outpatient and telehealth settings. However, Veterans with SCI/D who identify as LGBT may have additional health problems and concerns that are not addressed by standard SCI/D programs as VA providers may lack the experience, sensitivity, and/or knowledge to manage their specific needs. The goal of this study is to collect information from patients and providers to better understand these issues in order to offer quality care to these Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The proposed research will generate the first ever customizable, multispecies, multiannual models of WNV transmission. This research will employ simulations to identify when and where control interventions will be most effective to reduce WNV transmission, thereby improving human and animal health. As other arthropod-borne diseases (e.g., St. Louis and Lacrosse encephalitis; Lyme disease) also show seasonal patterns of disease transmission, the results of the proposed research will enhance understanding of WNV transmission dynamics, and the ecology and evolution of multiple arthropod-borne diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vibrio cholerae is the etiologic agent of the severe human diarrheal disease cholera, which is responsible for severe morbidity and mortality in developing countries around the world. These proposed studies will characterize Vibrio cholerae-gut microbiome interactions in the protective mucus layer of the gut during V. cholerae infection, with the goal of better understanding how V. cholerae using intestinal mucin to promote pathogenesis and interactions with resident microorganisms and the host, and, potentially, discovering novel therapeutic and prophylactic interventions for cholera.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE My research program aims to identify the proteins and signaling pathways that coordinate mRNA translation to prevent catastrophic proteostatic collapse. Defects in translation, RNA-protein granules, and protein degradation are associated with degenerative conditions of the nervous, muscular, and skeletal systems, cancer, diabetes, aging, and neurodevelopmental disorders. A mechanistic understanding of protein homeostasis will aid in the development of novel therapeutic strategies to improve health across the lifespan.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research aims to study the intrinsic and synaptic adaptations of pyramidal neurons in the layer V of the primary motor cortex using experimental models of Parkinson’s disease (PD). With this research, we will gain mechanistic understanding of the aberrant motor cortical activity seen in individuals afflicted by PD, providing critical insight into PD’s pathophysiology that can help us to improve the treatment of this devastating disease. Therefore, this research is relevant to the missions of the NIH and the NINDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE This study aims to contribute to the elimination of persistent tobacco use disparities among sexual and/or gender minority (SGM) groups; disparities which are worse in places with high levels of stigma against SGM people. Drawing from Empowerment Theory and building on findings from Oklahoma, we will work with community partners to (1) inform, (2) develop, and (3) pilot test the protocol for a smoking cessation intervention tailored for sexual and/or gender minority (SGM) people who live in high stigma places. Findings from this project will improve understanding of the factors that support smoking cessation for SGM people, and will develop and assess the feasibility and acceptability of a novel and scale-able intervention protocol to improve smoking cessation outcomes for SGM people who live in challenging environments that exacerbate SGM tobacco use inequities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE Intimate partner violence (IPV) is common and particularly dangerous during the perinatal period. Healthcare- community linkages, particularly through use of community-based doulas, offer an important opportunity to support perinatal survivors and ultimately reduce IPV and improve health outcomes. Through a community- academic partnership, this study will evaluate the effectiveness of a healthcare based universal empowerment intervention delivered during prenatal visits compared with universal empowerment plus an IPV-trained doula in reducing perinatal IPV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inflammation in the placenta can cause harm to the developing baby and to future pregnancies; yet, often there is no explanation as to why it occurred. Our goal is to uncover the interactions between the mother’s immune system and the fetal placenta that are altered, resulting in a chronic villitis of unknown etiology diagnosis at birth. Understanding these interactions can lead to new ways to diagnose and treat this damaging inflammation, leading to improved pregnancy and infant outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because many clinical and experimental vaccines fail to generate long-lasting humoral immunity, which is a key to preventing infection in the long term. The proposed study’s expected result is an in-depth understanding of the transcriptional regulation generating long-lasting humoral immunity that will be instrumental in identifying targets for pharmacological intervention and designing an immunomodulator/vaccine adjuvant that can enhance the duration of long-lasting humoral immunity upon vaccination. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH’s mission to develop fundamental knowledge that will help to reduce the burdens of human disease and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative In addition to the significant social, psychological, and physical tolls of eosinophilic gastrointestinal diseases (EGIDs), the annual healthcare burden of eosinophilic esophagitis alone is estimated to reach $1.4 billion. The prevalence of EGIDs in children and adults is increasing worldwide, yet the mechanisms whereby eosinophils contribute to pathology or pathogenesis of disease is not known. The overall goals of this project are to identify functions of intestinal tissue eosinophils that impact GI diseases and to define core cellular processes that govern these functions. Completion of this proposal will provide fundamental insights to speed the development of precision eosinophil-modulating therapies to treat EGIDs and other GI diseases associated with eosinophilia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Not having enough healthy food to eat during pregnancy can lead to health disparities for both moms and babies, so some healthcare systems are offering “medically tailored groceries”—foods chosen by a nutritional professional and available to be picked up for several weeks or months-- to address this. Sometimes, lack of transportation or other challenges can make it hard for families to take advantage of MTG. Our study helps us understand if delivering MTG to a family’s home, as well as adding nutrition and cooking education, can improve outcomes for moms and babies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Men and women who inject drugs and living with HIV are less likely to adhere to antiretroviral therapy (ART) or continue with opioid substitution therapy. To address the paucity of interventions to improve these outcomes, the proposed project will develop and assess preliminary impact of a family-engaged support intervention, called Project Vuselela, led by peer navigators. ART adherence and OST continuation are the primary outcomes. Findings will provide essential information for related family-engaged interventions globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Target-directed microRNA degradation (TDMD) is a mechanism by which endogenous target RNAs degrade specific microRNAs to modulate gene expression. Treatment of T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL) cells by glucocorticoid induces apoptosis through BIM expression, which can lead to microRNA-221/222 degradation via TDMD. We will examine how microRNA-221/222 degradation may contribute to T-ALL apoptosis, globally profile TDMD events and explore the role of TDMD during glucocorticoid-treatment of T-ALL.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: RELEVANCE (See Instructions): Results from our surveillance sampling, AdV phylodynamics, advanced computational tools and predictive transmission Is will provide knowledge of disease transmission in a spillover hotspot. Our protocol will demonstrate how tools and predictive models will provide knowledge of disease transmission pathways in complex environments. The proposed work will enable future research targeting dangerous but rarepathogens, such as single-stranded RNA viruses of zoonotic origin (e.g., Ebola). Transmission d ynamics of viral pathogens will inform proactive health and conservation policies to i reduce cross-species disease transmission at a time of increasing climate change and human-wildlife interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: Narrative Antibiotics severely alter the gut microbiome producing a state of microbial imbalance called dysbiosis. How dysbiosis affects cancer progression is largely unknown. This project will expand our understanding of the crosstalk between the gut microbiome, the tumor microenvironment, and cellular immunotherapy during antibiotic-induced dysbiosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Radiation therapy for the clinical management of brain tumors and metastases is linked with severe cognitive decline and neuroinflammation in cancer survivors. We hypothesize that radiation-induced aberrant activation of the glial complement cascade play a causal role in development of cognitive impairments. This proposal will address glial complement activation mechanism and translationally feasible intervention to curtain this unmet medical need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immunotherapies hold immense potential to provide cures for many cancers and metastatic disease, but the complexity of activating and sustaining anti-tumor immune responses will necessitate combinatorial treatment regimes and a better understanding of how the tumor microenvironment (TME) affects response. Here we develop a in vitro model of the tumor-immune circuit which allows precise control over spatial, molecular, cellular, and mechanical aspects of the TME that affect response to immunotherapy, and use it for both mechanistic studies as well as high-throughput predictive screening of immune therapies in a tumor- or patient- specific manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The diversification of genomics research cohorts is a national priority intended to accelerate research and improve individualized prevention, treatment and care. Concrete, tailored strategies are needed to ethically engage various individuals living in the rural South to promote equitable access to genomic discovery and translation. Thus, the proposed study leverages a multi-disciplinary team and stakeholder-engaged approach to ultimately identify best practices for community translation of genomic discoveries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We have identified 2.5-fold higher prevalence of doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity (DIC) in African American (AA) than European American survivors yet the biological basis of this racial disparity in DIC is poorly understood. We will use human induced pluripotent stem cell-derived cardiomyocytes derived from AA survivors to discover novel genetic variants for DIC and validate the mechanisms by which these genetic variants influence this potentially fatal drug complication. This knowledge will provide clinicians with a validated genomic tool to predict if a patient will experience DIC and a route to discover genotype-specific cardioprotective drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE MDM2 and its numerous isoforms are key regulators of the expression and function of the p53 gene, a critical tumor suppressor that prevents inappropriate cell growth and proliferation. The proposed research will study the molecular connection between DNA damage, MDM2 isoform switching, p53, and cancer. Unraveling this pathway could lead to the discovery of novel therapeutic intervention points and thus be a crucial stepping-stone for cancer drug discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ovarian cancer affects only women for which cisplatin is a commonly used chemotherapeutic drug but it causes neurotoxicity leading to painful neuropathy, cognitive decline, called `chemobrain' and alterations in gait with increased propensity to fall/fractures, which may continue even after the discontinuation of treatment. We hypothesize that the activation of p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase and c-Jun N-terminal kinase plays a critical role in cisplatin-induced damage to the nervous system and that inhibition of these pathways will attenuate cisplatin-induced neurotoxic side effects in female mice with ovarian cancer. We expect that the results of our study will lead to the development of novel therapeutics to reduce the debilitating sequelae of cisplatin in women with ovarian and other cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The overarching goal of this study is to identify effective metabolic based diagnostic and therapeutic strategies to improve the overall survival of patients with Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). We propose to investigate the positron emission tomography (PET) tracer, 18F-BnTP as a novel metabolic diagnostic and to develop metabolic based therapeutic strategies targeting oxidative mitochondrial metabolism in therapy resistant KRAS/LKB1 and EGFR mutant lung tumors. This work represents a new approach to overcoming therapy resistance in KRAS/LKB1 and EGFR mutant lung tumors – one in which the tumor’s metabolic and bioenergetic dependencies are profiled and then selectively targeted.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE Despite rising rates of daily cannabis use in young adults and elevated risk for adverse cognitive, psychiatric, and social outcomes, very few young adults with cannabis use disorder (CUD) receive treatment, with disparities by sex and race/ethnicity. This project will use rigorous quantitative and qualitative methods to test the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of MOMENT-V, a novel, fully-remote telehealth and mHealth intervention in primary care, as a means of facilitating treatment for the vulnerable and underserved population of young adults with CUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance This proposal aims to determine key mechanisms by which altered cellular metabolism drives disease risk, for instance an up to 28% higher rate of breast cancer incidence in patients with type 2 diabetes. Our innovative solutions map events driven by the metabolism-linked protein modification O-GlcNAc with control over cellular timing and the cellular location in which they operate, filling critical existing gaps in knowledge that do not track spatiotemporal mechanistic aspects. We apply our “time and space” cellular tools to the oncogenic transcription factor NFkB to determine actionable therapeutic strategies for metabolism-linked cancer risk and establish a well-rounded research program to target fundamental and applied mechanisms able to link metabolism with human disease risks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: In this one-year project, we will create a digital twin for rectal cancer treatments by extending our radiobiology- based tumor simulation model. We will conduct this project using personnel, tools, and data readily available to us, including a prospectively collected, outcome-annotated institutional rectal cancer cohort consisting of patients treated with total neoadjuvant therapy, with tumor genomic assay data, including either long-course chemoradiotherapy or with short-course radiotherapy. In addition to the implications for rectal cancer treatment in general, the results of this project could be particularly useful in establishing a digital twin model for use as a baseline component of our parent ImmunoRad ROBIN U54 rectal cancer analyses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Deficits in effortful control (the top-down control of self-regulation) represent a major transdiagnostic risk factor for childhood psychopathology, yet associations between the caregiving and neurobiological mechanisms that disrupt the early development of effortful control are unknown. This prospective longitudinal study investigates the development of effortful control in the first three years of life, examining the extent that maternal mind- mindedness (accurately interpreting infant behavior as resulting from infant mental states), as a specific yet critically understudied component of parenting, alters infant brain structural and functional connectivity in key brain regions underlying effortful control development. Findings will elucidate maternal mind-mindedness as a modifiable component of the caregiving environment that can be targeted in early parent-child interventions to enhance infant brain connectivity and support development of effortful control to reduce risk for developmental psychopathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In the parent award, we aim to improve image-guidance of pediatric cardiac catheterizations by developing a closed-loop, multi-beat data synthesis reconstruction pipeline. Recently, our group, led by the Candidate for supplemental support, has developed a fast, inline approach to score image quality. In this supplement, we request support for this current graduate student to pursue the use of image quality as a metric to extend our imaging framework and further their graduate training.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Consistent with its fundamental roles in neurobiology and cell development, complete knockouts of dynein stop the entire MT transport machinery and inhibit mitosis. Mutations that alter the processivity or velocity of cytoplasmic dynein movement lead to pathogenesis of motor neuron degeneration, Alzheimer’s disease, ALS, lissencephaly and schizophrenia, and the absence of axonemal dynein arms causes male infertility and primary ciliary dyskinesia. A detailed investigation of dynein’s mechanochemical cycle and its regulation by dynactin and cargo adaptor proteins will significantly contribute to our understanding of how points mutants in the dynein/dynactin complex contribute to human disease and the development of specific chemical inhibitors of dynein function for the treatment of these diseases in future studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This real-world efficacy study (NIH stage 3) will determine whether overcoming common information and communication technology (ICT) access barriers (i.e., to stable cellular phone, broadband internet, and navigation) can enhance community services' ability to address social needs and improve health outcomes for socioeconomically disadvantaged populations. In a randomized controlled trial of 600 patients seeking care in urban, suburban, and rural emergency departments, we will collaborate with community and digital service providers and leverage existing protocols and scalable health information technology to evaluate the integration of ICT access and digital navigation assistance. By facilitating stable cellphone access and digital navigation within our screening and referral infrastructure, we aim to gain critical insights into whether these interventions lead to more successful connections to social services and improved health outcomes for disadvantaged populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: PALO ALTO VETERANS INSTIT FOR RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will identify new approaches to treating a group of blood disorders called myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPN), that arise due to mutations in the gene, calreticulin (CALR). MPN is characterized by excess blood cell production, an increased risk of blood clotting and bleeding, in addition to increased risk of transformation to acute leukemia and no curative treatment options apart from stem cell transplantation. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to understanding mechanisms of disease with the goal of identifying better, more specific treatment options, thus reducing the burden of human disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: An increase in unexplained persistent respiratory complaints in Gulf War [and Post-9/11 Veterans] has led to mounting concerns that region or conflict specific inhalational hazards cause occult lung injury resulting in chronic small airways inflammation and fibrosis, referred to as deployment-related chronic bronchiolitis (DR-CB) in this proposal. [At present, DR-CB is difficult to diagnose without resorting to surgical lung biopsy. This study will determine whether parametric response mapping, a new CT scan analytical technique, can substantially advance our ability to non-invasively diagnose DR-CB and assess its prevalence in symptomatic SW Asia- deployed Veterans, including those with Gulf War Veterans Illness. The pathogenesis of DR-CB is poorly understood and no treatments for this disorder have been tested in humans or animal models. This proposal utilizes a novel murine model of chronic bronchiolitis to elucidate critical pathologic pathways and potential treatments for this disorder.]

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Traumatic brain injuries occur frequently in combat and are among the leading causes of chronic disabilities in the Veteran population. A well-recognized complication of penetrating brain injury is post-traumatic epilepsy (PTE). The treatment of PTE is often inadequate. The VA has a clear mission to improve the outcome of combat casualties, and to reduce the disabilities of these Veterans currently suffering from complications of Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI). This mission is based on the mandate to provide to provide support to the Department of Defense for the care of combat casualties, and to treat those diseases that are disproportionally represent in the Veteran population. In this project, we seek to further improve and validate a novel PTE animal model which will aid in improving therapies for PTE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcoholic hepatitis is a disease of intense liver inflammation and injury caused by heavy alcohol use that can be deadly when severe. Cytokine IL17 may contribute to the development of alcoholic hepatitis by stimulating liver sinusoidal endothelial cells (LSECs) to produce chemokines that drives the inflammatory response. In this study, we will explore the mechanisms of IL17-mediated LSEC activation in alcoholic hepatitis and experiment with novel ways of inhibiting IL17 production by targeting a gene regulatory element.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to develop and evaluate a digital mental health intervention (DMHI) for adolescents who engage in nonsuicidal self-injury (NSSI) and who are not currently engaged in treatment. I will employ user- centered design methodologies to understand adolescents’ specific needs and preferences, which will guide the development of a scalable, low-intensity DMHI designed to be implemented within the digital offerings of a large mental health advocacy website. The DMHI will support the acquisition and practice of skills to reduce NSSI frequency, and encourage use of external supports to increase further help-seeking among high-risk adolescents who are currently unable or uninterested in accessing traditional psychological treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aiming to address the significant mental health needs and barriers to care faced by refugee and immigrant “newcomer” youth in the United States, this project proposes a community-based intervention, “Meet Me on the Pitch,” that integrates behavioral health services, school, and sports programming. The study will apply a mixed-methods approach to develop and refine the intervention, assess its feasibility and acceptability among newcomer youth, and measure the short-term impact of the intervention on mental health outcomes and related social determinants of health including access to healthcare services, school engagement, and social connection of participants. Through rigorous evaluation and authentic community engagement to develop and implement this intervention, this project offers an innovative, upstream approach to transforming behavioral and mental health service delivery and can inform strategies to improve health equity for underserved youth.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Globally, linkage to HIV care and retention on antiretroviral therapy are challenges to achieving successful HIV outcomes. mHealth approaches to improving HIV outcomes have not been tailored to older people with HIV in resource-limited settings. We will adapt an evidence-based mHealth intervention and tailor for older people with HIV in the Ukrainian context, test extensively using established methods to ensure a fully functional prototype, and then evaluate feasibility, acceptability, and efficacy of the adapted mHealth intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative Racial and ethnic disparities in food insecurity have persisted over decades and are associated with higher rates of chronic diseases like diabetes and depression, worse chronic disease management, and increased healthcare costs. Aware of the importance of addressing food insecurity to reduce health disparities, there has been a rapid increase in food insecurity interventions, yet evidence to support the effectiveness of these interventions to improve health outcomes remains mixed. Leveraging a clinical-community partnership that has developed a patient-centered, multi-component food insecurity intervention, we will conduct a hybrid effectiveness-implementation study to understand the food interventions’ impact on health outcomes, impact on health care costs and identify implementation strategies for program scale out and sustainment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We will determine the molecular mechanism(s) by which Amino Acid Transporter, SLC7A5 regulate profibrotic TGF-β signaling. We plan to further unravel the downstream cellular, molecular, and metabolic mechanism(s) by which SLC7A5, HIF and antiapoptotic protein, BCl-2 crosstalk in fibrosis and the critical role of SLC7A5 in fibroblast apoptosis and mitophagy. Furthermore, we will investigate whether targeting SLC7A5 will ameliorate severe disease and promote efficient recovery in a therapeutic model of lung fibrosis of both young and aged hosts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Relevance Black patients with advanced cancer who receive cancer care in outpatient settings have unmet spiritual needs, receive care isolated from their faith communities, and are more likely to receive overly aggressive, burdensome, futile, and less hospice, end-of-life care than their white counterparts. This study will provide evidence of how integration of health-care chaplaincy into outpatient oncology clinics, and its linkage with faith community spiritual care providers, promotes spiritual wellness and results in higher quality end-of-life decision-making and care for Black patients with advanced cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Darwinian evolution drives the emergence of resistance to targeted therapy in cancer. We propose to use results from our in vitro evolutionary game assay to parameterize a computer model to allow us to predict 3-dimensional dynamics on clinically relevant timescales. Further, we will extend our assay to function in vivo, allowing the community to test mathematically derived evolutionary therapy hypotheses in preclinical models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Improved treatment strategies for patients with cancer require enhanced tools to better predict patient response, model clonal heterogeneity, and identify novel treatment options for individual patients. This study validates accessible optical imaging tools and heterogeneity analysis to assess patient-derived tumor organoids for this purpose. These insights could ultimately lead to improved treatment options for cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project, Housing, Environment, And Living Conditions for Transformed Health (HEALTHe Birmingham), will seize a once-in-a-generation opportunity to determine the effectiveness of large-scale, multicomponent social determinants of health (SDoH) initiatives in reducing health disparities through improved housing and neighborhood conditions and indoor air quality. We will compare the cost-effectiveness, translation potential, and health equity implications of specific intervention components for lung health and chronic disease risk. This innovative approach will help us fill a knowledge gap regarding the potential of SDoH interventions to improve health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: The immune system dysfunction underlying Hidradenitis Suppurativa (HS) is poorly understood and the devastating effects this disease has on quality of life disproportionately affect women and minorities, highlighting a critical health care gap. This study will comprehensively characterize activated immune cells surrounding hair follicles within HS lesions, which represent the pathologic anatomic unit, with spatial precision and test the novel hypothesis that neurogenic inflammation contributes to dysregulated microbe sensing in HS by inducing strong Interleukin (IL)-1, TNF- and IL-17-mediated immune responses. We expect that the proposed studies will identify neurotransmitter inhibitors, many of which are FDA-approved for other indications, as promising treatments for HS.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While millions of Americans harbor the pre-cancerous lesion, Barrett’s esophagus, putting them at elevated risk of esophageal cancer, many will not develop cancer and this progression is poorly understood. IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acanthamoeba keratitis is a blinding eye infection with poor treatment options. This study will determine whether steroid eye drops improve vision outcomes and also assess for genetic predictors of severe inflammation using metagenomic sequencing. IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative: Pediatric acute care is woefully insufficient among the low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) of sub- Saharan Africa due primarily to provider proficiency gaps. Our proposed studies will determine a strategy for blending a novel adaptive eLearning tool with face-to-face skills learning that includes key elements of repetition and reach to even the most rural providers, and ultimately understand its effect on improving quality of care in LMICs. Together, these results will create a model for provider education that integrates global health perspectives in advancing safe and effective treatment of children, worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative O-GlcNAc is the only known intracellular glycosylation signaling pathway in mammals, and is implicated in nearly every basic biological process from signal transduction and gene expression to cell division and differentiation. Here, we propose to apply new groundbreaking tools we have recently developed to uncover the principles of O-GlcNAc signaling, including its dynamics, how its propagated, and its role in transcriptional control of stem cell differentiation. This Equipment Supplement request for a high- throughput sonication device to lyse cells and nuclei without denaturing protein complexes will enable and facilitate the ongoing success of the projects.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The rotator cuff (RC) of the shoulder is a common source of pain and disability. Full-thickness RC tendon tears occur in >20% of the adult population and Veterans are particularly affected, due to the presence of injuries incurred during active duty and greater average age. Conventional magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and ultrasound (US) can be used to assess tendon tear size, muscle atrophy, and fatty infiltration, but are less well- suited for evaluation of tendon degeneration and muscle fibrosis. Both of these important variables can increase surgical complexity and lead to lower patient outcome scores. We propose to develop, optimize, validate and translate novel quantitative MRI and US techniques for comprehensive assessment of RC collagen abnormalities and fibrosis. These techniques may guide treatment decisions, operative planning, and yield prognostic information. In addition, these techniques may be useful for many applications that are highly relevant to the VA population, such as muscle wasting due to aging, cachexia, chronic bed rest, and nervous system injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic exposure to stressful experiences can result in maladaptive affective states yielding behavioral disturbances in rodents and stress-related mood disorders in humans. One potential cause is corticotropin- releasing hormone (CRH) signaling in bed nucleus of the stria terminalis (BNST), which is a sexually dimorphic integrative center for limbic information and valence monitoring. CRH-expressing BNST neurons (in the oval subnucleus) are critical mediators of the chronic stress response and may underlie sex differences therein. Our proposed studies will examine the role of BNST CRH signaling as a nexus for chronic stress-induced behavioral outcomes increasing our understanding of the impact of chronic stressors on affective states in both sexes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Most pancreatic ductal adenocarcinomas have a dense, fibrotic, and hypo-vascular stroma, rendering them hypoxic, nutrient deprived, and chemoresistant. The overall goal of this project is to gain a better understanding of the stromal components – vasculature and cancer associated fibroblasts – by which pancreatic cancer cells acquire essential nutrients. The information gained from these studies will provide guidance for precision medicine-based approaches targeting these essential metabolic “supply lines” in pancreas cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE- OVERALL The Alzheimer's Disease Research Center (ADRC) at New York University Langone Health has facilitated pioneering research to define transitions from normal aging to the subjective cognitive decline (SCD), mild cognitive impairment (MCI), and early dementia stages of AD; as well as AD biomarker development. We now propose to continue this long-standing successful research direction with a focus on understanding disease heterogeneity and delineating biomarkers and their role in these transitions, with the long-term goal of helping to develop novel interventions that will delay or prevent cognitive decline, to help achieve the NAPA goal of a cure by 2025.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions}: Depression is one of the most common complications of pregnancy and there are interventions that can help treat or even prevent depression symptoms among pregnant people. The earlier individuals start such preventive care, the sooner it can work, but there are often limited numbers of mental health care providers available, and it is not yet known which treatments work best for which patients. This research will help tailor treatment approaches to proactively prevent depression before it starts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The proposed project will make use of artificial intelligence (AI) to collect and analyze data from hospitalized patients with sepsis. We plan to conduct a clinical study to quantify the benefit of an AI assisted care protocol to reduce organ failure in patients with sepsis. We intend to seek regulatory approval for our AI system to maintain quality assurance and ensure patient safety. We have a very strong team of doctors and researchers who work closely together, covering all aspects of the proposed project, which we hope will help us improve the care of hospitalized patients with sepsis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative: Fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD) is an arterial disease that can cause stenosis (inward growth), aneurysm (outward growth), dissection (tearing), or tortuosity (abnormal bending) of blood vessels, leading to manifestations such as high blood pressure, stroke, heart attacks, and death. These dysplasia-associated arterial diseases are estimated to occur in 1-4% of the U.S. population and most often afflicts women. This study will use genetic and laboratory approaches to discover and characterize the involved genes and understand their functions in causing pathologic changes in the arterial wall, leading to the cardiovascular manifestations; the biologic insights from this study will be important for developing novel diagnostic and therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Anticancer drug resistance often results from cancer cells bypassing the targeted pathway by adopting alternative mechanisms to maintain their growth. We have identified hnRNP A18 as a key regulator of several cellular pathways controlling cancer growth and immune protection. Using structural biology, Computer Aided Drug Design, medicinal chemistry and cellular biology we are developing small molecules that can selectively inhibit hnRNP A18 to prevent cancer cells growth and immune evasion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative When developing new cancer treatments, many scientists use animal models in which human tumors are implanted into research animals (i.e. patient-derived xenografts or PDXs). However, we lack understanding of how we bias our results based on the methods we use to make new PDXs (e.g. implanting tumor pieces under the skin of immunocompromised mice as opposed to implanting into the site of origin). To improve the efficiency of pre-clinical research, this proposal will provide a clear answer to this question in head and neck cancer by methodically studying how tumor response to chemotherapy changes over time and the impact of a immune system on tumor evolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dysregulated high-density lipoprotein (HDL) levels are strongly correlated with an increased risk of cardiovascular diseases, including Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA). The use of biomimetic synthetic HDL (sHDL) nanoparticles has been shown to be effective in addressing this risk; however, the mechanism by which sHDL exerts its protective effects in AAA remains unknown. This work aims to describe how AAA pathogenesis is altered by treatment with sHDL, providing critical information for the development of therapeutics aimed at attenuating AAA pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Acute kidney injury (AKI) is a severe disease characterized by sudden deterioration of kidney function. The kidney is an active organ relying on energy produced by mitochondria (cell powerhouse). Non-treated AKI leads to end-stage renal disease; in the application, we will deliver competent mitochondria as a new therapeutic strategy to restore kidney cells function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will identify multi-level (e.g., individual, household, neighborhood, school/community) correlates and consequences of food insecurity in households (n=627) with racially/ethnically diverse children ages 5-16. Using mixed-methods (e.g., ecological momentary assessment (EMA), biomarkers, Geographical Information Services (GIS) data, focus groups), this study will examine when and how cardiometabolic risk emerges from food insecurity in childhood, mechanisms/pathways between food insecurity and cardiometabolic health, and multi-level factors that buffer against or exacerbate food insecurity to inform multi-sector interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will apply a novel dual-layer x-ray detector for calcium scoring to enable early detection and intervention of cardiovascular disease, especially when patients are asymptomatic. Our technology, which innovatively combines material engineering to tune electro-optical properties of chalcogenide alloys, detector structure design, and artificial intelligence-guided image processing, brings much-needed quantitative capabilities to x-ray imaging. This approach will allow accurate quantification of coronary artery calcium from chest x-rays and will have immense impact on proactive healthcare, improving the clinical outcomes of patients, and reducing the number of deaths associated with cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our laboratory has identified a new mechanism by which crosstalk between liver, brain, fat tissue, and kidney drives the most common form of kidney cancer, renal cell carcinoma. We have also observed that mice lose muscle mass as they develop renal cell carcinoma tumors, in a process called cancer cachexia. Work proposed in this supplement will ascertain how, and will support the work of the candidate, Andin Fosam, a rising star in the areas of muscle function, health maintenance, and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PARENT AWARD R35GM118027 NARRATIVE Our work focuses on understanding how inflammation resolves and tissues are repaired in the context of human health and disease. We aim to uncover mechanisms of cell migration within tissues, the signaling networks that regulate these processes and how they are integrated during wound healing. This work will impact our understanding and treatment of autoimmune disease, diabetic and other chronic wounds, cancer and immune deficiency disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Changes in thyroid hormone action profoundly affect both metabolism and food intake in man. Hypothyroidism results in obesity, reduced energy expenditure (EE), and hypophagia, while hyperthyroidism causes weight loss, increased EE, and hyperphagia. We discovered a novel AMPK signaling pathway that phosphorylates a specific thyroid hormone receptor (THRB2) and suppresses the thyroid axis and food intake, establishing this pathway as a central regulator of the hypothalamus and suggesting it may be dysfunctional in human obesity.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: HIV/AIDS affects about 37 million people worldwide including Veterans. Successful anti-HIV treatments can eliminate nearly all active viruses and prolong patients’ lives to nearly normal lifespans. However, the new challenge faced by aging patients is chronic neuroinflammation in the brain, leading to various HIV-associated neurocognitive disorders (HAND) that are found in more than 50% of HIV-infected individuals. Even under effective antiviral therapies, chronic HAND persists with high rates of delirium and dementia that can lead to suicide. According to a VA report, “the risk of suicide mortality in HIV-infected persons is 3-5 times higher than in HIV-uninfected counterparts.” What causes HAND is not well understood. Through our pilot studies, we have linked a HIV protein Vpr to HAND, and discovered a novel mechanism involving activation of the Sur1-Trpm4 channel. The goal of this proposal is to study the specific role(s) of Vpr in neuroinflammation, neurotoxicity, and viral wakening; as well as the possibility of treating HAND with a repurposed FDA-approved drug glibenclamide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early diagnosis and therapeutic intervention for the treatment of heart failure are key determinants of patient overall health. The current methods for diagnosis are restricted to detecting markers of cardiac injury and irreversible remodeling. We propose the use of 2-[18F]fluoropropionic acid-based PET to image the metabolic changes in cardiac metabolism which occur before the onset of debilitating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intranasal vaccination induces populations of resident memory T cells throughout the respiratory tract that can prevent infection with respiratory viruses, including influenza virus. This proposal seeks to define the role and mechanisms of respiratory tract resident memory CD8 T cells in natural respiratory virus transmission. Our findings will provide valuable insights for vaccine development that limits the spread of respiratory viruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Post-translational modifications, or the structural modification of a protein after it is folded, of key heart contractile proteins (cMyBP-C) lead to the quick and precise regulation of the heart. These modifications appear dysfunctional in cardiac myosin binding protein-C (cMyBP-C) during heart disease. In this proposal, we aim to study the functional consequences of modifying cMyBP-C under normal conditions, elevated stress, and therapeutically treated states of the heart to better understand the consequences of these protein modifications and, ultimately, to determine if altering these modifications can lead to improved heart health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T-cell therapy has revolutionized the treatment of relapsed and refractory hematologic malignancies; however, the immunologic impact and risk for infections and mortality following treatment have not been well-characterized. This Career Development Award focuses on applying advanced clinical epidemiology and simulation modeling to understand the immunologic impact of CAR T-cell therapy. Our overall objective is to identify predictive risk factors and cost-effective screening methods to allow for risk stratification, protocols for immunologic monitoring, and initiation of earlier interventions to mitigate the risk for morbidity and mortality and improve quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Early onset colorectal cancer occurs in individuals under age 50 and is an emerging and deadly form of colorectal cancer in the United States. Bacteria and other microbes in the colon are now thought to contribute to causing colorectal cancer. This proposal will seek to define the microbes and mechanisms leading to early onset colorectal cancer so that new ways to detect and prevent this disease can be identified.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) and its precursor amnestic mild cognitive impairment (aMCI) are major public health problems that may go unidentified in persons living with HIV (PLWH) because they must often be detected against the backdrop of additional mild cognitive problems directly related to HIV termed HIV-associated Neurocognitive Disorders (HAND) that can sometimes include memory problems. The aim of this study is to identify unique profiles of memory and thinking skills, biomarkers in body fluids, and brain changes that can distinguish between aMCI and HAND in PLWH to allow us to know who has aMCI and may eventually develop AD, and who has HAND and may not develop AD. Being able to identify PLWH who have aMCI will allow for treatments and interventions better targeted for aMCI/AD in PLWH and help to reduce fears among PLWH who do not have aMCI, a significantly more debilitating disorder that confers greater risk for dementia than HAND.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to investigate neuroimmunological and reward functions to study comorbid depression in women living with HIV (WLWH), a group heavily impacted by depression and its health consequences yet underrepresented in HIV research. This collaborative proposal bridges disciplines of depression, neuroimaging, HIV, and metabolomics in an effort to improve our understanding of neural mechanisms underlying depression in WLWH and has the potential to improve overall and mental health outcomes in this highly vulnerable group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mobile app mental health interventions are accessible and effective when used at the recommended dose; but when implemented in routine care, patients do not stay engaged long enough to see clinical benefits. The proposed research evaluates what drives patient engagement and tests the impact of two strategies— automated motivational push messaging and coach support—to improve engagement with an evidence-based mobile app intervention for depression and/or anxiety. Findings will lay the foundation for a program of research focused on optimizing mobile app interventions for engagement and effectiveness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with dementia represent the fastest growing population of hospice users in the U.S. and account for a quarter of all hospice spending. Behavioral symptoms such as agitation, anxiety, and hallucinations are nearly universal in advanced dementia and, despite limited evidence to support their use, the mainstay of such symptom management in hospice is off-label use of psychotropic medications. Given the growing number of patients with dementia enrolling in hospice services, a better understanding of 1) the factors that influence psychotropic prescribing in hospice (including patient and caregiver preferences), and 2) the intended and unintended outcomes of such use, are critical in order to inform caregiver, provider, and policy decisions regarding appropriate use of psychotropic medications in end-of-life care for dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Exposure to household air pollution from primitive energy sources (such as charcoal and wood-burning stoves and kerosene lamps) is a top-ten risk factor for morbidity and mortality worldwide. This research will investigate whether a whole-house energy intervention can produce meaningful health benefits for women, men, and children in rural Rwandan homes. Outputs from this work will increase the clinical knowledge-base on the health effects on household air pollution and will generate policy-relevant information on scalable solutions to achieving cleaner, healthier forms of household energy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The novel coronavirus 2019 (COVID) pandemic is the most significant Public Health crisis of the past century, and African-Americans are disproportionately impacted-- with rates of COVID-19 infection and mortality that are 2 to 4 times higher than those in Whites. Because most research on COVID-19 has focused on the physiological consequences of the disease, we know almost nothing about the psychosocial impact of COVID- 19, particularly in the most vulnerable groups. The goal of the proposed project is to examine the impact of COVID-related psychosocial stressors on vascular aging in a cohort of African-American women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Cancer is treated with DNA damaging chemotherapy and radiation therapy (XRT). Cancer cells are sensitive to DNA damage as they divide rapidly and have often acquired mutations in mechanisms that safeguard genome stability. Immune cells are also sensitive to DNA damage as they divide extremely rapidly (<6 h). Since cancer is treated with combinations of DNA damaging chemotherapy, XRT and immunotherapy, we investigate new approaches to separate the impact of DNA damage on cancer and anti-tumor immune cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Proper localization of viral components in cells is critical for efficient production of virus particles and spread from infected to uninfected cells. The goal of the proposed research is to elucidate the mechanisms that direct Gag, a structural protein of HIV-1 that causes AIDS, to the proper sites within virus-expressing cells. Knowledge obtained from proposed studies will help us develop novel antiviral strategies that may either directly suppress assembly and release of HIV-1 particles or inhibit spread of this virus to uninfected host cell

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The Paramyxoviridae family includes several pathogenic viruses that pose major threats to human health, including human parainfluenza virus 3 (HPIV3) which causes illness or death in millions of infants and young children, and the lethal Nipah (NiV) and Hendra (HeV) viruses that pose a risk of global emergence. We propose to apply the results of our fundamental research to advance a potent new antiviral strategy that is based on the use of fusion-inhibitory peptides to block viral entry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: We have discovered a new mitochondrial metabolic adaptation process, called secretory mitophagy, that is used by cancer cells to survive under stress of chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and molecular therapy. Under the Aims we will explore the molecular controls of this process in vitro, and in vivo, because it constitutes a new therapeutic target, and a clinically-relevant means to monitor the ongoing efficacy of cancer therapy. We will further investigate the tumor microenvironment response to cancer cell secretory mitophagy induced by increased oxidative stress.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Ovarian cancer is usually diagnosed at a late stage when survival is only about 10%, rendering this disease the deadliest gynecological malignancy. Disease recurrence is the major cause of mortality and despite a greater understanding of ovarian cancer biology there have been no significant improvements in mortality rates in the last five decades. Investigation of tumor cells that are resistant to chemotherapy and have the capacity to regenerate tumors is crucial for achieving cures for ovarian cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – NO CHANGES FROM PARENT GRANT Rigorous experiments from our lab and others have shown that human gut bacteria can metabolize numerous anticancer drugs; however, the major bacterial species that influence drug metabolism in patients, the genes and enzymes responsible, and the consequences for drug pharmaco-kinetics and -dynamics (PKPD) remain unknown. Here, we propose a series of in vitro and in vivo experiments to dissect the human gut bacterial species, genes, and enzymes responsible for the metabolism of the oral fluoropyrimidine capecitabine and their downstream consequences for drug PKPD in mice. Due to our focus on drugs used as current standard of care and naturally occurring bacterial species prevalent in the human gut microbiota, this preclinical research program is highly synergistic with ongoing clinical studies of cancer patients conducted by our team and the broader microbiome field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The coronavirus SARS-CoV2 emerged in late 2019, and caused a global pandemic resulting in over 3.5 million deaths worldwide. In the search for molecules that can be used to inhibit coronaviruses, the carbohydrate binding protein BOA was discovered to inhibit SARS-CoV2 infection at low nanomolar concentrations. The research proposed here is to understand the mechanism by which BOA inhibits SARS-CoV2 infection and demonstrate that BOA can inhibit emerging variants of concern as well as related beta-coronaviruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project narrative The supplement grant is to request the support for Mr. Emanuel Baltrip, a graduate student of African American, to pursue his Ph.D. training. In research aspect, he will work on his dissertation project, a part of the parent funded parent project (1R01CA257842-01A1) on developing polymeric micelle delivery of paclitaxel and cyclopamine for the treatment of hepatocellular adenocarcinoma (HCC) in orthotopic mouse models. In mentoring and career development aspect, Mr. Baltrip will be trained in developing research skills in hypothesis development, experimental study planning and execution, critical data analysis, and verbal and written communication skills, as well as developing proposals, to acquire a comprehensive set of skills for becoming a conscientious and capable cancer researcher of the underrepresented ethnicity, to fulfill the unmet clinical need for improving the survival and quality of life of HCC patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative: The goal of this supplement is to characterize how sex and age pattern cellular and molecular differences in the macaque entorhinal cortex. To do so, we are generating single nucleus (sn)RNA-seq data from the entorhinal cortices of 135 macaques, including 77 females, spanning the natural lifespan of free-living macaques. Graduate student Kelsi Watkins will receive training in computational, statistical, and theoretical analysis of large-scale snRNA-seq data, directly supporting the parent grant's objectives to uncover factors influencing cellular variability and to understand the biology behind the female bias in Alzheimer's Disease diagnoses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Despite evidence of its clinical importance, family health history (FHH) is broadly under-utilized and under-appreciated, due in large part on patients’ ability and willingness to discuss FHH. This proposal aims to explore patients’ culture, age and gender, and other factors that likely impact FHH knowledge and sharing. These data will inform revisions to the FHH tool and development of educational resources to promote more complete data collection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Heart Failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) affects millions of people and weakness of the diaphragm muscle that is used to breathe. Diaphragm weakness, caused by muscle atrophy and contractile dysfunction, impaired metabolism, and exercise intolerance are significant problems in patients because it contributes to morbidity and mortality. Our goal is to gain a deeper understanding of mechanisms and identify targets for prevention and treatment of diaphragm weakness in HFrEF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Exposure therapy is the most effective treatment available for obsessive compulsive disorder, yet up to 50% of patients fail to recover because we do not understand the mechanisms underlying successful response, leading to significant variability in how clinicians conduct exposure therapy. Using machine learning to analyze patient data from real-world treatment, the current study will determine which exposure mechanisms lead to favorable clinical outcomes and what makes a good exposure for whom. Results of this study have the potential to improve personalized care for the many patients who do not remit following exposure therapy for OCD.

PHR: Project Narrative Integral to all aims of the parent grant (from here on, Human Mammalian Brain Atlas, or HMBA) is a hospice/palliative care brain donor program which will collect functional imaging data from participants antemortem to integrate with the whole brain atlas generated postmortem. Disparities in access to palliative and hospice care have the potential to disrupt HMBA's ability to meaningfully include and positively impact people from minoritized groups. This supplement will support post-baccalaureate researcher Zoë Hale as she designs a qualitative interview study to collect the perspectives of hospice and palliative care workers serving underrepresented minority groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Contact PD/PI: KIEHL, KENT A Project Narrative Forensic populations have a rate of traumatic brain injury many times higher than the general population. The parent R01 conducts follow-up exams with N=300 male and female offenders with varying history of brain injury. The R01 tests the ability of machine learning algorithms to predict brain injury and cognitive decline from multimodal neuroimaging data. This raises complex bioethical questions. Here we conduct bioethical inquiry and stakeholder analysis in vulnerable forensic populations regarding the complex issues surrounding Artificial Intelligence/Machine Learning diagnostics for TBI and use of advanced techniques for treatment of TBI in forensic populations.
