IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Debilitating pain, a hallmark of tissue injury and neuropathy, is an unmet clinical challenge in heterotopic ossification (HO) that occurs following orthopedic surgery and traumatic injuries. With an aim at developing new strategies to manage injury-induced chronic pain and pathological HO, we will use novel preclinical models to elucidate the mechanisms downstream of active sensory neuron-specific ACVR1, mechanisms that may be shared by other chronic pain and musculoskeletal injury conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Individuals with cystic fibrosis (CF) have chronic respiratory infections. Oral diseases like tooth decay and gingivitis are potential sources of pathogenic bacteria that could spread from the mouth to the lungs, further compromising respiratory health. The proposed study will identify risk factors for oral diseases in adolescents and young adults with CF, evaluate associations between oral diseases and measures of respiratory health, and explore microbiologic links between oral and respiratory health using cutting-edge microbiome methods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: In response to the call for research on bioethical issues to guide health-related, behavioral science research (NOT-OD-24-031), this proposed administrative supplement will focus on the processes necessary to co- create multi-level interventions for students with disabilities (SWD) to address the nexus of sexual violence (SV) exposure and heavy drinking. Particularly challenging for research and intervention development is the continued ‘invisibility’ of disabilities, the stigma associated with disabilities, intersections with other forms of marginalization such as racism, homophobia, and transphobia, and limited patient and community engagement in alcohol research. Thus, the bioethical issues to be addressed in this proposal are: 1) development of a shared framework for conducting research with college SWD designed with SWD and other constituents, and 2) identifying accessible human-centered design strategies to ensure full inclusion of SWD in co-creating prevention interventions that increase protective factors and reduce exposure to violence and alcohol misuse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Continued opioid abuse and HIV infection contribute to exacerbated neuroinflammation and neurocognitive impairments. The proposed project aims to define molecular mechanisms of opiate and HIV-induced NLRP1 inflammasome activation in iPSC-derived primary human microglia. These in vitro model systems will be leveraged to identify host pathways to prevent microgliosis and the resulting neuroinflammation, which are critical to preventing the neuropathogenesis of in HIV+ OUD+ patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Comparative genomics and genetic engineering in model organisms are powerful tools that can be used to understand the biology underlying human traits, diversity and disease. We will study how essential proteins can evolve given the constraints imposed by the often multifaceted functions they perform, including for example, the important drug-target Na+,K+-ATPase, which has repeatedly evolved insensitivity to steroid inhibitors across diverse animals. Our work will yield insights into how new proteins associated with neurological and physiological disorders in humans, like Na+,K+-ATPase, can evolve new functions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to develop a multi-faceted therapeutic strategy to reduce ischemia reperfusion injury related damage to the endothelium of transplanted kidneys. We propose that polymeric vehicles specifically tailored for endothelial cells will be able to efficiently deliver and sustain the release of siRNA to prevent these injury outcomes by temporarily silencing the key molecules in each case that propagate inflammation outside of the cell. This modular approach will allow us to address the two key sources of injury to endothelium and substantially reduce the impact of IRI for kidney transplant.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative Several recent high-profile multi-state foodborne illness outbreaks highlighted the need for federal, state, and local food safety agencies to work together to prevent and respond to threats to the nation’s food supply. The Rapid Response Team program is a critical tool for promoting interoperability, consistency, and cooperation between federal and state agencies responsible for protecting the nation’s food supply and public health. The outcome of awarding this cooperative agreement to Wisconsin will advance efforts for a nationally integrated food safety system in Wisconsin.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Maintenance of Human and Animal Food Rapid Response Team - Wisconsin

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Living kidney donation, where someone donates one kidney while alive to someone whose own kidneys don’t function, provides the best outcomes for kidney patients needing renal replacement therapy. The growing prevalence of obesity in society reduces the numbers of potential living donors, since motivated individuals who have a high body mass index (BMI) are eliminated from being medically screened as donors and are not offered any support to help them lose weight. There is an urgent need to address issues of fairness in screening, comprehension of risks and benefits for both potential donors and recipients if a potential donor lost weight, and, if indicated, access to weight loss education and support programs. By interviewing excluded obese potential living donors about their views, experiences, and education and weight loss needs, this project will produce empirically informed recommendations and draft tools that support ethical and equitable decisions about living donation in situations when potential donors are obese.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This MIRA project will use theoretical methods, closely coupled with experimental data, to elucidate the basic factors that control the movement of electrons and protons in biological systems, providing fundamental insights into a wide range of biochemical processes essential to living systems. In particular, this project will enhance understanding of the radical translocation mechanism of ribonucleotide reductase, which plays a critical role in DNA synthesis, replication, and repair. The general insights about controlling electrons and protons provided by this work may also have broader implications for protein engineering, drug design, and optogenetics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HPV incidence rates are high among traditional college-aged adults (i.e., young adults aged 18-26 years) – a population that continues to display alarmingly low rates of HPV vaccination (i.e., <60% of all U.S. college students have received the first dose of the vaccine). We expect this diversity supplement project will: (1) identify factors associated with interpersonal barriers to HPV vaccination, specifically perceived HPV vaccine disapproval from friends and family; (2) provide important insights into how perceived HPV vaccine disapproval from important others impacts the HPV vaccine decision-making process; and (3) highlight the ability of the parent grant’s multilevel narrative-based intervention to decrease perceived HPV vaccine disapproval from important others and, consequently, increase HPV vaccine uptake among college students. It is expected that this diversity supplement project will have a significant impact on future intervention implementation approaches that address the most influential interpersonal relationships (e.g., parents and friends) to increase HPV vaccination uptake among young adults, specifically college students.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Barriers to using evidence-based nonpharmacologic pain treatments are especially prevalent for Black patients—who are offered fewer pain treatment options than White patients—and for patients with depression, since depressive symptoms can interfere with pain management. EQUIPD (Equity Using Interventions for Pain and Depression) is a novel intervention using a decision aid focused on nonpharmacologic treatments, combined with tailored individual coaching, to help Black patients with depression increase their use of these treatments to improve pain outcomes. Project results have important implications for improving equity in pain care for Black patients with depression by increasing use of safe, effective pain treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Borderline personality disorder (BPD) is a serious mental illness associated with comorbidity across internalizing and externalizing pathology as well as high personal and societal cost. This study will use a high-risk design to assess problematic interpersonal behavior exhibited by children with their friends to determine whether it reflects a precursor to BPD or other internalizing and externalizing problems. Results will provide critical information about hypothesized disease trajectory for BPD, which will inform targets for prevention and early intervention.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The National Environmental Health Association (NEHA) project entitled Using Technology, Data, and Collaboration to Expand SLTT Conformance with the Voluntary National Retail Food Regulatory Program Standards is intended to:   Work with FDA and project partners to develop, refine, and improve the grant  management system we developed to administer financial assistance to SLTT retail  regulatory food programs based on FDA's Retail Flexible Funding Model (RFFM) vision;   Maintain the Self-Assessment and Verification Audit Online Course we developed in  partnership with FDA and expand its use and value to SLTT jurisdictions;   Establish the NEHA-NACCHO Mentor Academy to recruit and train a new generation of  mentors, expanding our capacity to meet the increasing demand for expertise in the  Retail Program Standards; and   Work with CFP and FDA to host a biennial Retail Program Standards Symposium and  an annual Virtual RFFM Grant Year Kickoff Meeting, to engage current and attract new  enrollees in the Retail Program Standards. These four objectives will advance the Integrated Food Safety System (IFSS) requirements found in the Food Safety Modernization Act (FSMA) and support the goal of building New Business Models and Retail Standardization in the New Era of Smarter Food Safety.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Using Technology, Data, and Collaboration to Expand SLTT Conformance With the Voluntary National Retail Food Regulatory Program Standards

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE SRD5A2 is a critical enzyme for prostatic development and growth, and the SRD5A2 inhibitor, finasteride, is used to treat benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). SRD5A2 is absent in 30% of normal adult men, which explains the resistance of a subset of patients to this commonly prescribed drug. This project proposes new combination therapies (5-ARI+raloxifene) and evaluates novel non-invasive biomarkers, based on alternative pathways that lead to prostatic enlargement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Acute myeloid leukemia (AML), a hematological malignancy, remains stubbornly difficult to treat in both children and adults, with fewer than 30% of patients surviving five years after diagnosis. This project tests a novel treatment target (mitochondrial recycling—aka mitophagy) and novel small molecules identified using cheminformatics, in AML cell lines and primary cells. This project will facilitate the identification and characterization of promising leads for the development of future therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Correlations in neural dynamics across the brains of interacting individuals are an emergent and highly conserved property of social interactions, but the functional relevance of these correlations remains enigmatic. In this proposal we will use a comparative multi-species approach, combining state-of-the-art wireless technological advances and cellular/subcellular resolution imaging with pioneering molecular-genetic tools to decipher the biological mechanisms that enable neural synchrony and unequivocally define its function. By moving beyond a correlative understanding of this intriguing emergent neural property, we will determine its role in successful social interaction and attachment, a finding with transformative implications for the manipulation of these dynamics in a therapeutic context.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of HIV cure research is to eliminate persistent virus (“the HIV reservoir”) to overcome the need for lifelong antiretroviral therapy (ART) and improve clinical outcomes in people with HIV (PWH), but a challenge in achieving worldwide HIV eradication is targeting specific vulnerable populations who are most likely to benefit from an HIV cure and possess poorer immune responses due to chronic inflammation and ongoing HIV reservoir activation. Our preliminary data suggests that PWH with methamphetamine (MA) dependence disorder, even with adequate ART suppression, have elevated inflammation and HIV reservoir transcription. The proposed work will now leverage a unique longitudinal cohort of PWH on ART with and without MA use to determine the underlying mechanisms by which MA may lead to immune dysfunction, focusing on the NOD-like receptor family pyrin domain containing 3 (NRLP3) inflammasome activation pathway.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While it is now accepted that cell-to-cell variability affects viral infection outcome, we currently lack mechanistic understanding as to the host factors and transcriptional programs that control it. To gain such mechanistic insights requires the development of new approaches that are able to connect the cell’s initial state with infection outcome. This project will develop and apply state-of-the-art single cell approaches to decipher the molecular mechanisms that control viral infection outcomes at the single cell level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Viruses that are able to establish persistent or chronic infections have developed strategies to suppress immune mechanisms that would normally eradicate the virus. Regulating inflammation in the face of persistent infection is also critical as many of the long-term problems of chronic infection are due to persistent inflammation, including increased risk of developing cancer. Our new data have uncovered an unexpected role for IL-17 in helping to limit T cell activation and inflammation as persistent infection becomes established, and here we propose to explore the sources and functions of IL-17 in immunoregulation of antiviral response.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Synthetic oligonucleotide therapeutics are a promising class of biopharmaceuticals to treat various diseases which to date have been undruggable by small molecules or protein therapeutics. This project will develop new and innovative methods to determine the extent, range, and biological activity of phosphorothioate diastereomers for synthetic oligonucleotides. The developed methods will greatly improve the efficiency of developing new synthetic oligonucleotide drugs and enable the development of safe, effective, and affordable generic products.

PROJECT_TITLE: Comprehensive assessment of the diastereomer composition of LEQVIO (Inclisiran) to determine how chemical synthesis impacts biological activity

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Herein, we investigate how nanotube between prostate cancer cells and immune cells alter the effect of immunotherapeutic drugs. We utilize human and mice cell lines above human tissue to test the presence of nanotubes, while applying a novel class of inhibitors called endosidins to synergize with present immune check point inhibitors. The expected results of this study will avail a mechanism to explain poor immunogenicity in prostate cancers while availing new targets for therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project seeks to examine whether innovative local tobacco control policies restricting sales of flavored tobacco products can reduce tobacco use and disparities in tobacco and, ultimately cancer. The study will examine trajectories of flavored tobacco use in a large longitudinal national cohort of youth and young adults among those exposed and not exposed to policy. It will also examine youth and young adult non-tobacco user exposure to tobacco marketing and subsequent tobacco use outcomes in real-time in eight communities with different flavor policy variants and will have a particular focus on assessing differences in policy impact across vulnerable group status.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Signals communicating the need to maintain balanced blood production and aged blood cell removal must be correctly conveyed to the marrow's hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells and covey proper blood cell removal signals. These molecular mechanisms are intensely studied to provide new insight into the potential for novel therapeutic approaches in blood disorders, specifically affecting platelet and red blood cell counts. The proposed work will yield a transformative understanding of how liver-produced factors contribute to maintaining red blood cell production in the bone marrow at a steady state and provide new insight into novel therapeutic approaches for patients with blood disorders.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The overall goal of this proposal is to identify the influence of healthcare coordination on the association between autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and parent health and stress using a more robust, comprehensive assessment of ASD severity that includes co-occurring conditions, ASD complexity. Further, the role of healthcare coordination will be evaluated in the context of geographic and sociodemographic factors to identify disparities in healthcare access among marginalized and underserved populations. Our central hypothesis is that the degree to which care coordination affects the relationship between ASD complexity and parent outcomes will vary according to sociodemographic factors (i.e., race/ethnicity, rural/urban areas, HPSAs).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Septic shock is the most severe manifestation of sepsis and has a mortality rate above 40%. Unfortunately, existing sepsis research is limited by poorly understood variation and heterogeneity within septic shock patient populations. This study innovatively combines electronic health record and genetic data to improve the care of critically ill Emergency Department patients with septic shock, and addresses disparities in racial representation present in prior research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Prenatal alcohol and anxiety: an ontogenetic role for CRF Prenatal exposure to alcohol differential affects anxiety across the lifespan and increases ethanol consumption, yet the neurobiological underpinnings are not well understood. The corticotropin- releasing factor (CRF) system is heavily involved in regulating anxiety and ethanol intake through its actions in the medial central amygdala (CeM) and is disrupted by prenatal exposure to alcohol. This proposal will examine prenatal alcohol-induced adaptations in the CRF system within the CeM across ontogeny to determine how dynamic changes in this system contribute to fluctuations in anxiety-like behaviors and ethanol intake.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Our proposal for Improving Recruitment, Engagement, and Access for Community Health Equity for BRAIN Next- Generation Human Neuroimaging Research and Beyond (REACH for BRAIN) will utilize community engagement with Black and Latinx stakeholder networks, to co-create evidence-based solutions and ethical guidance to expand the inclusiveness of participation in NIH BRAIN research and human neuroimaging studies more broadly. Utilizing a stakeholder network, Outcome Map, and Theory of Change (ToC) already established in pilot work, and initially targeting recruitment for research with the BRAIN Initiative supported Connectome 2.0 project, community members, neuroscientists, and neuroethics experts will co-develop and implement a targeted, community-led and participant-centered deliverables to increase the participation of underrepresented and minoritized groups in neuroimaging research. Given the fraught history of scientific racism and biological essentialism in brain science, Aim 1 efforts to create appropriately diverse participation in neuroimaging will be accompanied by the Aim 2’s creation of Working Group consensus guidance and applied tools to guide neuroimaging researchers on how to measure and report on participants’ sociodemographic identifiers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many anticancer drugs have adverse effects on the heart and vascular system, making cancer survivors vulnerable to cardiovascular decline. By studying drug-induced changes in gene expression in cardiac organoids, I will identify specific cell types, genes, and alleles that are important for cardiotoxicity risk. Identification of risk factors and biomarkers may ultimately allow clinicians to provide cancer patients with safer and more effective treatment options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): Optimizing the dose of epilepsy medication to suppress seizures and minimize side effects can be an ongoing struggle. Although knowing the drug's level in the body would be expected to help guide dosing, laboratory measurement of drug levels in blood is inconvenient and slow. We propose to create and validate a device that could be used by a patient to measure (using chemical sensing and Al) the drug level in their saliva in order to rapidly find their optimal dosing plan and improve their quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Cancer is a frequent diagnosis in the emergency department (ED); ED cancer diagnoses are more common among racial minorities and low-income patients and result in poor outcomes, including lower survival. Evidence about emergency diagnosis of lung cancer in the United States (U.S.), and how to prevent it from occurring, is limited. This supplement will generate much needed evidence about emergency diagnosis of lung cancer, focusing on associations and outcomes among patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and predictors of survival to help identify modifiable drivers of disparities in patients with the poorest prognoses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Excessive alcohol use contributes to a wide range of negative health outcomes, including accidents, violence, alcohol dependence, and cardiovascular disease. Existing interventions to reduce alcohol use may not be appropriate for TNB people, both due to inapplicable and potentially unacceptable content (e.g., gender- specific drinking guidelines) and because they do not address anti-TNB stigma as a key determinant of alcohol use in this population. Relationship-focused interventions have the potential to jointly address alcohol use and co-occurring depression/anxiety symptoms in TNB people by reducing adverse relationship experiences (e.g., intimate partner violence) that result from stigma—and leveraging supportive romantic relationships as a buffer against the effects of stigma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE Randomized controlled trials demonstrated a reduction in lung cancer mortality with annual lung cancer screening with low dose computed tomography, yet real-world populations eligible for and undergoing lung cancer screening differ substantially from trial populations. By leveraging data from a randomized controlled trial and multiple real-world data sources, the proposed study will evaluate the benefits and harms of lung cancer screening in clinical practice settings with a focus on optimizing internal and external validity by applying novel causal inference methodologies. The proposed research is consistent with the Cancer Moonshot Initiative of the National Cancer Institute, which issued a call to action on cancer screening and early detection in February 2022.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Darwinian evolution drives the emergence of resistance to targeted therapy in cancer. We propose to use results from our in vitro evolutionary game assay to parameterize a computer model to allow us to predict 3-dimensional dynamics on clinically relevant timescales. Further, we will extend our assay to function in vivo, allowing the community to test mathematically derived evolutionary therapy hypotheses in preclinical models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescent females detained or on probation in juvenile justice settings present with a unique health risk profile, including elevated risk of unplanned pregnancy, substance use, HIV/STI infection, and the overlapping risk of substance-exposed pregnancy. This study will test the efficacy of a targeted bundled prevention intervention for this vulnerable population, many of whom are ethnic minorities disproportionately at risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cerebral edema is the deadliest consequence of traumatic brain injury (TBI), but current therapeutic interventions are only modestly successful – likely because our understanding of the basic mechanisms underlying edema remain incomplete. If successful, our results could prompt a reassessment of how we treat TBI related edema, with a focus on treating excitability as well as swelling after the event. Moreover, our studies will provide the basis for rational approaches for targeted treatments during the critical hours and days following TBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – OVERALL The Universities, Hospitals and Community Organizations in Rhode Island are well positioned to bridge the gaps between the worlds of clinical and basic science. Using the targeted resources of an IDeA-CTR Award, the Brown Institute for Translational Sciences, and a statewide consortium of collaborators, hospitals, universities, non-profit organizations and government agencies, will draw on the resources already developed in the NIH Institutional Development Award (IDeA) programs (core labs and faculty development programs) to enhance the Advance Clinical and Translational Research Program’s (Advance-CTR) ability to support clinical and translational research. We will serve as a bench-to-bedside research network and career development umbrella for the investigator community in affiliated institutions. In so doing, we will enhance patient-centered research and accelerate discoveries and health innovations to benefit our communities and to serve our State.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will investigate how the brain uses rules to guide our behavior. Rules define how we should act in a given situation and so disrupting one’s ability to learn and follow rules carries significant social and economic costs for many neuropsychiatric and neurodegenerative diseases, including schizophrenia. Our work will provide insight into the neural mechanisms of rule-based behavior, providing the foundation for a better understanding of these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Allergic disorders including food allergy, hay fever, eczema, and asthma, affect approximately 25% of people in industrialized countries and can cause life threatening reactions. Genetic differences among individuals account for about half of the risk of allergy; identifying the underlaying genes and biological pathways could suggest new strategies to treat and prevent allergy. Whereas the genetics of allergy has largely been studied in cell lines, we will pioneer an approach to study allergy at the single cell level in heterogenous human pathology specimens encompassing diverse clinical subtypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Much has been learned about neural circuitry and function; however, we still lack a fundamental understanding of how neural activity drives complex behavior and how naturalistic environments influence long-term neural activity. To address this, we will design, implement, and share an innovative neuro-behavioral recording and real-time processing platform that integrates complex behavioral measures with months-long, uninterrupted, wireless neural imaging across a colony of animals living uninterrupted in large, naturalistic environments. Collected data will span learning, recall, sleep, social behavior, and aging and will be shared openly and in real-time through a novel collaborative data sharing framework.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative: Shifting Suicide Prevention Paradigms: Looking Beyond Clinical Settings The goal of this research is to shift the paradigm of suicide prevention research by prioritizing social determinants through broad, but strategic, partnerships with industries outside of mental health care. By transforming psychological autopsy methodology into social autopsy and surveying and interviewing individuals who work in industries dealing with the depths of life disruption (i.e., family law, mortgage foreclosure, and unemployment processing), this project challenges the status quo of suicide prevention research that is anchored in clinical environments. This unconventional path through non-mental health industries is the chance to bring new perspectives and novel ideas for better, richer, novel data to inform suicide prevention strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Crucial to the wiring of neural circuits is the expression of sufficient Protocadherin (Pcdh) protein isoform diversity such that essentially every neuron in the brain is uniquely barcoded at its surface and therefore capable to self-recognize and self-avoid. This proposal aims to develop novel genomic, genetic and biochemical approaches to test a new model of Pcdh RNA splicing mechanism. The findings from this work will provide general principles of gene expression regulation of Pcdh genes and more broadly in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Temporal processing is central to cognition and behavior, and it has been hypothesized that memory deficits in Alzheimer’s disease and Schizophrenia result from disrupted temporal coordination and temporal processing within the brain. However, the neural mechanisms that underlie the brain’s ability to encode time remain largely unknown. This proposal will address the question of how the brain perceives and stores memories of temporal duration on the scales of seconds and minutes by leveraging cutting-edge optical imaging techniques in order to monitor and manipulate neural activity as mice engage in virtual-reality based timing behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: We work at the intersection of neuroscience and epigenetics which explores how our experiences and environment changes transcription of our genes. We seek to uncover the transcriptional signature encoding a memory within a neuron and how this is influenced by epigenetic mechanisms. Through this work, we hope to understand how the world around us influences gene regulation in the brain to allow us to learn, adapt, and become the people we are today.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative A large number of gene mutations that are associated with disease risk have been identified for diverse diseases. Hypotheses about how these mutations confer disease risk and their effects on cells and tissues are needed in order to prioritize therapeutic targets for intervention. This study proposes computational frameworks for identifying gene mutations that affect cellular behaviors of individual human cells, therefore enabling prioritization of therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The major challenge in understanding how the brain functions is the lack of knowledge and tools in tackling neuron-glial interactions. The project aims to develop a method to profile critical molecules that mediate neuron- glial communications in vivo with the spatiotemporal precision. We will apply this method in oligodendrocytes and axons to understand the molecular mechanisms governing axon ensheathment and myelination selectivity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Airway protective disorders are a prevalent and progressive consequence of Parkinson’s Disease (PD), and often result in aspiration pneumonia which is the leading cause of death in PD, yet many patients with PD do not access specialized services to address these critical deficits, especially individuals from historically marginalized groups. As an administrative supplement to our parent award R01 NS126319-01, we will utilize an embedded mixed methods design, in which we will use qualitative data to (1) understand how participants experience EMST and CST treatment both in-person and via telehealth and (2) explain quantitative treatment outcomes. In alignment with NIH, NINDS, and HERN priorities, the goal of this work is to improve person- centered, accessible, and equitable care to improve the health and well-being of persons with Parkinson’s disease – an area of public health need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The tectorial membrane plays an important role in the inner ear by stimulating hair cells in order to transduce sound. We have recently discovered a mutation in TECTB, which encodes an important organizing protein in the tectorial membrane which causes hearing loss in humans. We propose to investigate the effects of this mutation on the tectorial membrane through a mouse model to better understand its pathology and potential treatments, as well as supplement critical data towards establishing TECTB as a human deafness gene.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We utilize an innovative multimodal neuroimaging approach to better understand how sleep disturbances and brain networks that regulate emotion may underlie the clinically distressing and economically relevant problem of neuropsychiatric symptoms in those with mild cognitive impairment and Alzheimer’s dementia. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (from Parent Grant) Calcium signaling helps maintain normal cellular functions, but pathogens, including intestinal viruses like rotavirus, reprogram normal cellular calcium pathways to commandeer cellular machinery for their replication, which results in potentially life-threatening diseases like diarrhea. We recently discovered that rotavirus infection triggers long-distance signaling that also increases calcium in surrounding uninfected cells in the gut. This proposal investigates how this long-distance calcium signal is involved in host responses to rotavirus-induced damage but also exploited by rotavirus to increase its replication and spread.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE – Overall The UCLA Brain Cancer SPORE will support research into new and innovative strategies to diagnose and treat brain cancer, particularly focusing on innovative ways to overcome the problem of treatment-induced resistance to current therapies (i.e., immunotherapy, chemo/drug therapy, and radiation therapy resistance). Despite many different treatment approaches, the five-year survival rate for glioblastoma (WHO grade IV) patients remains dismal, and there are still no definitive cures for this disease. Thus, the proposed research is of relevance to public health, as there is clearly an unmet need for patients with this type of cancer and continued investigations into novel therapeutic approaches for brain cancer are desperately needed.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: The proposed research will develop a principled, scalable, and reproducible approach for rigorous and timely evaluation of the safety and effectiveness of generic drug-device combinations compared to brand-name reference products using large longitudinal healthcare datasets. We will demonstrate this approach for generating multi-phase actionable real-world evidence in 2-3 use cases, including description of utilization patterns, evaluation of comparative effects, and systematic screening for unsuspected safety issues. This project will provide the Food and Drug Administration with a reusable framework and set of tools for generating real-world evidence to evaluate complex generic drugs in the post-marketing setting.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: The Safety of Switching Between Complex Branded and Generic Drugs: Developing a Semi-Automated Sequential Surveillance System Using Tree-Based Scan Statistics

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Epidemiological evidence shows that women represent a particularly vulnerable population in Substance Use Disorder, and preclinical studies have demonstrated a significant sex difference in reward processing and motivated behavior in female subjects. Acetylcholine released from cholinergic (ChAT) interneurons in the nucleus accumbens (NAc) acting through pentameric nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChRs), is a potent regulator of dopamine release underlying reward processing in the NAc. In this proposal I will determine both the subunits of nAChRs modulating sex differences in reward processing and behavior as well as the circuit and cell-type specific regulation of dopamine release within the local NAc circuit by ChAT interneuron modulation of nAChR activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative: AIDS-associated cryptococcosis continues to ravage communities impacted by high HIV transmission rates, causing 15% of AIDS-associated mortality. Our work investigates the molecular mechanisms by which C. neoformans, among the millions of species of fungi, is able to adapt to the host environment, coping with the stresses it encounters. We have identified pathways required for agility in stress adaptation, and will investigate how they promote stress adaptation, cooperate with other pathways, and how conserved these responses are across diverse clinical isolates from people with AIDS-associated cryptococcosis as well as environmental isolates from the same region.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Diversity Supplement on Funded Grant RF1 AG084134 “Biomarkers to Track Effective Interventions That Delay Dementia Onset In Participants of the "Risk Reduction for Alzheimer's Disease (rrAD)" Trial” Project Narrative: This proposed supplement aims to identify sex differences in immune dysregulation and inflammatory cytokines in subjects with cardiovascular risk factors (i.e hypertension and dyslipidemia) and at risk for Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) and determine if an effective lifestyle intervention will delay the development of dementia. Additionally, this project will help refine the fluid biomarkers and distinguish between males and females with high risk for ADRD, consequently improving diagnosis and drug development for Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE All cells must regulate genes in order to divide, differentiate and die. This proposal employs cutting-edge genomic techniques to better understand how single cells use MYC-network transcription factors to make these decisions in stem cell pluripotency. The results will inform our basic understanding of how cells divide and differentiate in mammalian development and ultimately help understand how these proteins can deregulate cellular growth during cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): Pennsylvania Asthma-COPD Syndromic Surveillance (PASS) meets the urgent public health needs of our citizens by building a nimble data analytic system capable of parsing out the emergent (i.e., air pollution-attributable) from the legacy (i.e., systemic built environment, access, and socioeconomic disparity) risks of lower respiratory infection, asthma, and COPD, referred to herein as chronic respiratory syndrome (CRS). We will clarify how Pennsylvania's recurrent air pollution episodes and erratic weather patterns contribute to 'outbreaks' of lower respiratory infections in children and asthma and COPD outbreaks in all age groups within specific geographic locations. Our system will meet the needs of Pennsylvania citizens and healthcare managers by detecting, warning, and anticipating air pollution-associated outbreaks of CRS exacerbation cases in emergency room visits and hospitalization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The metastasis of cancerous cells to distant and vital organs is responsible for approximately 90% of cancer mortalities, and it is clear that an important barrier to tumor progression and metastasis is the survival of cancer cells that are detached from the extracellular matrix (ECM). However, our understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying the survival of ECM-detached cancer cells remains rudimentary. This proposal seeks to examine how a novel pathway involving RIPK1 and the degradation of mitochondria can restrict breast cancer progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal aims to enhance the Hmong ethnic minority involvement in cancer preventative screenings. It seeks to boost awareness and knowledge regarding cancer prevention among Hmong communities in California, particularly those facing persistent poverty, while encouraging their participation in early detection screenings and assessing income intervention such as the earned income tax credit. This proposal for Diversity Supplement will allow Ms. April Vang, under supervision and mentored by Dr. Carvajal-Carmona, to investigate the association between key social needs and colorectal cancer screenings in the California Hmong population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Although pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) can alter the mRNA translation efficiency (mTE) of codons in response to severe nutrient-depleted environments to selectively synthesize proteins required for adaptation and tumorigenesis, we still do not understand the pathways that regulate this process in human cancers. This proposal aims to decipher the signaling cascades and mechanisms that regulate the mRNA translation efficiencies of Ser codons upon Ser-starvation, and to target these pathways during PDAC tumorigenesis. The findings from this work will have a profound impact on our fundamental understanding of the pathways and mechanisms that regulate the mTE of Ser codons, identify a therapeutic vulnerability in the adaptation to Ser-starvation in PDAC, and can greatly shift our perception of the effects of codon regulatory pathways in human health and disease.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Malignant phyllodes tumors are aggressive breast neoplasms, which have disproportionately high local recurrence and metastatic rates, and afflict very young women. With limited ability to predict outcomes and no known effective systemic therapy options, metastatic progression portends a truly dismal prognosis. This research will provide an improved ability to predict risk of recurrence and define clinically actionable opportunities for this rare, but frequently fatal, tumor.

PROJECT_TITLE: Defining Actionable Opportunities in Malignant Phyllodes via Genomic Profiling

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The project aims to understand how different types of immune cells transfer mitochondria to cancer cells through physical nanoscale tentacles called nanotubes, and whether blocking these tubes can improve cancer responses to immunotherapies. Here, I will develop 2D and 3D models to observe how these mitochondria transfers between cancer and immune cells alter cancer cell behaviors. The ultimate goal is to evaluate the efficacy and safety of the new drugs in the proposed bioengineered models, to make existing cancer immunotherapies more effective.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Suicide research has faltered in identifying short-term predictors of suicide risk and studies such as the parent study face unique challenges in the need to overrecruit from a population that faces unique adversities (e.g., suicidal crises, low resources, and housing instabilities). The proposed supplement seeks to leverage the research to identify suicide risk markers in this vulnerable population by (1) improving our power to detect effects, (2) improving suicide research by identifying how suicidologists can effectively manage risk, and (3) addressing early implementation considerations for how we can best provide suicide prevention and care to vulnerable populations. NIH’s mission will be served by the proposed supplement through improving the prediction of suicidal behaviors in high-risk populations, improving future suicide research, and informing prevention efforts, ultimately reducing suffering and mortality with substantial societal cost.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cancer therapies often fail because the target they inhibit is needed in normal cells. This problem manifests as toxicity in the clinic, and results in lowering the doses of the drug to levels that lose efficacy in the cancer. We have discovered a generalizable way to improve therapeutic index in cancer by taking advantage of dysregulated Iron (Fe2+) handling, a feature we find to be an early and prominent effect of RAS signaling in many malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE [parent project] State of the art methods for the early detection and monitoring of cancer are either invasive, time-consuming, expensive, or frequently inaccurate, which hinders the routine screening of at risk-patients to improve survival rates. Here, we propose a portable neural network enabled spectroscopy platform to diagnose cancer in patient biofluids (saliva, blood plasma, and sweat). The expected outcome is to deliver a novel point of care liquid biopsy platform to better classify, monitor, and improve diagnostic sensitivity of a broad range of diseases and conditions, with focus on early/late-stage head and neck cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The ubiquitin E3 ligase, UBR5 is one of the most commonly mutated genes (~18%) in mantle cell lymphoma (MCL) with the majority of mutations identified in UBR5 were frame shift mutations found within the HECT domain. Here we will study the molecular function of ubiquitin E3 ligase, UBR5 mutations in lymphomagensis. Deciphering the role of the UBR5 and pathways dysregulated by mutations in mantle cell lymphoma will provide clues to lymphoma transformation with the goal of identifying targets for future therapeutics.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Many VA patients receive long-term opioid therapy (LTOT). LTOT may be harmful, and so physicians are supposed to frequently monitor LTOT patients. However, many LTOT patients are not frequently monitored, and many are having LTOT discontinued, even though discontinuation may also be harmful. Because of potential harms of LTOT, difficulties of frequent monitoring, and potential harms of having LTOT discontinued, physicians need practical tools and guidelines to improve care. This project will improve patient care by developing integrated screening tools to indicate if LTOT is harmful to continue (yes or no), and if tapering to discontinue opioids is harmful to initiate (yes or no). When the tool indicates “yes,” this will mean that physicians should start additional, more comprehensive monitoring and examination to determine the harms and benefits of continued LTOT or of tapering to discontinuation. This project will also identify preliminary treatment approaches for an at-risk subgroup of LTOT patients: those who screen “yes” on both tools.

PHR: We will refine a cognitive-behavioral therapy for loneliness and substance use disorder (CBT-L/SUD) then assess its feasibility and acceptability first through a small single-arm trial, then a small randomized clinical trial. IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurological injuries and diseases negatively affect quality of life for millions of people in the US, such as the various visual and oculomotor pathologies (e.g. optic ataxia and oculomotor apraxia) caused by damage to the posterior parietal cortex (PPC). Despite extensive research, much remains unknown about how PPC encodes motor decisions, in part due to technical limitations of existing neural recording technologies. This project aims to increases our understanding of the neuronal circuits involved in these visual-motor pathologies by using a novel neuroimaging technique (functional ultrasound neuroimaging) and conventional electrophysiology to investigate how and where motor and decision variables are represented from the single neuron level to detailed maps of neural populations across the entire PPC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: FDA guidelines stipulate that all new drugs be tested for dangerous side-effects on the heart as part of preclinical research; however, the current tests are poorly predictive of both dangerous and safe drugs leading to unwarranted attrition and dangerous drugs reaching clinic. Human cardiomyocytes derived from donor tissue (iPSC-derived cardiomyocytes) are widely considered to hold great promise for clinical trial in a dish studies of drug cardiotoxicity. This STTR proposal is to commercialize a high throughput platform to accurately identify drug candidates that have cardiac side effects, in particular adding the ability to detect the type of primary heart cell damage common with anti-cancer drugs in a fully automated (high throughput) robotic assay for the first time, to improve the efficiency of preclinical research and the safety of human clinical trials, which will also likely have the added benefit of reducing animal research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative There is no treatment to correct the reduced brain blood flow observed in Alzheimer disease patients, although this reduction likely contributes to cognitive deficits and may accelerate disease progression. We recently found that blood flow in individual brain capillaries is stalled by arrested white blood cells in mouse models of Alzheimer’s disease, and we now propose to investigate the molecular and cellular mechanisms causing these capillary stalls and to determine the impact of increasing brain blood flow by interfering with capillary stalling on the progression of disease. These capillary stalls are a potential mechanism for the decreased blood flow in AD, and this work could lead to novel therapies that improve cognitive function and slow Alzheimer’s disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Impaired artery function is a major risk factor for cardiovascular diseases in men and women who have undergone cancer treatment with Doxorubicin chemotherapy. In the proposed project, I will investigate the role of cellular senescence in regulating arterial dysfunction with Doxorubicin in preclinical mouse models and in humans by conducting a trial in Doxorubicin-treated cancer patients. Overall, the findings of this project have the potential to identify cellular senescence as a new therapeutic target for preventing/treating impaired artery function with Doxorubicin and thereby reducing risk of cardiovascular diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The work conducted under this proposal will provide further insight into the regulative role of senescent cells within microenvironments in vivo. Leveraging the tools already developed and acquiring new state of the art techniques, we will identify the SASP factors of p16INK4a+ lung fibroblasts at homeostasis and during acute alveolar injury. The knowledge gained through this study will provide clarity on the role SASP from p16INK4a+ plays in regulating epithelial alveolar regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Nearly half of patients do not recover following the first line of treatment for OCD, exposure and response prevention (ERP). This study proposes to test a novel method of augmenting ERP, a computerized, scalable intervention targeting interpretation bias, which is a critical mechanism underlying OCD. The overall goal is to contribute to the development of technology-driven augmentations to ERP to enhance response rates, which may generalize to treatment for other OC-related and anxiety disorders in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Obstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is a common cardiac disorder that in some people can lead to substantial limitations in acts of daily living, poor prognosis, and mortality. Gold standard therapy for patients who do not respond to medical management are invasive septal reduction surgeries that have a high rate of serious side-effects and mortality. This proposal will validate a new minimally invasive method to precisely treat the source of the obstruction in a procedure that we believe will be safer and better suited for many patients than the currently available treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Aphasia (acquired language impairment) is one of the most common consequences of stroke and often leads to significant long-term disability. Audiovisual recordings of individuals with aphasia can provide rich information and are valuable for research and clinical education, yet the sharing of identifiable audiovisual data raises ethical concerns regarding privacy, confidentiality, and consent. This study will explore the attitudes of individuals with aphasia and their care partners towards sharing identifiable audiovisual data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This supplemental proposal provides a timely response to an environmental accident and chemical exposure in East Palestine, Ohio by initiating community engagement participatory research, providing context with qualitative research approaches, and establishing a baseline biospecimen repository within the scope of the parent grant. Specifically, the supplement will add children to the registry of participants in the parent grant, collecting the same novel biomarkers and health information as the parent grant, including measures of behavioral functioning specific to children. The utility of novel biomarkers for chemical-wide exposures establishes a new paradigm for environmental exposure assessment and health changes. The community engagement establishes a cornerstone for continued and future research determining long-term health impacts, as well as establishing a two-way relationship between community members and health researchers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT  Ascending thoracic aortic aneurysm (ATAA) is a major cardiovascular health problem characterized by a dilated aorta that may eventually dissect or rupture (fail). An accurate assessment of ATAA failure risk is a major clinical need. This project will use experimental biomechanics, computer modeling, and real and virtual patient imaging data to better assess ATAA failure risk.

PHR: Project Narrative Membrane Associated RING CH (MARCH) family of proteins were recently found to restrict HIV-1 replication by blocking envelope incorporation in the budding virions in the producer cells. Nevertheless, many questions remain regarding the role of this family of proteins during HIV-1 infection. A better understanding of the antiretroviral mechanism of MARCH proteins and its effect on HIV-1 infection has the potential to be utilized for the development of new therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ColoCare Study is a cohort of recently diagnosed patients with colorectal cancer (stage I-IV) that utilizes standardized protocols for longitudinally collecting participant questionnaires, biospecimens, medical record data, and clinical and patient-reported outcomes. Over 3,000 demographically and geographically diverse participants have been recruited (with a median follow-up time of 2.1 years, contributing >8,000 questionnaires and >17,000 biospecimens), and ColoCare data and/or biospecimens have supported 79 projects involving 72 external investigators (19 projects led by external investigators and 49 from early stage investigators and trainees). In this renewal, we will extend follow-up through 5 years post-diagnosis; prioritize recruitment of patients from underserved/understudied populations and with early-onset colorectal cancer; continue repeat ascertainment of self-reported data (including patient-reported outcomes) and blood samples; and enhance our centralized data repository and biobank to support data sharing and research that will improve colorectal cancer treatment, survivorship, and clinical outcomes. Project Narrative Page 9

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Despite the significant improvement in survival for patients with colorectal cancer deficient in DNA mismatch repair using cancer immunotherapy, up to half of these patients do not derive durable clinical benefit from immunotherapy. The mechanisms associated with resistance to immunotherapy in dMMR colorectal cancer are not clearly defined. We will study factors that mediate resistance to immunotherapy in order to develop strategies to improve the clinical efficacy of immunotherapy for patients with cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Blood-based ADRD biomarkers show tremendous promise as a non-invasive method to predict and diagnose ADRD. In a community population of 21,000 older persons without dementia, we will measure changes in these biomarkers over 7 to 10 years, to determine whether their ability to predict ADRD differs by sex or by other characteristics, and develop a sex-specific ADRD risk score for personalized medicine and clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative - Mucins are heavily glycosylated proteins that have been known to play roles in inflammation and cancer with potential to be therapeutic targets for future treatments1. The proposed project will work towards the development of a new mucin-selective enrichment strategy for mass spectrometry analysis of the “mucinome” by utilizing a novel proximity labeling approach6. To do this, I will develop a StcE[E447D] mucinase conjugate, validate utilizing glycoproteomics, and finally, develop a library of inactive mucinases with photocatalyst conjugates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The advent of molecular imaging has prompted a paradigm shift in medical imaging as a whole, from its foundations in purely anatomical imaging towards techniques aimed at probing tissue phenotype and function. We have for many years exploited aberrant targets associated with cancer in order to better diagnose, stage and monitor this disease. In this R35, we plan to highlight three highly integrated areas within the context of our expertise and insights that will have a significant impact on cancer treatment outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We will integrate novel mouse models, organotypic cultures of human and mouse cells and state-of-the-art single cell profiling and spatial transcriptional data to address fundamental questions regarding the cell of origin of distinct classes of gastric cancer. In parallel, we will define key transcriptional mediators of the progression to gastric cancer and then perform experimental validation. Together these studies can integrate addressing longstanding debates over origins of gastric cancer while defining targets to prevent cancer initiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sexual minority men (SMM) experience intimate partner violence (IPV) at alarming rates and prior work has linked IPV with sexual risk-taking behavior and to increased risk for HIV seroconversion among SMM, but less is known about the impact of IPV on HIV testing, pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) uptake, and the persistence of PrEP use among SMM. The proposed innovative observational cohort study will examine how perpetration and/or receipt of various forms of IPV (e.g., physical, sexual, and psychological; in the context of steady or casual intimate relationships) contribute to HIV risk and protective behaviors among HIV-negative SMM over a 24-month timeframe. This research will advance our understanding of both the risk and resiliency factors relevant to preventing and reducing IPV, reducing HIV risk behaviors, and increasing HIV protective behaviors among SMM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: This study seeks to discover the reason patients with long COVID suffer from persistent chest pain symptoms. Using advanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), this study will determine: (a) whether MRI accurately and precisely detects blockage in small blood vessels supplying oxygen to the heart in long COVID patients; (b) whether the said blockage is the cause of persistent chest pain symptoms in long COVID patients; (c) whether the said blockage resolves better if patients undergo therapy. Our findings will inform future clinical trials aimed at preventing and/or reversing persistent chest pain caused by long COVID.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cadmium is a toxic metal that is a major public health concern, due to its ubiquity in the human environment. If successful, our work will show that exposure to cadmium during development causes non-alcoholic fatty liver disease in later life through activating a specific set of genes, identifying these genes as potential markers of disease susceptibility and novel targets for treatment. Given that NAFLD affects 30-40 % of the US adult population, and has been linked to metabolic impairments and a shorter lifespan, findings from our work have the potential to improve disease prediction and management for a large number of people.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative Six million Americans live with atrial fibrillation (AF), a heart rhythm abnormality that is a major risk factor for stroke, and only 60% of these AF patients take the recommended treatment, anticoagulation (AC). This problem is even worse for non-White patients who are at higher risk of stroke due to AF. The proposed Diversity Supplement will support an outstanding early-stage investigator to examine AC use in a diverse population of older adults while also providing mentoring and training opportunities to establish the candidate as an independent investigator.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative In this Supplement, Ms. Karam, an under-represented minority by the NIH-guidelines, will be supported on her career path to graduate school. Her project falls within our Parent R37 grant by examining the tumor- supportive roles of the fatty acid binding proteins (FABPs) in multiple myeloma. Her project will explore the effects of FABP inhibitors in a myeloma model using a more effective and clinically-relevant dosing route than we have used before, and her results will provide novel insight into the effects of FABP inhibitors on myeloma cells as well as the other immune cells within the bone marrow and surrounding the tumor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Social anxiety disorder (SAD) is one of the most prevalent mental disorders, affecting 12.1% of U.S. indi- viduals at some point in their lifetime, and is characterized by fear and avoidance of socially evaluative situations, often leading to devastating consequences for the affected individual and placing considerable economic burden on society at large. The proposed study is the ﬁrst (to our knowledge) to tackle speciﬁc ethical concerns for conducting research with mobile sensing devices in individuals high in social anxiety (a group likely to have heightened concerns about being monitored), considering aspects of both users' comfort and perceptions of leveraging digital health interventions with embedded sensing, as well as the preferred methods and content of informed consent to communicate about potential risks. The outcomes of this work will contribute to best research and clinical practices in the ﬁeld of digital mental health for socially anxious individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Many metastases of breast cancer may further disseminate to seed more metastases, but the pre-clinical models, the underlying mechanisms, and the potential therapeutic targets are all lacking. Herein, based on several lines of preliminary evidence, we propose to test the hypothesis that the bone microenvironment invigorates metastatic seeds for further dissemination. Specifically, we will focus on delineation of temporal course of metastatic seeding from bone to other organs, and identification of druggable pathways driving this process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Lymphedema is an incurable condition that affects over 5 million individuals in the US and is characterized by tissue swelling after lymphatic node injury or resection. There is no pharmacologic therapy that is currently approved to prevent post-surgical lymphedema. Our laboratory has shown that retinoic acid therapy mitigates lymphedema after surgical injury by promoting lymphangiogenesis in multiple pre-clinical models. The objective of this proposal is to increase our understanding of the mechanisms by which retinoic acids regulate lymphangiogenesis and develop a translational framework for the clinical use of these compounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Deleterious mutations of DNA damage repair (DDR) genes associated with increased prostate cancer risk and mortality. However, our knowledge of the complete implications of DDR aberrations other than BRCA2 in prostate cancer tissue is limited due to functional significance gaps. This proposal introduces a novel approach to uncover the critical role of non-BRCA2 DDR gene alterations in prostate cancer biology, aiming to enhance treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Radiation therapy delivered at ultra-high radiation dose rates, which are more than 100 times faster than traditional radiation therapy delivery methods, has been postulated to produce a FLASH effect of similar tumor responses but with less toxicity to healthy tissue. However, not all preclinical studies testing ultra-high dose rates have reported consistent FLASH effects and no optimization has yet been performed to maximize the normal tissue sparing after FLASH compared to conventional irradiation. Therefore, the proposed study will analyze the FLASH effect using different types of radiation modalities, optimize parameters for delivery, and more precisely measure tumor curability, enabling consistent translation of this method of radiation therapy delivery to the clinic.

Various extended formulation designs will be developed using variety of extended release polymers and manufacturing methods (Design: matrix system, coating design; Manufacturing method: direct and wet granulation, coating, hot-melt, 3D printing) and evaluated for quality attributes and alcohol-induced dose dumping.

Recognizing the impact of effective communication on overall health, healthcare literacy, treatment adherence, trust-building, and reducing disparities, the study seeks to provide clinicians with tools to facilitate discussions with minorities about cancer clinical trials, addressing a critical need in the current landscape of cancer care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Hundreds of thousands of genetic variations associated with complex diseases and traits have been uncovered within the past two decades, but remarkable gap persists between these discoveries and what is required to advance the clinical treatments and medicine. This application proposes to develop novel statistical methods to address computational and analytical challenges for combining high-dimensional molecular and cellular datasets for disease gene discovery. The methods and resources developed in this study will bridge the gap from genetic variations associated with disease risks to relevant biological processes and provide starting points for experimentalists and clinicians to translate the genetic findings into new preventative and therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Social stigma due to health conditions increases disease burden and adversely impacts health. The internalization of health-related stigma (i.e., self-stigma) is associated with impaired mental health and quality of life, yet little is known about how to reduce internalized stigma. The current project will test the effects of a novel, transdiagnostic, group counseling intervention, and of general peer support, to determine the optimal method for helping patients cope with health-related stigma, reducing its internalization, and, ultimately, enhancing patient quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Our team has developed an advanced, first-of-its-kind machine learning (ML) algorithm intended to provide prognostic information about severe brain tumors and advise decisions about neurosurgery. The capacity to obtain and make treatment decisions based on artificial intelligence-generated insights raises myriad ethical considerations and risk factors. This project will systematically collect original data via in-depth interviews with three relevant stakeholder groups (i.e., patients with brain tumors, caregivers of patients with brain tumors, neurosurgeons) to identify shared and unique needs, values, concerns, priorities, and perceived risks and benefits of using this technology both in research and clinical settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: We will conduct a mixed-methods study, employing a national online survey and in-depth qualitative interviews, of public and key stakeholder perspectives on investigators’ responsibilities to research participants and non- participants in community-based pragmatic clinical trials (PCTs). We will then undertake a normative ethical analysis, informed by our empirical findings and a thematic synthesis of the relevant literature, to develop an ethical framework for community-based PCT protocol design. We will translate this framework into practicable directives for investigators and research oversight entities for the ethical conduct of community based-PCTs, specifically addressing NHLBI research priorities of confronting bioethical issues relevant to novel trial design and investigations involving vulnerable populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer is ranked as the fourth leading cause of cancer-related death in the United States with 1 - and 5-year survival rates of 20% and 7%, respectively. It is known that in pancreatic cancer zinc storage and transport is dysregulated, and that the level of dysregulation follows malignant progression. This work proposes a non-invasive technique to detect early malignant transformations in pancreatic cancer using a MRI zinc sensor. This approach based on MR imaging of zinc content and secretion places this proposal in a unique position to revolutionize the diagnostic paradigm of pancreatic cancer in the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Parent RO1 CA268055 Cisplatin-based combination chemotherapy is the standard-of-care treatment for muscle invasive bladder cancer but 70% of patients do not respond. We discovered a novel mechanism by which puromycin-sensitive aminopeptidase, NPEPPS, is upregulated, and we have strong evidence supporting its interaction with volume- regulated anion channels (VRACs) to block import of cisplatin and other platins into cancer cells. The focus of this proposal is to characterize this novel mechanism and evaluate pharmacological inhibition of NPEPPS in combination with platin drugs in preclinical models with the objective of eventually improving patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative: This proposal seeks to develop a physiologically based pharmacokinetic model to predict in vivo drug release from long acting injectable suspensions, through an in depth understanding of critical formulation attributes and critical process parameters. This will facilitate the development of bioequivalence recommendations for generic long-acting injectable suspensions. As a consequence of the proposed research, the regulatory burden will be reduced, and clinical studies will be minimized without sacrificing product quality and safety while delivering cost-effective products to the public with minimal delay.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) is a leading cause of cancer death, but it lacks effective detection and treatment due to complicated pathogenesis mechanism. Our research aims to uncover how a crucial non- coding RNA is abnormal in its methylation in NSCLC and how this impacts the formation and phenotype of the cancer. This study will shed light on the pathological effects of de-regulated RNA modiﬁcation in NSCLC and establish a foundation for creating therapeutic molecular tools that can regulate gene expression through non- coding RNAs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Ceramides are products of fat and protein metabolism that accumulate in individuals with obesity or dyslipidemia and are strongly linked to insulin resistance. Herein we propose to leverage large-scale epidemiologic and clinical cohorts to identify associations of ceramides with colorectal cancer risk, and animal experiments to study the efficacy of new ceramide-lowering interventions. Our study will clarify the key role of ceramides in the metabolic dysregulation underlying colorectal cancer and identify new targets for colorectal cancer prevention. Project Narrative Page 7

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Multi-omic technologies enable high-throughput characterization of transcriptomic, metabolomic, lipidomic, epigenomic, and proteomic profiles, elucidating the complete chain of disease pathophysiology and offering the possibility of tremendous advances in our ability to diagnose, understand, and treat human disease. However, the ability of researchers, clinicians, and patients to reap the benefits of these investments in science and medicine will require the development of frameworks for clinical translation, including parameters for responsible return of individual research results from multi-omic data. The goal of this project is to create a preliminary map of the ethical, legal, scientific, and pragmatic challenges to return of multi-omic results with a focus on rare diseases, and to identify opportunities for the GREGoR Consortium to develop solutions to these challenges.

While most of the original funding supporting this effort has elapsed, it is recognized that there is a need for additional support for data and sample management including as needed to enable multiple high impact multi-omic IMPACC manuscripts currently in preparation. In this context, the Precision Vaccines Program (PVP) at Boston Children’s Hospital (BCH), operating via its Administrative Core and as the IMPACC Clinical Data Coordinating Center (CDCC), commits to providing additional comprehensive data coordination, quality control (QC), and quality assurance (QA), as well as robust digital infrastructure for the IMPACC project's data management and analysis needs. Parent Award PROJECT NARRATIVE Founded in 2010, the Human Immune Profiling Consortium (HIPC) has successfully brought together independent research centers to identify immune signatures associated with the outcomes of vaccinations and infections in humans. We propose to develop a HIPC Coordinating Center (HCC) that supports the HIPC network by providing a centralized Portal and Knowledgebase to facilitate data analysis and visualization, and to promote collaborations across the network by organizing subcommittees and cross-HIPC analysis projects.
