IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Caregivers of deaf/hard-of-hearing (DHH) may want to provide sign exposure to protect their child from linguistic deprivation but have to learn how to sign in order to do so. Adults have developed their embodied cognition skills – the ability to use stored sensory-motoric experiences during tasks – and may be able to capitalize on these skills when learning to sign, particularly for signs that directly access these stored representations. This proposal aims to assess the impact of motoric-iconicity–the structured mapping between a sign’s form (shape/movement) and its meaning–on embodied cognition in native signers and adult sign learners to determine if these signs can serve as a starting point for caregiver-centric interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project narrative We propose to build upon the STAR-OM study (R01 DA050486) to assess the feasibility and acceptability of behavioral treatment and challenges of medication treatment for people with primary methamphetamine use disorder and without opioid use disorder at methadone clinics in Hanoi, Vietnam. Expanding treatment options at methadone clinics to provide evidence-based interventions to people with primary methamphetamine use disorder would be a cost-effective strategy to increase treatment coverage for this population. The study will provide preliminary data for prospectively assessing effectiveness and implementation barriers of the interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rekovar is developing a low-cost wearable monitoring system that integrates wirelessly with a mobile device to allow real- time monitoring of the baby’s physical and physiological state and its ability to sleep, eat, and be nurtured while undergoing neonatal abstinence syndrome (NAS). This device has significant impact in helping reduce both hospital stay and costs as neonates receiving pharmacological treatment are usually in the NICU away from family and non- pharmacological care. Our interest lies with respect to proper neonatal care, where separate procedures occur for essential neonatal needs and needs for neonates undergoing withdrawal, and by using this monitoring device to assess addicted neonates undergoing withdrawal, caregivers are provided the better ability of treating the right neonatal needs with the appropriate procedure in hospitals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Progenitor cell states contributing to aging and lung cancer Narrative Aging is a primary risk factor for lung cancer, which accounts for the largest cause of cancer deaths. Cells in the lung alveoli are the source of the most common lung cancers and slowly become less functional as they age. We will use new models to investigate how molecular changes in alveolar cells contribute to cancer initiation during aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infantile rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS) is a newly identified and poorly understood aggressive pediatric muscle cancer that affects young children. There is one single mutation that causes the disease, but we do not have specialized treatments targeting this genetic event, and patients are treated with general strategies that are often ineffective or have harsh life-long side effects. We will leverage novel zebrafish and mouse cancer models to help young children with cancer by understanding the biology of how infantile RMS develops and implementing these models to identify clinically tractable therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Relevance As the proportion of older adults in the population continues to expand, magnifying the relative impact of their decisions, it is increasingly imperative to better understand changes in decision making across the life span before and throughout all stages of significant cognitive impairment related to Alzheimers Disease and related dementias. Increasing interdisciplinary research combining psychology, neuroscience/neurology, medicine, and economics has tremendous potential for increasing translation of science for real-world impact to better understand and alleviate the burden of Alzheimers Disease and related dementias. The long-term goal of this network is to conduct integrative and multidisciplinary research that contributes directly to interventions aimed at improving health and well being in the daily lives of aging adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In African Americans, prostate cancer is characterized by higher aggressiveness, more extensive metastases, early- onset, and increased mortality rates than those in Caucasian Americans. We hypothesize that the racial disparity in prostate cancer diagnosis can be reduced by using racially associated magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) analysis. The proposed MRI-based analysis model will be evaluated for men of different racial/ethnic characteristics at the University of California Los Angeles (UCLA) and the University of Alabama at Birmingham (UAB).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Malignant tissue removed during surgeries is frozen, sectioned into thin slices, stained, imaged with a microscope (2D images), and assessed by pathologists to provide intraoperative consultations. The frozen section procedure is lengthy, slows down surgeries, inflicts extra operating room cost, and is less accurate than permanent sections. Here, we will develop a product that quickly prepares the tissue and enables 3D visualization of the tissue, potentially saving time, money, and lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Differences in our individual genomes give rise to most of human diversity, including the severity of disease presentations and responses to therapeutic interventions. Yet, the component of genetic diversity has been largely ignored in preclinical studies, including in muscular dystrophies. This project aims to revolutionize the conventional method by which we develop genetic therapy in muscular dystrophy to reflect diverse patient populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Telephone-based cognition testing is cost-effective and lends itself more easily to a broader range of populations than in-person face-to-face testing. However, scores obtained from phone-based testing differ systematically from more traditional face-to-face testing, and comparability across modes of test administration is critical for interpreting scores in research studies. The primary objective of this administrative supplement to the SWAN Aging U19 aims is to conduct a cross-calibration study in a new sample of N=100 women, of similar age as SWAN V17 participants (age range, 66-76 years) to create test-score adjustment/correction formulas that incorporate differences by level of cognitive functioning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: In living things, proteins with a reduced diversity of their amino acid building blocks play an integral role in the organization of biochemical activity in time and space. These proteins are of fundamental importance to the understanding of human health as more than 30% of the proteins coded by human genome have this characteristic, many of which are genetically linked to disease. The proposed research will provide an understanding of fundamental microscopic protein chemistry underlying macroscopic biological activity that will be useful for improving treatments for neurodegenerative diseases and cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Severe early childhood dental caries (SECC) constitutes a significant economic burden, can have dramatic impact on a child's well being and may contribute to overall health later in life. Studies of clinical Streptococcus mutans strains are needed to investigate the diversity of novel small molecule metabolites produced by biosynthetic gene clusters and their impact on the pathogenesis of dental caries. Identification of novel metabolites from cariogenic S. mutans may lead to the development of new therapeutics that can effectively treat or even prevent SECC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Children with autism spectrum disorder who receive intervention earlier in life show larger gains in language skills and improved overall development; presymptomatic intervention during infancy may soon be feasible because recent research advances have lowered the age of possible detection to 6-months. The proposed study will inform future presymptomatic interventions by identifying infant-based language and communication risk markers, caregiver-based intervention targets, and brain-based monitoring biomarkers. The objectives of this proposal align with the NIDCD Strategic Plan Priority Areas in Voice, Speech, and Language Research by: 1) understanding diseases and disorders; 2) improving diagnosis, treatment, and prevention; and 3) improving outcomes for human communication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The incidence of invasive cervical cancer (ICC) is considerably higher in women living with HIV (WLWH) compared to women living without HIV. Toll-like receptors (TLR) agonists show promise for dysplasia therapy, but the relationship of TLR expression in WLWH with cervical cancer is unknown. Here we will evaluate TLR expression in WLWH and without HIV with cervical cancer, in a diverse population of African and African American women and test a novel TLR agonist formulation in animal models to determine how it affects immunity and progression of cervical cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This project will examine how experiences of microaggressions, a common and understudied form of racial discrimination, affect Black youth’s neurobiological vigilance circuitry, and subsequent PTSD symptoms several months after a traumatic assault. The results of the study will highlight both the immediate effect of experiencing microaggressions as well as the impact of cumulative experiences during the first year of recovery from a traumatic assault. Results may suggest a mechanism linking experiences of racial microaggressions to posttraumatic stress symptoms, and thus, inform a target for intervention that considers Black youth’s lived experiences with racial discrimination as they intersect with additional traumatic events.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative People living with HIV (PWH) at the age of 50 or older have a higher incidence of cancers and worse outcomes than those without HIV infection. To improve treatment and health of older PWH, we must better understand the molecular and cellular mechanisms by which HIV infection and aging facilitate cancer development among PWH. Our proposed interdisciplinary studies using immune cells from older PWH will help decipher how HIV-associated cancers and aging affect host gene expression and the innate immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Computational models suggest cognitive deficits in schizophrenia (SZ) may arise from the effects of cortical excitation:inhibition (E:I) balance disruptions in regions of the association cortex. These models have computational and statistical properties that make them difficult to translate to clinically relevant contexts. The proposed project uses a novel computational approach, Mesoscale Individualized Neurodynamic (MINDy) modeling, to translate computational models of E:I balance to large-scale neuroimaging datasets, genetically- informative research designs, and novel asessments of cognitive function in schizophrenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose a novel computational framework for clinical investigators to initiate clinical trial simulation studies using real world data (RWD). We propose a first-of-its-kind computational approach to represent the entirety of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) trials while considering the connection of RWD (Aim 1), to use both structured and unstructured RWD to develop robust phenotyping algorithms that will render previously incomputable AD study traits computable (Aim 2), and to develop a web application which will provide an integrated environment for AD researchers to construct virtual AD trials using an interactive web interface and obtain analytic-ready datasets for trial simulation studies (Aim 3).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Since 1979, the biennial Gordon Research Conference on Epithelial Differentiation and Keratinization (GRC- EDK) and its associated, trainee-run Gordon Research Seminar on Epithelial Differentiation and Keratinization (GRS-EDK) have served as a pivotal platform to showcase the latest conceptual and technological advances aimed at addressing fundamental questions in epithelial biology and to advance scientific discoveries into treatments for human disease. The 2025 GRC/GRS-EDK will focus on areas such as stem cells and homeostasis, epithelial tissue organization and niche signaling, immunology, epigenomics, cutting-edge technologies, and innovative therapeutic approaches. The 2025 GRC/GRS-EDK meetings aim to present breakthrough discoveries in these fields, encourage the free exchange of ideas, facilitate interactions and new collaborations, and promote discussions on enhancing diversity and inclusion in the scientific community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Suicide and overdose are leading causes of death for people released from prison and there are strong racialized disparities in these health outcomes. Through this proposed plan, the applicant will use advanced epidemiologic approaches to optimize North Carolina’s post-release supervision (PRS) program to prevent and address racialized disparities in suicide and overdose mortality and reincarceration among formerly incarcerated people. This work will generate evidence-based policy-relevant PRS recommendations to support community reentry for people being released from prisons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Herpesviruses are important human pathogens that can have devastating effects in neonates and immunocompromised individuals, yet there is no cure for any herpesvirus and treatment options are lacking. Here, I dissect the mechanism of an essential feature of the herpesviral lifecycle - viral genome packaging - by exploring the role of a unique accessory factor required for packaging and by developing an assay to monitor packaging in vitro. Detailed mechanistic insight is essential to understand the mechanism of current antiherpesviral drugs and to facilitate the identification of new targets for antivirals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  Hallucinations and other perceptual abnormalities are hallmark symptoms of psychosis spectrum disorders, but as of yet, there is no definitive mechanism to target for intervention and prevention. One modern theory of hallucination formation leverages a predictive coding model of belief updating, but this model might be expanded upon by considering the mechanisms driving the vividness of mental imagery to explain perceptual abnormality severity. By combining the predictive coding theory with novel research on the mechanisms of mental imagery, the present study aims to identify a potential mechanism for the formation of perceptual abnormalities and thus identifying a target for intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Highly targeted nerve stimulation could greatly benefit people with lower urinary tract disease by correcting the behavior of malfunctioning organs; however, the urinary tract has so many complex, interacting parts that tuning all the stimulation parameters accurately to get good therapy is very difficult. We propose a new framework for computationally modeling the lower urinary tract that combines mathematical models of known physiological principles with unknown complexities accounted for by artificial intelligence. Drawing on this framework, we can simulate the urinary tract, and innumerable possible nerve stimulations, to learn more about what goes wrong in urinary tract disease and discover the most promising therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Defects in cellular polarity are associated with numerous neurological disorders, kidney diseases, and cancer. In many cell types, polarity is established by the motor-driven localization of RNAs, proteins and vesicles to distinct regions within the cell. This proposal seeks to understand the molecular mechanism by which cell polarity is established and the role of motor proteins in this process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Synaptic connections in the hippocampus have exquisite dynamic properties which underlie plasticity and cognition in the brain. Elucidating the mechanisms that regulate synaptic behavior is therefore key to understanding deficits in cognition and memory that contribute to neurodevelopmental and neurological disorders. In this project, I will determine how Ca2+ sensor molecules underlie the activity dependent dynamics of synapses and thus regulate hippocampal circuits that drive cognition.

ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prenatal Alcohol Exposure (PAE) is the leading cause of neurodevelopmental disability in the US. However, the emerging practice of simultaneous alcohol and cannabinoid (SAC) use among young adults of child-bearing age makes it imperitive to investigate the additional risk for adverse infant outcomes due to such prenatal poly-substance use. The goals of this proposal are consistent with the priorities of the Collaborative Research on Addiction at NIH (CRAN) initiative, which are to, “address poly- or multiple substance use, abuse, and addiction” and to “elucidate the common, specific, and interacting causes and consequences of substance exposure”.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: 8. Project Narrative This project investigates the underlying biological mechanisms whereby environmental chemicals alter the expression of genes that control physiological processes that affect human health and liver-based disease. This research is centered on the effects of foreign chemicals on gene transcription events whose dysregulation leads to non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, which affects an estimated 25% of all US adults and is a major cause of advanced disease and liver failure. Overall, the findings obtained are expected to increase our understanding of the effects of environmental chemical exposures on hepatic metabolism and the development of liver disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cadmium (Cd) is a potential neurotoxicant positively associated with cognitive impairments and neurodegenerative diseases in humans. Since the gut microbiome is a target of Cd toxicity and the gut-brain axis is important for regulating neurological functions, this project aims to determine the role of the gut-brain axis in regulating Cd neurotoxicity. This project will determine for the first time the importance of the gut-brain axis in Cd-induced neurotoxicity, enhance the understanding concerning the neurotoxicity of Cd and other environmental toxicants, and provide translational implications for the design of prevention and intervention strategies to mitigate Cd neurotoxicity by reprogramming the gut microbiome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Project Narrative Pancreatitis is a painful condition in which pancreatic enzymes are not properly routed to the small intestine and instead damage pancreatic cells. I will study pancreatic triacylglycerol lipase (PTL) to determine if it self-regulates by filamentation to prevent lipase activity during vesicular storage, in a similar fashion to lipoprotein lipase (LPL). These studies will uncover how LPL and PTL are stored inside of vesicles, revealing an innovative path to stabilize inactive PTL structures and prevent PTL from damaging pancreatic cells during pancreatitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Repeated binge drinking is associated with elevated systolic blood pressure, which confronts more than half of mid-life adults in the United States. This K99/R00 application proposes training and research to develop a research strategy that integrates vascular physiology, physical therapies, and alcohol-related health. This will address the gaps in knowledge of mechanisms underlying alcohol-attributable contribution to elevated blood pressure and help identify/develop therapeutic approaches to decrease the burden of hypertension in mid-life adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescent suicide is a public health issue of critical priority, with rates rapidly increasing, and suicidal ideation (SI) is one of the most robust predictors of death by suicide. Adolescents that belong to a sexual- or gender- minority (SGM) group are at a significantly greater risk of experiencing SI; thus, identifying underlying processes that contribute to the development of SI in SGM youth are crucial in order to pinpoint intervention targets to aid in preventing death by suicide. As part of a larger longitudinal study, the current proposal will evaluate a potential mechanism linking SGM identity to increased SI risk via interactions with low social reward responsiveness and interpersonal stress – the proposed project will be the first to test this pathway by leveraging an innovative approach with a large high-risk sample of adolescents and will identify novel targets for intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurodegenerative diseases including Alzheimer’s disease and related tauopathies impact millions of individuals and with cases on the rise, there is a desperate need for effective therapeutic options. Impairments in protein quality control mechanisms contribute to pathology by allowing the accumulation of toxic protein species. In this proposal, I will investigate the ability of a novel target to promote protein quality control machineries in neurons, offering a strategy to prevent or delay the onset of neurodegenerative pathology and identifying a potential target for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Humans and other animals use olfaction, the sense of smell, to perform a number of essential behaviors, including detecting food and avoiding predators. This work aims to understand how the piriform cortex, a brain region important for processing odor information, represents relationships between odors, and how these relationships may change depending on an animal's experience and learning. Results from this study will contribute to a broader understanding of how learning shapes sensory perception, and offers potential benefits for understanding and treating olfactory dysfunction observed in numerous neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Intracortical brain-computer interfaces (iBCIs) have the immense potential to restore motor function for individuals with motor disabilities, through directly accessing the neural signals driving movement. However, multiple factors necessitate electrodes being surgically implanted in less desirable cortical regions, due to brain damage (e.g., stroke), neurovasculature or surgically inaccessible cortex, thus comprising access to the required neural signals and hindering the clinical translation of BCI technologies to populations that would most benefit from it. To bridge this gap, in this proposal, we will investigate the amount of whole-body movement information that can be extracted in a single region of human motor cortex and quantify the degree to which we can modify the functional architecture of the implant site itself to support the desired iBCI application, laying the groundwork for developing versatile iBCI applications for a variety of clinical populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is the most common cancer among AIDS patients and is caused by a virus our laboratory discovered called Kaposi sarcoma herpesvirus (KSHV). KSHV must express a protein, LANA, to survive in the cell and it has evolved to avoid host cellular immune responses. This proposal identifies these immune evasion pathways for LANA and eliminates them to develop a therapeutic vaccine that will harness the restored immune system to target KS in AIDS patients who have had immune reconstitution but still have persistent KS after antiretroviral treatment. 2

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the acknowledgment that chronic stress can negatively impact the quality of life, learning, and thus, rehabilitation outcomes, little research has explored the role of chronic stress on communicative participation and language rehabilitation in people with aphasia (PWA). The purpose of this study is to elucidate the sources of stress related to communication and explore the adaptive and maladaptive self-management strategies that PWA use to decrease perceptions of stress secondary to their language impairment. The results of this project will lay the foundation for interventions that reduce perceptions of stress and facilitate successful communicative participation while providing insight into adaptive coping strategies that can be promoted as an adjuvant to routine, impairment-based language rehabilitation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In everyday listening environments, integrating multiple acoustic features is crucial for auditory object perception and stream segregation, yet there is a gap in our understanding of how various spatial and temporal cues are integrated to influence perception in healthy and impaired auditory systems. This project adapts a pitch-based auditory illusion to the spatial domain to investigate spatio-temporal feature integration, examining the biasing effects of sound source location on the perception of relative timing among sequential sounds in normal hearing and single-sided deaf (SSD) adults. The public health significance of this project lies in establishing a simple, innovative task for assessing auditory spatio-temporal feature integration to serve as a more specific functional marker of real-world localization performance than current clinical tasks, and applying this task to SSD patients with and without a cochlear implant (CI) to determine the nature of auditory spatial cue restoration with CI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Major depressive disorder (MDD) remains a prevalent, debilitating, and recurrent disorder that is characterized by cognitive and behavioral inflexibility, the failure to adapt thinking and behavior to meet environmental demands. Given that individuals with a history of MDD often continue to experience ineffective emotion regulation during remission, the proposed study aims to develop a novel theory-based measure of emotion regulation flexibility in everyday life, and to examine its neural underpinnings. By advancing our understanding of real-world emotion regulation flexibility and its precise neural mechanisms, the proposed study will elucidate novel, ecologically-valid treatment targets for depression, that could be modulated using neurobehavioral interventions to improve flexibility and lessen the disease burden of recurrent MDD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is aimed at elucidating how the multiple trafficking pathways inside cells are coordinated. Unobstructed flow of proteins and membrane through these pathways is required for proper functioning of all cells during normal growth and under stress, and even minor defects can result in severe acquired and inherited diseases. Conserved small GTPases that function as molecular switches are key regulators of these pathways and we will explore mechanisms by which these GTPases integrate cellular pathways into a dynamic network.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Scoliosis and growth plate disorders are among of the most common pediatric musculoskeletal disorders, causing disfigurement, psychosocial distress. The causes of these disorders of the spine and long bones are likely due to a variety of factors, yet little is known about the genetic factors and signaling pathways involved. This proposal will gain novel mechanistic insight into the regulation of spine and growth plate development and homeostasis through subcellular analysis gene expression and characterization of native protein complexes in these important musculoskeletal tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project narrative While cognitive impairment is a key domain of alcohol use disorder, the neurocircuit mechanisms underlying this remain poorly understood. This project explores how chronic alcohol-induced changes in the claustrum-anterior cingulate cortex pathway contribute to cognitive control impairments. In so doing, this proposal seeks to introduce the claustrum as a key nucleus underlying alcohol-induced cognitive impairments with therapeutic targeting potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE The present approach for brain injury monitoring employs multiple invasive brain probes with each probe providing a different measurement which must be individually visualized, analyzed and integrated by the physician. We will develop a brain monitoring solution (the “NeuroProbe Solution”) based on a single probe that will combine the function of multiple individual brain probes. The NeuroProbe Solution has many advantages over current solutions including improved safety, better total patient physiology data integration and a lower cost, and is, thus, expected to lead to improved monitoring and personalized care of patients with brain injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A breakdown in antigen presenting cell (APC) tolerance towards intestinal microbiota plays a critical role in the initiation and perpetuation of inflammation in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). This proposal seeks to test whether QR401, an APC-targeted AMPK agonist designed to restore tolerogenic APCs in the GI tract, can alleviate intestinal inflammation and disease severity in proof-of-concept murine models of IBD. Successful completion of the proposed project will result in the validation and development of a first-in-class, oral, APC- specific nanotherapy, which could provide a much-needed treatment option for IBD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will describe a previously unknown mechanism of postnatal neuron and synapse pruning in the mammalian cochlea. Data generated from these experiments will build upon our knowledge of the function of both membrane dynamics and supporting cells in postnatal cochlear development. Understanding this process could provide insight into the prevention of hearing loss, which affects approximately 1 in 5 people worldwide (World Health Organization World Report on Hearing).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI) is a common tool for measuring human brain function, but it does not measure neuronal firing directly—instead it tracks changes in blood delivery and blood oxygen that accompany this neuronal activity. New evidence shows that the brain is capable of controlling these “hemodynamic” changes finely enough to use it to identify neuronal activity at the scale of the “layers” of the cerebral cortex, which are the inputs and outputs of brain circuits, yet, unfortunately, the imaging resolution of modern fMRI is not high enough to resolve these layers. To address this, in this F32 fellowship we propose to develop a high-resolution one-dimensional imaging approach called “linescan fMRI” that rapidly scans across the cerebral cortical layers, then fully characterize its performance, validate it as a tool for measuring brain activity within cerebral cortical layers, then apply it to a new experiment we have designed, all to establish linescan fMRI as a mainstream tool for human neuroscience.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Oral Squamous Cell Carcinoma (OSCC) is a common and complex disease with limited therapeutic options. We propose to investigate how cancer cells communicate with other supporting cells in the OSCC tumor microenvironment to facilitate the progression of this disease. Such studies are essential for understanding the mechanism(s) by which cancer cells grow and spread, and for identification of candidate biomarkers and therapeutic targets to better diagnose and treat OSCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Innovations in artificial intelligence (AI) algorithms have exponentially increased with the widespread digitization of healthcare data in general and ophthalmic data in particular, but the implementation of AI-based technologies into clinical ophthalmic practice for clinical decision support is still in relatively early stages. This study will leverage data from diverse research and clinical glaucoma populations to develop deep learning algorithms to predict 1) patients who will need glaucoma surgery and 2) patients who are progressing in the next 12 months, and 2 years. These algorithms can then be used to support randomized clinical trial testing of AI guided glaucoma management using the AI models developed.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative Children and adults with rare cancers such as rhabdoid and desmoplastic small round cell tumors have dismal outcomes with current therapy. The planned research project is relevant to public health because the development of comprehensive proteogenomic methods and elucidation of tumor-specific cell surface proteomes will provide candidates for new targeted therapies. The proposed research is highly relevant to the NIH and FDA mission and the urgent unmet need of defining therapeutic targets for rare tumors, thereby overcoming fundamental barriers towards the development of improved treatments for human cancer.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Integrative proteogenomics for elucidation of tumor-specific cell surface proteomes in ultra-rare cancers

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Developmental stuttering affects 5% of children and 1% of adults worldwide, and exhibits a sibling relative risk of 70%; however, despite this high population prevalence and remarkably high heritability, understanding of the molecular and neurological function of genes impacting stuttering risk is lacking. The present application proposes to enhance our understanding of how common and rare genetic factors contribute to stuttering by using information about how genes are transcribed and how gene transcription affects brain features. This study represents the largest and most comprehensive functional genetic analysis of stuttering ever performed and the results obtained in this study will be critical to improving basic understanding of the mechanisms that contribute to risk, providing a foundational first step for future studies and therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Urinary tract infections (UTIs) are common during pregnancy and can cause serious maternal and neonatal consequences, but current clinical guidelines fail to provide guidance for first trimester management of UTI due to uncertainty about the relative benefits and harms of commonly used antibiotic regimens. Our proposed study will evaluate the utilization, effectiveness, and safety of commonly-used antibiotic regimens in pregnant women treated for outpatient UTI. Ultimately, the evidence generated by this study will inform clinical guidelines and antibiotic prescribing, which will lead to better outcomes in pregnant women and infants, improved antimicrobial stewardship, and improved long-term bacterial susceptibility to antibiotics.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE There is a rapidly growing population of over 16 million children who are HIV-exposed uninfected (HEU) under the age of 14 years, and substantial investments have been made to evaluate the impact of in utero HIV and antiretroviral (ARV) drug exposures on the health and developmental outcomes among children who are HEU throughout infancy, childhood, and adolescence. While it is equally of public health importance to follow outcomes of young adults with in utero HIV- and ARV drug-exposures, young adults must be made aware of their exposure status, necessitating parent disclosure, which can be challenging. The Disclosure Intervention to Support Caregivers (DISC) study will result in the development of a contextually appropriate tool to prepare caregivers living with HIV to disclose their HIV status to their adolescents and equip caregivers to assess the wellbeing of their adolescents during and following disclosure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Narrative Persons with HIV have an increased risk of Clonal hematopoiesis of Indeterminate Potential (CHIP) which is the presence of a proportion of blood cells carrying a somatic mutation that have all arisen from a common blood stem or progenitor cell. CHIP is hypothesized to be a biomarker of accelerated aging and may increase an individual’s risk for developing cancer. In this study, we will evaluate the prevalence of CHIP and methylation markers in PWH and their potential association with cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative. Youth commonly seek help for their mental health concerns in schools, but many schools don’t have enough mental health providers to help everyone in need. Research studies show that digital, self-guided, single-session interventions can help reduce students’ mental health concerns, but we don’t know how to get schools to use these kinds of interventions in real life outside of research studies. In this study, we will work together with students, parents/caregivers, teachers, administrators, and school mental health providers to find out the best ways that digital, self-guided, single session interventions can be practically implemented in schools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) exhibits a proclivity for regional recurrence in the tumor draining lymph nodes (tDLNs) well after clearance of the primary tumor. This pattern of spread is highlighted by decreased lymphocyte trafficking and de-differentiated Lymphotoxin Beta receptor (LtBR) expressing High Endothelial Venules (HEVs) within the tDLN. We aim to decipher how regional recurrence is promoted in the absence of LtBR signaling, and whether LtBR agonism restores HEV functionality to mitigate regional recurrence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The population of people living with HIV (PLWH) is aging due to the improvement in life expectancy brought by anti-retroviral therapies (ART), unveiling the increased risk that PLWH have for developing cancers that are not typically associated with HIV infection. Clonal hematopoiesis (CH) is an age-related phenomenon in which we accrue somatic mosaicism in the blood system, increasing the risk of hematologic malignancies. Given that HIV infection increases the risk of developing CH, the objective of this project is to determine whether HIV infection promotes CH and its transformation to hematologic malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Emerging evidence from recent genome-wide studies has revealed that promoters across eukaryotes are commonly paired to drive bidirectional transcription. Work in yeast suggests bidirectional transcription could be the naïve or innate state of transcription initiation with directionality evolving due to the action of diverse pathways. Building on our initial success in developing a highly efficient in vitro reconstitution system of transcription initiation from highly purified yeast factors, we set out to further develop this system to solve the mechanism of divergent transcription through structural and biochemical dissection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE MYT1L syndrome is a recently identified, understudied neurodevelopmental disorder caused by loss of one copy of the MYT1L gene . Antisense oligonucleotides (ASOs) are a class of molecules that have been safely used in the clinic to treat neurological disorders by changing gene regulation for disease genes like MYT1L. This project will explore MYT1L gene regulation and its potential to be harnessed for ASO-based treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Last, First, Middle): HOY, JENNIFER, LYN PROJECT NARRATIVE This work will identify neural circuit mechanisms underlying the development of visual stimulus detection and pursuit behavior. Appropriately orienting towards salient stimuli and filtering out distraction is required for healthy visual cognition and attention in adults and is sensitive to developmental experience. Autism, schizophrenia, ADHD and generalized anxiety are disorders rooted in perturbed development and are associated with deficits in the ability to properly modulate visuospatial orienting behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE APOE4, the strongest genetic risk factor for late-onset Alzheimer’s disease, causes aberrant cholesterol and lipid accumulation in human glial cells. No therapeutics are available to treat central nervous system lipid dysfunction in APOE4 carriers, which could prevent or slow cognitive decline in this large subset of Alzheimer’s disease patients. MCM6 Therapeutics, in partnership with Dr. Joel Blanchard’s lab at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mt. Sinai, proposes to screen a diverse small molecule library to identify novel therapeutics that reduce cholesterol and lipid accumulation in APOE4 oligodendrocytes and restore neuron myelination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative: Through this Avant-Garde Award, I plan to fill in the gaps of the United States Ending the HIV Plan for persons who use drugs (PWUD). My pioneer award vision is to develop a mobile hub and spoke model that has mobile pharmacies and clinics on wheels that deploy a rapid response sustainable workforce of trained community health workers and pharmacists that literally meet the community where they live. They will provide rapid HIV testing, opioid use disorder (OUD) diagnosis, same day deployment of medication treatment for OUD, PrEP and ART, and retain them on treatment where they live to advance the goal of ending HIV in PWUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding the neurobiological mechanisms of known risk factors for alcohol use disorder (AUD) provides one avenue for developing potential therapeutics. An individual’s response to the stimulating and sedating effects of alcohol represents known risk factors for the development of AUD. The proposed studies use mouse models of alcohol-induced stimulation and sedation to explore the role of striatal astrocytes in modulating neuronal activity to produce these behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The central nervous system relies heavily on mitochondria as one of the most energy consumptive tissues in the body, and mitochondrial dysfunction thereby relates to a plethora of neurodegenerative and neurodevelopmental disorders, such as Fragile X Syndrome (FXS). This study focuses on investigating our finding of miRNA targeting of mitochondrial transcripts in the mammalian forebrain and the possible implications of these binding events in both health and disease, such as altered mitochondrial gene expression which may impact electron transport chain composition and function. If successful, this study will expand our understanding of mitochondrial perturbation during FXS, as well as inform basic molecular biology principles concerning miRNA regulation of mitochondrial gene expression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transgender and gender diverse (TGD) communities in the rural United States experience a disproportionate burden of depression, anxiety, and suicidality due to stigma experienced on the structural level, including laws, policies, social attitudes, and norms. Using both publicly available and survey data, this mixed methods study will explore how recent state-level laws and policies focused on transgender healthcare, as well as the policy environment more broadly, affect the mental health of TGD people. Findings from this study can inform future policy decisions by demonstrating the impact of policies on mental health in the rural TGD community.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disruptions in fundamental cellular and genetic processes during embryogenesis can lead to developmental defects, which in humans are a major public health burden and leading cause of infant mortality. Interestingly, heritable disruptions to these processes can also lead to morphological diversity over evolutionary time. By studying the developmental basis and molecular evolution of a key morphological innovation, the mammalian gliding membrane, we can gain new insight into how mammals sculpt and shape mesenchyme and skin during development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT This study will examine how metabolism within specific host organs and the resulting metabolites within those host environments affect the virulence potential of Fusobacterium nucleatum, a key colonizer in the development of dental plaque and a pathogen linked to both pre-term birth and colorectal cancer. A better understanding of these host-pathogen relationships is needed to unveil critical new targets for developing anti-infective therapies so as to treat and prevent significant diseases that are associated with this pathogen.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Establishing how early and mid-life social relations are associated with ADRD risk in different racial/ethnic groups risk provides an innovative, cost effective opportunity to identify modifiable factors in midlife for ADRD risk. This project will capitalize on an existing longitudinal cohort study of detailed social relations over 28 years in a diverse lifespan sample and add cognitive and genetic measures, as well as extend racial/ethnic group comparisons to include Arab Americans in a new regionally representative adult sample in metro-Detroit. Characterizing how social relations vary as a function of race/ethnicity and clarifying unique links to ADRD risk will advance the field in terms of theory and intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Amelogenesis imperfecta is a genetic dental disorder characterized by abnormal enamel development, leading to teeth that are prone to rapid wear, chipping, and increased susceptibility to cavities. The overall objective of this study is to decipher the molecular underpinnings of amelogenesis imperfecta from the perspective of the ameloblast – a specialized cell type that generates enamel. Findings from this research will provide insight into the developmental basis of enamel disorders like amelogenesis imperfecta, which will further contribute to the development of better treatment and therapeutic approaches.

PHR: Both Congenital Disorders of Glycosylation and dystroglycanopathies are clinically heterogenous, multisystem disorders that can lead to severe progressive neural and muscular degeneration, which deleteriously impacts quality of life and is frequently lethal. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This application is being submitted in response to the Notice of Special Interest (NOSI) identified as NOT-CA- 24-029. Although treatment of early-stage HER2+ breast cancers is curative, metastatic HER2+ breast cancer is incurable. This project is relevant to public health because it will demonstrate how HER2 isoforms activate dormancy programs and immune checkpoint to drive tumor dormancy and dissemination of cells that escape the immune system. Our work will provide a new possible strategy for activating the immune system and treating dormant and metastatic tumor cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atypical facial expressivity is a common characteristic of autism that is strongly associated with negative social and mental health outcomes. This work seeks to identify the neural basis of atypical facial expression in autism using functional neuroimaging, clinical, and behavioral data. Generated findings will inform the necessary development of targeted, evidence-based interventions for this critical nonverbal communication barrier.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will characterize the flow of visuospatial information along a circuit involving the rodent pulvinar, postrhinal cortex, and medial entorhinal cortex that transforms high-dimensional sensory information into straightforward spatial representations that can guide spatial memory and behavior. Dysfunction in these brain regions is associated with cognitive impairments in disorders such as Alzheimer’s disease and topographical disorientation. Understanding the precise functional connections among these regions may provide insight into mechanisms underlying these disorders and will significantly expand our understanding of the neural processing of space.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Similar to electrical circuits, cells possess enzymatic circuits that sense, signal and respond to the presence of redox-active stimuli in their microenvironment. We will design molecular strategies to rewire enzymatic redox circuitry that will enable cells to overcome excess or deficiency of critical redox reagents. These strategies will inform future methodologies for prevention and treatment of several redox-related diseases including cancer, cardiovascular and neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Predicting language outcomes in children referred for early language concerns is a longstanding clinical and scientific challenge that often results in the delayed implementation of intervention. The overarching goal of this project is to examine how speech skills and motor skills are related to language function in children with and without early delays in language abilities. An improved understanding of these relationships will advance clinicians’ ability to make informed prognoses of language outcomes for children at risk of language impairments and will also inform future research aimed at improving the assessment and treatment of language disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A growing number of Americans report experiencing chronic loneliness, which is not only itself distressing but confers increased risk for mental and physical health problems (e.g., depression; heart disease), cognitive decline, and all-cause mortality. Despite efforts to address this pressing public health issue, rates of loneliness continue to increase, and progress has stymied, due in part to a lack of collaboration across disciplines and methods that cannot fully capture the complex interactions among biopsychosocial contributors to loneliness. The proposed study uses computational modeling to formalize an interdisciplinary theory of loneliness, rigorously test the hypotheses put forth by this theory using simulated data, and identify knowledge gaps that will serve as critical targets of future study to improve our understanding and treatment of chronic loneliness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE & PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Chronic stress contributes to many neuropsychiatric disorders, leads to cellular adaptations in the brain, and it can influence other organs throughout the body via the release of stress hormones and norepinephrine. This proposal aims to elucidate how norepinephrine signaling in microglia remodels neuron activity in response to chronic and acute stress using a combination of molecular, imaging, and behavioral approaches. As such, the results of this work will shed light on microglia-neuron interactions during stress and could reveal new strategies to develop novel therapeutics for stress-related disorders such as anxiety, depression, or post-traumatic stress disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This work aims to enhance craniofacial reconstruction by developing a nuanced understanding of the mechanisms underlying bone regeneration, focusing on the influence of the microenvironment in this process. By engineering a series of biomimicking hydrogels that replicate the stages of bone formation, this project seeks to evaluate the role of the microenvironment, by varying matrix density and mineralization, on stem cell differentiation and bone regeneration, aiming to find factors conducive to faster healing to overcome the limitations of current bone grafting methods. The potential to accelerate bone regeneration presents profound public health implications, including decreasing the dependency on limited donor grafts, eliminating donor-site morbidity, expediting patient recovery, and broadening treatment options for managing bone loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Craniofacial anomalies make up around one-third of all birth defects, and cleft palate occurs in greater than one out of every 1500 live births. During secondary palate morphogenesis, complex cell movement within the heterogeneous palatal mesenchyme is essential, but how this movement is regulated remains unclear. This proposal aims to address this gap using state-of-the-art approaches and new tools for studying cellular movement during morphogenesis in mammalian craniofacial development with the ultimate goal of advancing therapeutic treatments.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Laws legalizing cannabis use for adults have increased exponentially across the U.S. since 2010 with 38 states, the District of Columbia (D.C.), and four U.S. territories legalizing cannabis for medicinal use and 24 of those states, D.C., and three U.S. territories also legalizing cannabis for non-medical (recreational) use. Policy change has outpaced scientific research, and in the absence of federal legalization of cannabis, states have taken different policy approaches, providing a natural experiment that can lend insight into how policies impact consumer safety, public health, and equity. The Cannabis Regulators Association is a nonpartisan association of government agencies regulating cannabis and/or hemp. CANNRA’s 2024 Annual Member Meeting brings together over 200 agency officials and their staff to share emerging practices and develop skills to advance regulatory science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  Social recognition, or the ability to distinguish between familiar and novel conspecifics, is essential for organismal survival as organisms must be able to direct their behavior based on social stimuli. This proposal seeks to elucidate the functional role of basolateral amygdala-activated, lateral septum ensembles in social recognition and to comprehensively characterize their molecular signature. Elucidating the neural substrates that regulate social recognition is essential to understanding how social experience shapes the brain.

IC_NAME: Global Health Center
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is focused on the development of a new point-of-care testing technology that will provide an alternative to the conventional lateral flow technology that is currently the most common method used for detecting antibodies or antigens as markers of disease. The new method promises to simplify the development and production of point-of-care tests, thereby making these previously esoteric specialties broadly available to a broader community of assay developers and users. The current project will establish the feasibility of the new technology through demonstration of its application to rapid diagnostic testing for Chagas disease as an example of the many diagnostic and other testing applications foreseen.

PROJECT_TITLE: MiCRIA: Two-minute rapid assay platform for point-of-care diagnosis

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tobacco use disorder disproportionally affects patients with serious mental illness. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Current prevention protocols for people at risk for infective endocarditis (IE) focus on antibiotic prophylaxis prior to invasive dental office procedures for only 10% of people at risk for this life- threatening disease. Although a high percentage of cases of IE are caused by bacterial species from the mouth, there are only informal guidelines on prevention for the remaining 90% of people at risk. This study will determine if improved oral hygiene and reduction of gingival inflammation decrease the incidence and duration of bacteremia of IE-causing oral species, which would refocus longstanding guidelines on prevention for all people at risk for IE.

This will include studies of novel and durable HIV treatment in HIV-infected adults, including pregnant women, and children; strategies to induce antiretroviral-free HIV remission (or eradication) in adults and children; new treatments and prevention approaches for tuberculosis in adults, including pregnant women, and children; and HIV prevention strategies, including pre-exposure prophylaxis and integrated prevention approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN) is a significant clinical challenge affecting many cancer patients and survivors with no approved treatments to target the root causes of CIPN effectively. Serpin Pharma’s SP16, a novel LRP1 agonist, is a highly potent anti- inflammatory and neuro-protectant drug, that repairs nerve injury and ameliorates pain, creating a revolutionary complete solution for CIPN. The overall goal of this project is to advance the development of SP16 through a Phase 1b clinical trial as a preventative strategy in CIPN, offering a unique approach and a commercially viable opportunity to address an unmet need for cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescent mental health has been named a public health emergency, with rates of depression and suicide rising steadily. Social media (SM) is linked to negative mental health consequences for some adolescents but not others, and no studies to date have uncovered a modifiable target that could alter the course of negative mental health outcomes for affected adolescents. This NRSA project proposes to identify whether emotion regulation strategies—a widely used and effective target in existing clinical interventions—may contribute to these differential patterns and may be a candidate target for future adolescent SM/mental health interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are currently no effective therapies to reduce vascular contributions to cognitive impairment and dementia (VCID). Over 80% of individuals with Alzheimer’s disease (AD) have underlying VCID pathology that contributes to dementia progression; this is known as multiple etiology dementia (MED). Our goals is to determine if an estrogen prodrug can be used as a preventative therapy, during either peri-menopause or menopause, to reduce VCID pathology and slow progression of MED.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding how individuals seek and consume alcohol in the presence of alternative reinforcers is critical for understanding the progression from recreational drinking to alcohol use disorder given that six of eleven of the diagnostic criteria pertain to increase appetitive (seeking) and consummatory behaviors directed towards alcohol with concurrent decreases in these behaviors maintained by non-alcohol alternatives. The current proposal aims to investigate a circuit that may control alcohol choice behavior by using a novel operant self-administration choice paradigm that procedurally separates appetitive and consummatory facets of behavior. Particular focus will be directed towards understanding whether acute withdrawal from chronic alcohol exposure and sex as a biological variable result in differential effects on alcohol choice behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative The identification of mechanisms responsible for poor response to epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) inhibitors in HNSCC is warranted in order to harness the beneficial properties of these agents. This grant application tests if NOX2 redox activity and IL-8 signaling contribute to poor long-term anti-tumor response to EGFRIs via increased IL-1 signaling in RT-treated HNSCC tumors. We expect that this application will discover novel mechanisms and possibly lead to promising new therapeutic approaches for HNSCC patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The transition from initial to problematic alcohol use occurs within a subset of individuals; thus, evaluating individual variability in punished alcohol seeking models can reveal why some individuals abstain from alcohol use in the presence of negative consequences while others persist. The orbitofrontal cortex is a neural substrate that modulates action selection and action contingencies. The proposed project seeks to explore contributions of the orbitofrontal cortex in the individual variability to seek alcohol despite negative consequences as well as dissect the behavioral features of punished alcohol seeking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Ohio State University Comprehensive Cancer Center (OSUCCC) is a matrix cancer center that integrates and leverages all of the resources of the University to achieve its broad vision of creating a cancer free world. The OSUCCC addresses the public health needs of the catchment area (the state of Ohio) through research, education and community outreach and engagement as research conducted within the five OSUCCC Programs focuses on high priority cancers for the OSUCCC including lung, breast, colorectal, prostate, endometrial, cervical cancer, thyroid, and leukemia, as well as tobacco use, obesity, and HPV vaccination. Screening and outreach activities are provided to the populations across the lifespan that we serve, especially those with higher burden of being diagnosed with cancer, such as racial/ethnic minorities and other underserved populations (e.g., rural, LGBTQ+, Appalachian) through targeted, culturally appropriate education activities, free cancer screenings, patient navigation, community networking, environmental scans, and addressing policy issues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Pain and depression affect large percentages of the population and identifying the optimal medication for an individual can be challenging, so this trial will determine whether using genetic information to inform selection of opioids or antidepressants leads to better clinical outcomes for patients. People with African ancestry (AAs) have the highest rates of uncontrolled high blood pressure, chronic kidney disease and kidney failure, some of which is due to APOL1 genetic variants. We will test AA adults with high blood pressure for APOL1 and return the results to patients and their clinicians, to see if early knowledge of high genetic risk improves blood pressure, provider and patient behaviors and is cost effective.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative  Alzheimer's disease is one of the most common and progressive genetic neurodegenerative disorders in the US with more than 5 million people currently living with Alzheimer's disease and women are more likely to develop a rapid progression of Alzheimer's disease, than men when predictive factors such as obesity, lifespan, and enhanced stroke severity are considered. We propose to use a targeted non-invasive photobiomodulation (laser) therapy to decrease protein arginine methyltransferase 4 in Alzheimer's disease and related vascular dementias. Photobiomodulation (through the modulation of protein arginine methyltransferase 4) can combat cerebral hypoperfusion/vascular tonicity and neurovascular uncoupling in mouse models of Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol use disorder (AUD) is a debilitating condition with poor long-term treatment outcomes, despite effective treatments for initial recovery. A common cause of relapse is anxiety that develops during abstinence, where individuals use alcohol for its negative reinforcing properties to remove anxiety that they experience. This project aims to better understand changes in negative reinforcement behaviors and their associated neural network during early abstinence from an AUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neuronal adaptation to the current environment is vital to sensory perception, especially in noisy environments where the relevant signal is obscured by noise. People with various types of hearing impairments, including age- related hearing loss, struggle disproportionately to understand speech in noisy environments, impairing their ability to communicate with others and negatively impacting their quality of life. The proposed research will further our understanding of the neuronal circuits involved in separating signal from noise and will lead to new treatment approaches for these patient groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is a cancer caused by a virus called KSHV that occurs frequently in individuals with HIV infection, and KS may lead to death despite treatment. This study will assess how interactions between KSHV, HIV, and host immune responses in KS tumors before and during treatment influence KS clinical outcomes, which could ultimately lead to new therapies for the treatment of KS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal aims to develop a novel, safe, and effective tissue-adhesive tattoo (TAT2) ink for endoscopic marking with improved precision to enhance colorectal lesion surveillance. The current commercial inks pose several limitations including extensive diffusion, fibrosis, and extravasation. The proposed project will develop new, optimized ink formulations with robust stability, biocompatibility, and localization efficacy with evaluation in in vitro cell-based, ex vivo, and in vivo pig studies for pre-clinical evaluation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Binge drinking (BD) has numerous adverse consequences, including accidents, assault, and alcohol poisoning. College represents a critical time for the development of BD, wherein drinking patterns established early in the first semester influence future BD and increase risk for alcohol use disorders in the years following graduation. This study will use smartwatches to examine sleep, physical activity, and heart rate variability as prospective predictors of BD onset and frequency during the first and second semesters of college, serving to identify novel biopsychosocial risk factors that will facilitate the early detection and prevention of harmful alcohol use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Work is a social determinant of health, and workers in the United States increasingly engage in non-standard work arrangements that may be classified as forms of emergent work. To better understand emergent work’s implications for worker health and well-being, this project will investigate how these non-standard work arrangements can be classified into distinct forms of emergent work and the lived experiences of emergent work relative to health, well-being, and health disparities. This project will enhance understanding of objective and subjective factors influencing the health and well-being of contemporary workers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Despite recent progress in artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML), deep learning models have been shown to perform inaccurately on patients from minority racial and ethnic backgrounds. This limitation adversely impacts underrepresented patients through propagating existing biases and inequities in healthcare. The pro- posed research identifies and validates computational strategies to address this issue in the diagnosis and treat- ment of pulmonary tuberculosis, sepsis, and other diseases of important significance to public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Transfusion is a common lifesaving therapy, but some patients have an immune reaction to transfused blood, making ongoing transfusion increasingly difficult or even impossible. It is currently difficult to predict which patients will have this problem and there are no accepted therapies to prevent it. The proposed studies aim to develop the ability to predict which patients will have an immune reaction and also to understand why they do. Achieving this goal will have the immediate benefit of allowing the modification of current practices to decrease immune reactions in patients likely to have them and also identify targets to allow new therapies to prevent this problem.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: The outcomes of this study will provide a method to accurately measure body fat in the clinical environment and information on energy expenditure in youth with spina bifida. This population is at a higher risk of obesity then the general population. These findings will provide a method to screen and support prevention and treatment of obesity through the ability to accurately identify the youth’s weight status and to recommend daily caloric needs for this high-risk population.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The long-term goal of this research is to understand bone anabolism, cessation of treatment and fracture repair in the setting of Down Syndrome (DS). These studies will provide important new insights regarding the specific involvement of genes associated with trisomy 21 and the regulation of skeletal homeostasis. The application provides the first ever assessment of fracture repair and the impact of anabolic treatment cessation in DS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While emotion dysregulation and sleep disruption are associated with vulnerability for mood disorders during adolescence, the neurodevelopmental underpinnings are unknown. Using a combination of advanced neuroimaging techniques and digital phenotyping, this project will provide critical knowledge on the neurodevelopmental mechanisms linking emotion dysregulation and sleep disruption during adolescence. Such knowledge will yield actionable information regarding the optimal timing of intervention strategies targeting easily modifiable sleep behaviors to improve mental health outcomes, and will thus provide an important contribution to public health. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative: Hair cells are responsible for the transduction of sound and acceleration stimuli relevant to the auditory and vestibular sensory systems, respectively. Critically, when the “hairs” or stereocilia of the hair cells are deflected, tip link proteins connecting the stereocilia are pulled upon, opening the mechanoelectrial transduction (MET) ion channels and allowing for excitatory cationic current to enter the hair cells. In this study, recent advances in gene therapy techniques are leveraged to investigate the effects of modulating biophysical properties of the tip link proteins on MET current, which will lead to a better understanding of the basic mechanisms mediating the mechanotransduction function in hair cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The Data Management and Coordinating Center (DMCC) of the Rare Diseases Clinical Research Network (RDCRN) at Cincinnati Children’s will enhance clinical trial readiness of the RDCRN by advancing the methods and the practice of rare disease clinical and translational research. The DMCC will develop and share knowledge accumulated by the Network, including research data, study findings, and best practices, for use by all stakeholders studying, treating, or adversely affected by rare diseases. We will catalyze shared participation in the Network in order to transform the RDCRN into a collaborative community dedicated to the goal of better, faster, more impactful clinical research for rare diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE Between 4 and 6 years of age, children develop eating habits that last a lifetime, often with negative consequences for health. Flavor perception is a major determinant of food choices but is poorly understood among young children. The present proposal addresses this issue by investigating how different senses (taste and smell) contribute to flavor perception in early childhood, and how flavor perception relates to weight status.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Spatial transcriptomics revolutionized cancer comprehension by allowing whole transcriptome analysis while maintaining the tumor architecture. With that the critical cell-to-cell interactions, that have been demonstrated to modulate tumorigenesis and responses to therapies, are preserved and can be characterized. In this new collaboration we will apply novel gene expression spatial experimental and computational tools to expand the DNA- and RNA-sequencing profiling to understand IPMN clonal evolution, and identify the microenvironment changes that follows premalignancy progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the inner ear, disrupted axon guidance has been shown to result in altered neural circuit assembly, which may cause hearing loss or the ability to avoid damaging noise. Type II spiral ganglion neurons (SGNs) possibly act to protect and preserve cochlear structures by responding to damage and triggering noise-avoidance behaviors. In my proposed studies, I will determine mechanisms that control normal OHC innervation by type II SGNs. This will reveal insights into how a putative mammalian auditory pain system is established during development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Sulggi Lee PROJECT NARRATIVE Methamphetamine (MA) use is highly prevalent among HIV+ individuals and is likely to pose challenges for achieving an HIV cure in these individuals, even with effective antiretroviral therapy (ART) suppression. HIV+ ART-suppressed individuals with a history of MA use will be studied to determine whether MA increases virus production and systemic inflammation, and to identify the genes and immunologic pathways that drive MA- induced effects. Data obtained during the course of this study should contribute important and novel genetic and immunologic data to the HIV cure and psychostimulant addiction research agenda.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Depression is a highly prevalent and disabling mental illness and, despite considerable research into pathophysiological mechanisms and treatments, treatment response remains heterogeneous and it is difficult to predict how an individual will (or will not) respond to a specific treatment. There is evidence that psychomotor disturbance (e.g., psychomotor slowing) may be indicative of pathogenic mechanisms and an effective predictor of illness course and treatment response; however, current assessment methods are subject to bias and there is limited understanding of biological markers of this dysfunction. Examining the relationship between biomarkers of motor dysfunction which have been observed in other populations (e.g., Parkinson’s), instrumental measurements of psychomotor disturbance, and key outcomes (e.g., symptomatology, functioning, quality of life) has considerable potential for developing novel treatments and improving personalized treatment recommendations.
