IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The differential diagnosis of childhood apraxia of speech (CAS), a pediatric speech disorder that affects between 60,000 and 780,000 children under 14 in the US, remains difficult in clinical and research settings. This difficulty is due in large part to the reliance on diagnostic techniques that can be subjective and prone to bias, resulting in inconsistent diagnostic and treatment outcomes for children in this population. This project systematically investigates the validity and potential differential diagnostic accuracy of a well-motivated set of objective acoustic measures in a large retrospective sample of children with and without CAS to help improve accurate diagnosis and thereby support more effective treatment decisions and outcomes for children with CAS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study is relevant to public health because diabetes and COVID-19 disproportionately affect racial and ethnic minorities. It is important to understand the intersection of social determinants of health and underlying biologic risk of developing diabetes to improve health equity. A more comprehensive understanding of factors influencing health outcomes in racial and ethnic minorities will inform targeted interventions to further advance the NINR mission to improve population and community health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to characterize neurodevelopmental mechanisms underlying the association of early childhood adverse experiences involving deprivation with pediatric psychopathology. The proposed research will improve understanding of neurodevelopmental risk for adverse mental health outcomes by identifying pathways of frontoparietal network development linking deprivation with psychopathology first in early childhood and then longitudinally from early childhood through adolescence. Findings will have implications for population health by identifying pathways of transdiagnostic psychopathology risk that can inform future early intervention efforts for childhood adversity, which impacts nearly 50% of children and adolescents in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Contact PD/PI: Rijo-Ferreira, Filipa Project Narrative Malaria parasites invade, replicate and burst host’s red blood cells in a synchronized manner, leading to rhythmic fevers. The proposed research will investigate how malaria parasites process daily rhythms within their hosts to regulate the synchronized development. When parasite and host rhythms are mismatched, infection is disturbed, therefore, uncovering the mechanism by which malaria coordinate their 24h periodicity will have an impact on understanding and treating this deadly infection. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Skin-penetrating parasitic nematodes cause significant global health burdens that disproportionately impact socioeconomically disadvantaged communities. This proposal aims to identify and characterize the behavioral and neural mechanisms mediating odor-evoked host seeking and host invasion in the human-parasitic, skin- penetrating nematode Strongyloides stercoralis. Findings from this work will generate fundamental insight into parasitic nematode chemosensory biology that will inform future preventative and control methods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal will provide the most comprehensive study to date of H. pylori, other Helicobacter infection and liver cancer in both African Americans (AAs) and whites by using a pooled nested case-control study. Results from this proposal have etiologic relevance and clinical impact by identifying (1) a novel bacterial infection for non-viral liver cancer; and (2) race/ethnic-specific Helicobacter infection associated with liver cancer that will inform designing interventions to reduce existing disparities, given the high prevalence of H. pylori infection in AAs in the U.S. These investigations into the associations between bacterial infections and liver cancer risk will also advance the field of liver cancer etiology, prevention, and case management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Previous research has found that sexual minority people are at increased risk for psychopathology, including Obsessive Compulsive Disorder (OCD). Further, sexual minority people experience unique stressors (e.g., discrimination), but the associations between these stressors and OCD severity and treatment outcomes have yet to be examined. As such, the current project aims to identify the roles of general versus sexual minority- specific risk factors in OCD severity and treatment outcomes among sexual minority people with OCD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Olfaction and memory are intimately intertwined, demonstrated by unique neural circuitry, and highlighted by the loss of smell in memory-based disorders, such as Alzheimer's disease. The proposed research aims to probe the cellular identity of odor stimulus decision-predicting time cells, the importance of their divergent time tiled activity in the context of behavior, and the contributions of PV interneurons to these cells regulated activity. The outcomes of this research will not only help to guide further research into divergent pyramidal cell behavior in the hippocampus but will also contribute to the greater understanding of how olfactory memories are stored and recalled, laying foundational groundwork for possible memory recovery in patients with memory loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: RELEVANCE: Given the disproportionate burden of cardiovascular disease in rural areas, particularly in the southeastern portion of the United States, the proposed study will investigate the impact of distinctive structural processes of disinvestment in rural areas that influence neighborhood opportunity and vulnerability. This proposal focuses neighborhood measures of disinvestment, social vulnerability, and racial and economic isolation to investigate associations with CVD risk factors leveraging the Risk Underlying Rural Areas Longitudinal Study (RURAL). Findings from this research may help to identify macrosocial drivers of cardiovascular risk and disparities in rural communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Community health workers (CHWs) play a crucial role in reducing health disparities by improving health care access and mitigating the impacts of social determinants of health. As community health workers tend to be part of or closely affiliated with the communities they serve, they often experience many of the same social risk factors as their clients. Exploring how community health workers experience integration into clinical settings can improve how programs are designed to support their professional quality of life and enhance the quality and effectiveness of health care services.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bone is one of the most widely transplanted tissues in the world, however, the complex mechanisms that underlie bone formation after injury remain incomplete. Nerves have been shown to play a role in modulating bone healing, yet their interactions with bone forming cells, such as osteoprogenitors, have not been fully elucidated. By understanding these interactions, we can identify potential therapeutic targets to encourage bone formation following injury or disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE American adolescents are currently experiencing high rates of anxiety and mood disorders, signaling potential short- and long-term consequences for mental health and well-being. Neuroinflammation, linked to circadian dysregulation in the neuroimmune system, is considered a risk factor for psychiatric disorders and presents a unique targetable mechanism for novel therapies and treatment. The proposed research aims to explore the development of circadian rhythms in neuroimmune tissues and investigate whether early-life perturbations to the circadian system contribute to enduring behavioral changes.

PHR: NARRATIVE Olfactory loss serves as a prodromal symptom of neurodegenerative diseases and is also frequently observed in clinical manifestations among COVID-19 patients. This study aims to characterize and compare the inflammatory responses elicited by neurotoxic oligomers and SARS-CoV-2 infection. Additionally, it seeks to investigate the combined inflammatory responses and their neuropathological implications when viral infection is compounded with predisposing conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Amelogenin is essential for enamel formation, and when mutated, it causes X-linked Amelogenesis Imperfecta (X-AI), a hereditary disease that causes enamel defects that decrease the quality of life due to a poor-functioning tooth. This proposal aims to investigate the mechanisms of X-AI development, focusing on how the X-AI-causing mutations affect the key molecular genetics mechanism; alternative splicing of the amelogenin gene. The knowledge outcomes of this study would be utilized to stop or prolong the enamel defect phenotype of this hereditary disease in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The symptoms of memory impairment are devastating for patients and families, and existing therapies only have modest efficacy. Devices that implement direct electrical brain stimulation (EBS) hold great promise towards a means of modulating brain function to alleviate memory impairment, but have yielded mixed results, likely due to an incomplete understanding of the mechanisms underlying human memory. The proposed research will implement brain recordings in awake humans to investigate memory neurocircuitry and assess the impact of EBS that is specifically designed to enhance memory-related brain activity, which will lead to improved understanding of the mechanisms underlying human memory and optimized implementation of patient-specific EBS that may ameliorate the symptoms of memory impairment in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol use disorder is classically characterized by a loss of behavioral control, particularly in the face of negative consequences, resulting in a loss of inhibitory control that may normally suppress alcohol seeking. I hypothesize that a thalamo-striatal circuit, paraventricular thalamus projections to the nucleus accumbens, typically functions to inhibit alcohol seeking but distinct ensembles within this circuit become dysregulated following dependence. Using two-photon microscopy and single-cell optogenetics, I will identify distinct neuronal ensembles in this critical circuit, determine dependence-induced dysregulation, and demonstrate the functional role of these ensembles in regulating alcohol seeking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Clinically Assessed Risk Factors for a Second ACL Injury Using an Innovative Wearable Sensor Project Narrative ACL injuries are common among adolescent athletes, and due to residual muscle weakness and asymmetrical movement and loading patterns, many sustain a second ACL injury following return to unrestricted physical activity. This clinical cohort study seeks to demonstrate that a combination of traditional clinical and novel clinical return to sport measures (including load symmetry) will result in high predictive accuracy for second ACL injuries. The project specifically focuses on assessing the role that novel clinical return to sport measures (load asymmetry, a known risk factor for ACL re-injury) have in predicting second ACL injuries and will result in the development of a clinic based prognostic model that can be used in return to sport decision-making.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE Serving as one of four disease teams of the Accelerating Medicines Partnership and Autoimmune Mediated Diseases (AMP-AIM) consortium, the Lupus Omics Cutaneous Kidney Investigative Team (LOCKIT) will enroll and follow an estimated 400 patients with Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) from nine centers across the country. The initial focus of inquiry will be on the kidney and skin given the high prevalence, severity, and remarkable heterogeneity with which SLE manifests in these organs, and the considerable but poorly understood influences of race, ethnicity, and socioeconomic status on disease phenotypes. With a high priority on identifying early kidney involvement and understanding what drives the range of skin rashes from acute to chronic, state-of the art and next generation analytics will be applied to interrogate tissues, blood, and urine from our informative populations, with the ultimate goal to identify novel targets for intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Osteoarthritis (OA) is a widespread painful disease manifested by multiple pathological changes in the joint; but currently there are no strategies to efficiently deliver gene therapies in a cell- specific way. We propose a novel screen to identify nanoparticles that have specific affinities to various joint cells in OA. Therefore, this project is paradigm-shifting and relevant to public health, aligning with the NIH's mission to support innovative and high-impact research for treating OA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative The fitness and, ultimately, survival of an organism requires proper formation and positioning of both simple and complex epithelial tubular networks. Using the embryonic salivary gland of Drosophila as a model system, I seek to understand the processes underlying key stages of epithelial tube formation. I focus on two distinct morphogenetic processes: 1) the pathway that determines the order of primordial cell invagination to initiate salivary gland tube formation and 2) the ligand-receptor signaling molecules involved in subsequent salivary gland tube placement within the whole organism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite unprecedented clinical success in the treatment of advanced cancers, immune checkpoint inhibitors are associated with immune-related adverse events. Understanding the mechanisms of immune-related adverse events is critical to identify valid biomarkers to predict and assess these events and to establish the optimal treatment strategy targeting autoimmunity while preserving antitumor immunity, both of which are triggered by immune checkpoint inhibitors. This work seeks to determine the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying arthritis associated with immune checkpoint inhibitor therapy by utilizing patient samples.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  In nature, different sexes of a species must determine their sexual identity within the germline in order to create proper sex-specific gametes. Animals such as humans and flies rely on proper transcriptional signals as well as post-transcriptional gene regulation through RNA binding proteins to ensure proper sexual identity and germline development. Determining these mechanisms is critical for understanding the multiple levels by which sex-specific gene expression is regulated in the germline and can further treatment of human syndromes leading to infertility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A hexanucleotide repeat expansion mutation in the C9ORF72 gene is the most common genetic cause of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis and frontotemporal dementia (ALS/FTD), two devastating neurodegenerative diseases which have few treatments and no known cure. The repeat is bidirectionally transcribed, and RNA and proteins encoded by the antisense strand have been shown to contribute to neurodegeneration in ALS/FTD but are understudied. This project aims to study transcription of the antisense repeat RNA, as well design and evaluate putative therapeutic strategies specifically targeting antisense transcription and translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The processing and categorization of behaviorally relevant complex auditory stimuli is a skill often critical to engaging with one’s environment, but the neural circuitry underlying this skill remains poorly understood. Many aging adults have difficulty parsing speech in noisy settings, cochlear implant users report poor quality of harmonically complex sounds such as music, and conditions like central auditory processing disorders profoundly affect the quality of life for many individuals. Identifying a causal relationship between the activity of auditory cortical ensembles and the perception and categorization of complex harmonic stimuli will lay the groundwork for a more complete understanding of auditory processing disorders, and could serve to motivate the design of cochlear implants to improve quality of life for users.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The cingulum bundle serves a critical role in mediating connectivity among mood-related regions and is implicated in several psychiatric disorders. The proposed research will investigate how variable local paracingulate sulcal pattern alters structural and functional effective cingulum bundle connectivity. This work will highlight the contribution of interindividual anatomical variability to brain connectivity in addition to informing patient-specific, neurosurgical approaches targeting the cingulum bundle for treatment-refractory psychiatric disorder intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prefrontal parvalbumin (PV) interneuron activity during early development is required for shaping prefrontal cortex connectivity, function, and cognitive flexibility, which go awry in psychiatric disorders like depression, schizophrenia and attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder; however, the factors responsible for altering PV interneuron activity are largely unknown. Here, we aim to elucidate the neurodevelopmental impact of serotonin on PV interneuron excitability and cognitive behavior by employing a combination of cellular, circuit and behavioral approaches. This proposed work would have tremendous public health relevance, as the research outlined will 1) provide insight into the development of neural circuitry supporting cognitive function; 2) promote newfound understanding of early risk factors of psychiatric disease 3) enable identification of timepoints for effective prevention and treatment of cognitive impairments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Individuals who have developed rheumatoid arthritis (RA) demonstrate several unique types of inflammatory and autoimmune cell patterns in the inflamed synovium. Molecular dissection of the synovial tissue in patients with RA has identified a number of new features with pathogenic, personalized therapeutic and prognostic importance. Using a pipeline of synovial samples obtained from patients with RA, this group will advance the field by increasing our understanding of the three-dimensional architecture and mechanisms by which cell populations interact both with each other and the systemic immune system, as well as interlink these phenotypes to patient characteristics and response to specific therapy.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Breast cancer mortality rates in Black women, particularly amongst Haitian immigrants, remain alarmingly high, exhibiting disparate outcomes. The proposed project considers how immigration as an exposure affects the epigenetic distinctions between Haitian immigrants, Haitians in Haiti, and US-born Black women with breast cancer. Additionally, we aim to explore the association between perceived stress and discrimination and aggressive tumor biology, as mediated by the presence of language barriers amongst Haitian immigrants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Post-stroke alexia, an acquired reading disorder affecting approximately 1.3 million Americans, causes a great deal of suffering and recovery is limited. The proposed research seeks to elucidate the neural mechanisms underlying post-stroke alexia by investigating functional changes in the visual word form system following damage to the language network. By investigating the relationship between atypical brain activity patterns, lesion characteristics, and behavioral deficits, this study will enhance our understanding of neural plasticity in alexia recovery and offer insights to inform targeted interventions for stroke survivors.

PHR: Project Narrative This project will build a granular, longitudinal database of local funding expenditures for the carceral system and community support services, thereby creating the ability to rigorously assess local budgets as structural determinants of health. The project will then use this novel database to assess the effect of local funding allocations on inequities in firearm violence, which disproportionately impacts segregated Black and Latiné communities. These findings can help inform local policymakers about modifying budgetary allocations as a strategy to address firearm violence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Sensations we perceive arise from both the external environment as well as our own actions, and we learn to expect that certain movements will elicit predictable acoustic consequences. However, the same motor action can often lead to different sensory outcomes, and it is known that the suppression of self-generated sounds in the auditory cortex is highly sensory specific, but the degree to which the motor system reflects both the execution of an action, and its anticipated sensory outcome, is unclear. This proposal will provide valuable insights into the brain’s mechanisms for predicting and updating its encoding of self-generated sounds in real time and uncover fundamental principles underlying the dynamic information flow between sensory and motor regions of the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: This administrative supplement supports the BringBPaL2Me Trial to fully meet trial aims. Newer treatment regimens for antibiotic resistant TB are shorter, better tolerated and have greatly improved treatment outcomes, yet access to these regimens is limited to physician-led, hospital-based programs. The BringBPaL2Me Trial is testing whether it is safe and effective to offer such treatment in a primary care clinic using a nurse-led treatment model, as such, this trial has great potential to improve access to care and significantly reduce patient and health system costs.

PHR: Project Narrative The effects of aging can be offset by supplying the tissue with rejuvenated niche cells. The testis of the fruit fly Drosophila is an ideal model to study niche cells and how they are affected by aging. Our study is designed to identify niche cell genes that change during aging and may open up new therapies for treating human age- related male infertility.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Four in ten young children in the United States are born into low-income families, and they face risks in kindergarten-readiness skills including language and socioemotional development. In this two-brain study of caregivers and children ages 2-6, I will investigate the real-time relationship between caregiver sensitivity (attunement, warmth, and responsiveness to a young child) and preschoolers’ prefrontal cortex synchrony, and further test the relationship between caregiver-child prefrontal cortex synchrony and child language and emotion regulation development. By uncovering moment-to-moment relational mechanisms of children’s learning and development, we can shape policies (e.g., paid parental leave, high-quality Pre-K, Head Start) that buffer young children against SES risks far outside of their families’ control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Second generation antipsychotics (SGAs) are widely used clinical tools, but they often take weeks to become effective, and the mechanism of this time course is not understood. Here, using in vivo optical methods, transgenic mice, and receptor radiolabeling, I will determine a mechanism of tolerance development to select SGAs at gross anatomy, cell-type, and protein levels. This will provide critical insight how these drugs alter the dopaminergic circuitry and explain the clinical time course of SGAs and, attribution of SGA tolerance to specific dopaminergic projections could inform the development of better antipsychotic treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Extensive epidemiological evidence links adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) to increased risk for developing alcohol use disorder (AUD) in adulthood. Given that women are more likely to experience multiple forms of ACEs, as well as that the number of women engaging in binge drinking is rapidly increasing, my goal is to define the sex-specific mechanisms by which early life stress enhances alcohol sensitivity and contributes to AUD susceptibility. Focusing on extended amygdala (BNST) neurons expressing the neuropeptide corticotropin- releasing factor (CRF) in a mouse model of early life stress (ELS), I will test the central hypothesis that ELS- enhanced alcohol sensitivity is mediated through increased BNST-CRF neuronal activity, circuit connectivity, and/or neuropeptide release in a sex-specific manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative of the Parent Award Conventional intracellular electrical signaling tools are not designed for sensing cellular activities either at different positions of a single cell or among different cells in a cellular network, which is essential for deciphering the propagative and communicative behaviors of electrogenic cells’ (e.g., neurons) signals and determining the mechanism and treatment of progressive neurological disorders, such as Parkinson’s disease. To overcome these challenges, we propose a 3D array of intracellular sensors featuring a field effect transistor configuration that is highly sensitive, accurate, and scalable to record both intra- and inter-cellular electrophysiological events in a cellular network.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Learned sound association is the process by which the auditory nervous system associates a sound with a certain outcome, and this ability can be impaired in neurodevelopmental conditions such as language disorder and autism spectrum disorder (ASD). In this proposal, I aim to identify variants and genes affecting language disorder and study the neuronal pathways and circuits involved in sound association along with the mutations that can disrupt them. This will be achieved by using computational approaches to analyze large-scale human genetic data and conducting behavioral experiments with fiber photometry in wildtype and mutant mice models using an interactive virtual reality (VR) environment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study will evaluate whether caregivers’ perceived and objective stress are linked to infant’s language development via levels of infant’s exposure to caregiver linguistic input in everyday life. The hypothesized associations will be examined in infants with and without increased familial likelihood for autism and language disorder, as well as a large sample of infants who are recruited from the general population. This project will be the first to more comprehensively assess aspects of stress among caregivers of infants at elevated familial likelihood for autism and has the potential to inform future research and policy, as well as to point towards novel intervention targets intended to support families of infants with and without language learning difficulties.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clustered Protocadherin (Pcdh) genes confer molecular identities to neurons that allow them to determine when they are contacting neuronal branches from the same or different cells. The ability of neurons to distinguish self from non-self is essential to their morphological and physiological development, and accordingly, dysregulation of Pcdh genes has been linked to several neuropsychiatric and neurological disorders. The findings from this proposal will generate a molecular understanding of how Pcdh genes are regulated across neurodevelopment, which could enable the development of therapeutics that remedy the defects in neural wiring seen in these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to reveal mechanisms of communication between skeletal muscle extracellular matrix and the fibroadipogenic progenitor cells that produce progressive fibrotic cycles in muscular disease. The robustness of the fibrotic cycle will be tested by interrupting the pro-fibrotic signaling through clinical gene therapy of the initiating muscle instability. Investigation of these mechanisms and their durability using innovative methodologies in mice and humans with fibrotic muscular dystrophy uncover specific targets for therapies to block and reverse progressive fibrotic pathologies and augment the efficacy of potential gene therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bacteria within the microbiome are associated with many aspects of health and disease, yet a mechanistic understanding of how these organisms manipulate and contribute to mammalian cell signaling is missing. This supplement extends our understanding by focusing on evolutionary connections between the bacterial and human immune systems. Our findings will allow for development of complementary pre- and probiotic treatments that irradicate harmful bacteria and/or support helpful bacteria to promote human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative IMS has developed the world’s smallest and first integrated electrochemical enzymatic multi-sensor continuous glucose monitor (CGM). The system uses a highly miniaturized (5x smaller than a rice grain) and innovative semiconductor chip (ASIC) with 3 electrochemical sensors (all in their own functionalization wells for independent operation),3 potentiostats, an Analog-to-digital converter (ADC), a multiplexer, and a temperature sensor along with control, power management, and processing circuits. A smallest-in-class external wearable transmitter powers the in vivo sensor and reads data from it via a thin and flexible biocompatible printed circuit board (flex PCB) filament as compared to rigid filaments used in current leading CGMs. The packaged sensor is thinner than a strand of human hair, works for at least 14 days, and is user-insertable and user-removable. We have tested the core platform extensively for the CGM application (30 days swine study, 1-day in- clinic study, 14 days human longevity study). This application is meant to support GMP manufacturing, sterilization and biocompatibility testing as discussed with the FDA to satisfy the requirements for the IDE for FDA 510(k) pivotal trial for an iCGM clearance. IMS CGM ASIC on a US quarter

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Vascular dysfunction and calcification are common in CKD and associated with progression to end-stage renal disease, cardiovascular disease, and death. The current proposal will examine the association of abundant circulating bile acids, including deoxycholic acid, a secondary bile acid that is elevated in CKD and linked with endothelial cell toxicity, vascular dysfunction, and vascular calcification, with cardiovascular disease events and all-cause mortality across a full range of kidney function. Because deoxycholic acid levels are potentially modifiable, they may be a target for intervention to reduce vascular dysfunction and calcification, cardiovascular disease events, and death in CKD.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: LOUIS STOKES CLEVELAND VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Implanted medical devices in the central nervous system (CNS) are used for a number of current and future applications including control of tremor (Parkinson’s disease, ~60,000 Veterans†), pain block/relief (chronic pain, >30 million US†), shunting cerebrospinal fluid (hydrocephalous, ~24,000 Veterans†), and brain-controlled prostheses (spinal cord injury paralysis, ~50,000 Veterans†), among others (†: prevalence). Chronic inflammation may reduce the longevity and performance of CNS-implanted devices. The proposed research plan focuses on advancing one such technology, intracortical microelectrodes for brain-computer interface (BCI) controlled prostheses, which are particularly sensitive to inflammation. The project seeks to mitigate the inflammatory response to enable long-term use of BCI microelectrodes to restore functional limb movement and improve quality of life for paralyzed Veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Older adults have been disproportionately impacted and distressed by the COVID-19 pandemic. Social distancing and stay-at-home orders have increased older adults’ risk of social isolation and loneliness that will has led to a pandemic-induced fear of being in close proximity to other people. These fears and avoidant behaviors will have lasting effects if not treated with effective, safe, and convenient psychological interventions. This study will evaluate the acceptability and feasibility of delivering a small group intervention, called Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT), through a telehealth modality to Veterans ages 65 and older who are experiencing pandemic-related emotional and physical distress. ACT helps decrease emotional suffering, improve well-being and promote positive behavior change by increasing one’s psychological flexibility through the practice of mindfulness, acceptance, and values-based behaviors. The knowledge gained from this study will be used to better tailor the invention to meet the needs of older Veterans in an era of post-pandemic recovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cancer incidence is expected to increase to 23.6 million by 2030 worldwide, and cancer is the leading cause of death for Asian Americans whose numbers are rapidly rising to reach 40 million by 2050. Despite instances of greater cancer-specific mortality compared to other Asians and likely limited access to high-quality care due many experiencing language barriers (~50%), very little is known about supportive care needs in Chinese-, Vietnamese-, and Korean-Americans with metastatic cancers. This project will fill a critical gap in our understanding, and develop culturally relevant and scalable psychosocial resources aimed at improving the quality of life of Chinese-, Vietnamese-, and Korean-Americans with metastatic cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project is relevant to public health because it addresses a novel mechanism by which interactions of aggressive cancers such as acute myeloid leukemia (AML) with their niche can promote disease progression. If successful, this work will provide a scientific basis for development of new strategies to treat these aggressive cancers with less than 25% survival rates. This is highly relevant to the NIH mission of developing fundamental knowledge to help reduce the burdens of human disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: 8. Project Narrative The Wits HIV Research Group Clinical Trials Unit (WHRG CTU) consists of four pleuripotent Clinical Research Sites-The Wits Helen Joseph Hospital CRS, The Wits RHI Shandukani Maternal and Child CRS, Wits RHI Hillbrow Health Precinct Ward 21 CRS and the Wits RHI Research Centre. The WHRG CTU research agenda includes HIV treatment, HIV-associated infections and HIV-related cancers; HIV prevention; TB treatment and prevention (including MDR-TB) and Hepatitis. The CTU conducts research across key populations, including adolescent girls and young women, men who have sex with men, transgender populations and female sex workers; as well as vulnerable populations such as neonates, infants, older children, pregnant and breastfeeding women to a high standard of quality, which has been recognized locally and internationally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE By integrating state-of-the-art T cell characterization in circulation, atherosclerotic lesions, and the kidney in humans with T1D, our project aims to bridge significant gaps in understanding CVD pathogenesis in T1D. Leveraging the CaRe-T1D biobank and multidisciplinary approaches, our research is poised to offer transformative insights, potentially revolutionizing T1D care and opening new therapeutic avenues across the cardio-renal axis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Despite its significant health care burden, no targeted therapies are available for the treatment of Fragile X Syndrome and specifically the autism spectrum disorder-related behaviors in Fragile X Syndrome, as the mechanisms underlying these disorders remain poorly understood. In this proposal we will delineate the cerebellar contribution to autism-relevant behaviors in Fragile X Syndrome and delineate the underlying mechanisms and therapeutic benefits of cerebellar genetic and circuit-based strategies to improve autism- relevant behaviors in multiple mouse models for Fragile X Syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although parent-involved interventions for adolescent alcohol use disorder and co-occurring disorders results in the best outcomes, our understanding of the parenting behaviors during treatment that improve outcomes remains at a nascent stage. The goal of this K99/R00 is to examine parenting practices (parental communication, general parenting practices, and alcohol-specific parenting practices), in real time in daily life, and their associations with adolescent core treatment targets (e.g., treatment motivation, alcohol craving and use) throughout evidence-based parent-involved treatment for co-occurring disorders. By identifying the parenting behaviors that most strongly relate to core treatment targets during treatment, results from this project will provide critical information to facilitate the development of brief, scalable, parent-involved interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The majority of individuals with opioid use disorder (OUD) smoke cigarettes, and they have less success quitting smoking and higher rates of tobacco-related mortality compared to the general smoking population. Novel cigarette reduction approaches, such as substitution of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) for combusted cigarettes, are urgently needed in this population. This proposal will employ a randomized waitlist-controlled trial with a mixed-methods sequential explanatory design to investigate the feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary effects of substituting e-cigarettes for cigarettes on tobacco use and exposure (e.g., cigarettes smoked per day, biomarkers, cigarette dependence) in individuals who smoke (not ready to quit smoking) receiving OUD treatment, to help inform tobacco control policy and clinical practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE This is a request to support the inaugural Nerve SPACE (Setting Priorities to Advance Clinical and Research Efforts in Nerve Injury) Conference, which will bring together nerve surgeons, researchers, and stakeholders who are mutually dedicated to improving upper and lower extremity function and quality of life after nerve injury. The Nerve SPACE conference will allow both established experts and emerging researchers the opportunity to exchange ideas and foster collaboration in an intimate and collegial setting. The overarching goals of the Nerve SPACE conference will be to build consensus on knowledge gaps to and to identify areas for short-term and long-term focus for clinical and research efforts and resources.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) is a significant global health concern with implications for both human and animal health, with worldwide deaths due to AMR predicted to rise to 10 million people annually by 2050. The actions and policies taken to combat the emergence of AMR and prevent the inappropriate use of antimicrobial drugs are collectively known as antimicrobial stewardship (AMS); antifungal use and resistance likely play a role in veterinary AMS but there is a paucity of information despite the increase of resistant fungi as a public health threat. This proposed project will collect data regarding current antifungal use and resistance in companion animals as well as inform on clinical outcomes of companion animals prescribed antifungal drugs.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: A Pilot Study of Veterinary Antifungal Use and Resistance in Support of Vet-LIRN's Antimicrobial Stewardship Efforts

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative HIV co-infection accelerates liver cirrhosis and liver cancer in chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) carriers. Our proposed work will establish robust and physiologically relevant primary cell culture systems to study HIV/HBV co-infections. These systems will provide a platform to develop novel antiviral strategies that may lead to a functional HBV cure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To understand the molecular and cellular mechanisms how protective immune responses are elicited by invading pathogens or vaccines would be useful for the design of vaccines. This project aims to study mechanisms of B cell responses to particulate antigens, or mock viral particles, at molecular and cellular level. The successful completion of this project will fill in a gap in our knowledge regarding how B cells may be activated by viral pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epidemiologic research into the exposome, or sum of human environmental exposures across the lifecourse, will benefit from coordinated efforts and resources that leverage disparate data sets to create a whole that is greater than its parts. The HHEAR Data Center will provide critical resources, expertise, and infrastructure enabling investigators to pool multiple datasets; access, analyze, and interpret these data; and to address hypotheses that go beyond their original funded aims. By achieving this mission, the HHEAR Data Center will accelerate the pace of environmental health research throughout the community to examine the environment on an exposome scale.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Neuromonitoring tools capable of reporting detailed brain signaling information stand to deepen our understanding of neural phenomena, informing improved diagnoses and treatments for neurological disorders and diseases. Although deep brain circuits are known to critically regulate key behaviors, including stress response, motivation, and social interaction, access to these regions by tools capable of large and specific cell population interrogation, such as optical imaging probes, is limited without incurring inflammatory disruption to the tissue environment and restricting animal behavior. This F32 proposal will develop thin, flexible imaging probes augmented by electrical stimulation and recording capabilities, as well as wireless back-end electronics, and deploy these tools to study circuit-level underpinnings of social behaviors in rodents, demonstrating their value to the neuroscience community as powerful and minimally perturbative recording platforms.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Thirty-three percent of children admitted to the intensive care unit with pediatric acute respiratory distress syndrome (PARDS) die prior to hospital discharge. Emerging data suggests that gut microbes living within us may influence PARDS progression or severity, and other organ dysfunction. Our research program will study how feeding strategies during PARDS, may improve the type of microbes in our gut, and may be a new approach to improve lung inflammation and injury, organ dysfunction, and survival in these children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary sarcoidosis is a condition that ranges in severity from mild and self-limiting--meaning it goes away without chronic therapy--to life-threatening with end-stage irreversible organ damage. There are no reliable “tools” available to the clinician that provide useful information about a patient’s future risk of having progressive lung disease and without these tools, clinicians cannot make the best care decisions for their patients. This study was designed to address these unmet clinical needs by creating and testing these “tools” using blood test results and clinical information from several groups of people across the United State who have sarcoidosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aging is a complex process that drives increased cancer risk in tissues throughout the body, including the blood system. To understand why aged individuals have higher risk of developing blood cancers, there is a vital need to understand the mechanisms by which aging contributes to clonal expansion and transformation. This research is relevant to public health because it will provide mechanistic insights into effective therapeutic strategies to target clonal evolution, attenuate pathophysiology promoted by clonal expansion, and intercept malignant transformation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Various physiological and psychological variables influence our decision making, but little is known about how the brain represents factors like heart rate or emotional state, or the neural mechanisms by which these factors bias the decision-making process. Here I propose to evaluate these mechanisms by recording from the non- human primate prefrontal cortex while they perform social and non-social decision-making tasks and either visceral or brain physiology is manipulated. The research described herein will provide a strong backbone upon which I will receive training in experimental and computational neurophysiology, as well as in the use of causal genetic manipulations in non-human primates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary sarcoidosis is a condition that ranges in severity from mild and self-limiting--meaning it goes away without chronic therapy--to life-threatening with end-stage irreversible organ damage. There are no reliable “tools” available to the clinician that provide useful information about a patient’s future risk of having progressive lung disease and without these tools, clinicians cannot make the best care decisions for their patients. This study was designed to address these unmet clinical needs by creating and testing these “tools” using blood test results and clinical information from several groups of people across the United State who have sarcoidosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most lethal hematological malignancy, and alternatives to chemotherapy such as differentiation therapy are greatly needed. We recently found that the H3K9 histone acetyltransferase KAT6A cooperates with the H3K9ac reader protein ENL to promote stemness and proliferation in AML. Here, we aim to determine the molecular mechanisms by which KAT6A and ENL cooperate to drive leukemogenic gene expression programs, and to identify the genetic subtypes of AML that are most sensitive to KAT6A inhibition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this proposal is to improve the guideline-concordant breast cancer (BC) screening among Latinas living in Chicago, by testing a new empowerment (empower) approach - wherein non-adherent Latinas are empowered to become informal breast health leaders in their community and are navigated to affordable, accessible care. We will examine if, relative to traditional approaches, the empower approach leads to greater BC screening among non-adherent Latinas and women in their social networks. We will also explore and identify the “active ingredients” that lead to greater BC screening in the empower approach - including greater knowledge, motivation to be a healthy role model, volunteerism in community BC initiatives, potential to “bridge” network members with formal change agents (e.g., community health workers, navigators), acceptability to promote BC, feasibility to promote BC, and BC promotion to network members.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE, Project 2 This project aims to bring therapeutic intervention to patients with locally recurrent head and neck cancer. We will employ locally advanced mouse models and patient-derived xenografts for experimental therapeutics in immune competent and compromised conditions, perform mechanistic analyses, and initiate a Phase Ib clinical trial. We aim to bring a therapeutic intervention to simultaneously enhance immunotherapy and reduce RT resistance in head and neck cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative One of the most challenging sequelae for patients undergoing spine surgery is chronic post-surgical pain (CPSP) which is associated with poor physical function and long-term opioid use. There is a significant need for effective nonpharmacologic interventions, such as Acceptance and Commitment Therapy, to prevent CPSP and long-term opioid use. Moreover, identifying psychosocial and psychophysical phenotypes associated with treatment efficacy will allow for a cost-effective, precision medicine approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Training Program in Neuroengineering and Medicine Disorders of the nervous system represent one of the largest, fastest growing areas of medical need in the United States and the most promising therapies for these disorders are new technologies to image, analyze, and modulate activity in neural circuits. There is a great need for engineers educated in clinical neuroscience and physicians with technical backgrounds to train and work together, to effectively bring these critical technologies to patient care. The goal of this multidisciplinary program is to train pre-doctoral engineering students, and post-doctoral MD and MD-PhD fellows together in Neuroengineering research, to translate their work to clinical care, and ultimately improve the lives of individuals with brain and nervous system disorders.
PROJECT_TERMS: Medicine;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: Training Program in Neuroengineering and Medicine

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Recent studies have found that infection with SARS-CoV-2 and COVID-19 diagnosis are associated with the development and progression of both Type 1 (T1D) and Type 2 Diabetes (T2D). The proposed study will engage 15 sites from the National Patient-Centered Clinical Research Network (PCORnet) and the T1D Exchange to recruit 1600 English- and Spanish-speaking pediatric and adult patients with recently diagnosed T1D or T2D who have had a known COVID-19 infection in the past 90 days or no recent diagnosis of COVID- 19 infection in the past year. The study will follow this population for 2 years and will utilize linked electronic health data from PCORnet sites to understand the impact of COVID-19 on diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Vivreon Biosciences, LLC 4940 Carroll Canyon Rd., Ste. 110  San Diego, CA 92121 milton@vivreonbiosciences.com NIDA RFA-DA-23-021 Project Narrative Opioid use disorder (OUD) is the chronic use of opioid medications that causes clinically significant distress or impairment. Opioid dependence and OUD can develop upon accepted opioid therapy administered while in the ICU and other hospital care settings where pain treatment and sedation are needed. No pharmaceutical exists to prevent development of opioid dependence. With support from this grant project, Vivreon Biosciences seeks to further validate and advance a promising small molecule drug candidate to bring the first drug to market that can prevent development of opioid dependence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed Center for Cancer Systems Therapeutics (CaST) will seek to perform systematic, single-cell- level elucidation of stable cell states and state transitions in tumor-related cells and in their tumor microenvironment (TME) to identify and target complementary dependencies leading to mechanism-based combination therapy trials. This will provide a more holistic understanding of the fundamental steps underlying tumor initiation and progression and of the critical mechanisms that can be targeted pharmacologically to transform cancer treatment. Critically, we have shown that the Systems Biology framework developed by CaST Center investigators can effectively generalize to virtually any tumor of interest leading to highly innovative, biomarker-based interventional trials, thus accelerating progression from biological analysis to cures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of R01DA054751 is to inform regulatory efforts to minimize cannabis use in disproportionately- impacted populations in states with legalized non-medical cannabis and those that subsequently legalize it, by examining the non-medical cannabis market, cannabis use, and related perceptions in market segments of diverse young adults within the context of diverse cannabis policies across states. The goal of the proposed Administrative Supplement is to expand on data collection in each aim of the parent R01 in order to assess derived psychoactive cannabis product (DPCP) laws, industry retail and marketing, and use in young adults. We will add: 1) comprehensive data on DPCP laws to our state cannabis-related law database; 2) DPCP retail audits to our planned cannabis retail audits to characterize the DPCP retail context; and 3) an additional wave of survey data collection for a subset of young adults in our longitudinal cohort study to assess differences in DPCP marketing exposure, DPCP perceptions and use motives, and use outcomes, by DPCP law context.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To address high unmet need for postpartum family planning (PPFP) in Rwanda, we developed, and pilot tested our ‘C4’ intervention (informed by Couples/clients, Clinic providers, Champions, and Community health workers), which significantly increased the use of PPFP in government clinics. We now propose to use an implementation science framework to test the hypothesis that C4 is adaptable to large-scale implementation, cost-effective, and sustainable. C4 could dramatically reduce unintended pregnancy and abortion and improve birth spacing and maternal and newborn health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We discovered that brainstem neurons expressing anoctamin 4 (Ano4, an ion channel) regulate food intake and blood glucose in mice. A large-scale human genetic study established the association of the ANO4 gene mutation with human obesity, but the causality of this association has not been tested. Here we propose to use genetic mouse models to examine the effects of the Ano4 mutation and Ano4-expressing neurons on body weight and glucose homeostasis, which will provide the necessary framework to develop therapeutic strategies towards treating obesity and metabolic dysregulations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative The Acquired Resistance to Therapy and Iron (ARTI) Center at The University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center will establish a foundation for understanding the role of iron in cancer resistance to therapies and will focus on deciphering the mechanisms of acquired resistance to radiation therapy, which can be extrapolated to other types of cancer therapy. The overarching goals of the ARTI Center are: 1) to bridge the basic science mechanism of a novel type of iron-dependent cell death called ferroptosis in acquired resistance to radiation therapy with translational research in preclinical models and human patient samples; 2) to identify cohorts of patients who are at greatest risk to develop acquired radiation therapy resistance; and 3) to investigate the ability of novel therapeutic agents to re-sensitize cancer cells to radiation by inducing ferroptosis. The long-term outcomes from the ARTI Center will foster collaborations with other centers in the Acquired Resistance to Therapy Network (ARTNet), build upon and iteratively feedback into research projects focused on drug resistance and sensitivities, and ultimately lead to cancer treatment strategies tailored to the individual patient.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative There is strong evidence that disruption of neural circuit development and plasticity contributes to the etiology of many neurological and neurodegenerative disorders. The proposed experiments promise to increase our basic knowledge of the cellular and molecular mechanisms that drive neural circuit development in the mammalian cerebral cortex, refinement during learning, and alterations associated with disease. Ultimately, such basic knowledge has strong potential to facilitate the development of therapeutics for human neurological and neurodegenerative disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative There is a critical need to develop accurate genetic risk prediction models for non-European populations because most studies to date have focused on individuals of European ancestry. This project will propose novel statistical methods to integrate data from diverse populations for more accurate risk prediction models in the underrepresented populations. Our developed tools, their applications to many diseases, and the associated dissemination platform will facilitate the translation of genome wide association study results into clinically useful disease risk prediction models in these populations.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Clinical provider burnout is a key indicator of how well a health care system is functioning. Reducing mental health provider (MHP) burnout could improve patient access to care, quality of care, and improve employee engagement, which are core components of VHA's priorities and strategic plan. We propose to conduct the largest and most comprehensive study to date on the systematic, facility-level predictors and consequences of MHP burnout. VHA can use the findings from this longitudinal, mixed methods study to facilitative future planning and interventions to improve MHP burnout, employee engagement, and patient outcomes. Supported by a wide range of VHA and community partners and stakeholders, our findings could be of clinical and financial value to VHA, its providers, and patients. Our work will contribute to broad healthcare improvements within VHA, and will generate new insights for healthcare delivery, informing efforts to address burnout in MHPs and other clinical providers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: In the global HIV epidemic, Africa accounts for about 70% of the 38 million people living with HIV (PLHIV) and the 1.7 million new infections. In South Africa, which has a fifth of all the PLHIV in the world, the province of KwaZulu-Natal bears a disproportionate burden, with 2 million PLHIV. In this province, community-based adult HIV prevalence exceeds 30% and incidence rates exceed 4 per 100 person-years. KwaZulu-Natal also has a substantial tuberculosis burden, with 50,822 new cases of tuberculosis (incidence of 494 per 100,000) in 2018, of which about 60% are co-infected with HIV. The KwaZulu-Natal Clinical Trials Unit’s overall goal is to contribute to the scientific priorities of the four Clinical Trial Networks through novel research concepts, innovative prevention technologies and high-quality clinical trials in target populations by highly experienced research teams at well-equipped Clinical Research Sites.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative: Patients with type 1 diabetes (T1D) suffer a disproportionate higher risk of atherosclerosis and its consequences (e.g. heart attacks) remain the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in these patients. Emerging studies demonstrate important regulatory roles for non-coding RNAs in atherosclerosis, yet this is a poorly understood area of research in T1D. Our studies aim to fill this void by investigating the roles of key non-coding RNAs and their target genes and interactomes in cellular events important in the progression and regression phases of T1D-associated atherosclerosis, with the ultimate goal of developing innovative RNA-based therapies in the treatment of this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Pain and depression affect large percentages of the population and identifying the optimal medication for an individual can be challenging, so this trial will determine whether using genetic information to inform selection of opioids or antidepressants leads to better clinical outcomes for patients. People with African ancestry (AAs) have the highest rates of uncontrolled high blood pressure, chronic kidney disease and kidney failure, some of which is due to APOL1 genetic variants. We will test AA adults with high blood pressure for APOL1 and return the results to patients and their clinicians, to see if early knowledge of high genetic risk improves blood pressure, provider and patient behaviors and is cost effective.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The University of Maryland School of Medicine (UMSOM) and the University of Maryland Baltimore County (UMBC) are submitting a joint application to the NIH Faculty Institutional Recruitment for Sustainable Transformation (FIRST) program to recruit new faculty members from groups traditionally underrepresented (UR) in biomedical research. This consortium will use a model for faculty development and promotion that is based on the UMBC Meyerhoff Scholars Program, which has been highly in training undergraduates from UR groups who have gone on to careers in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Medicine). The model will feature cluster hires of 10 new faculty in the areas of cancer biology, neuroscience and microbiology/immunology/infectious diseases, in which there is great institutional strength.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Glucagon secretion from α-cells has long been viewed as primarily a counterregulatory mechanism – e.g. an agent that with a role to prevent blood sugar from decreasing t0 levels that compromise function. Our group, along with other researchers, have begun to identify a much more complex role for α-cells, raising questions about when and how glucagon may influence blood glucose levels. This proposal looks to detail proglucagon peptide secretion from α-cells and the impact this has on β-cell function and glucose tolerance, exclusively in preclinical studies of human islets and translational studies in human subjects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is a progressive, lethal fibrotic lung disease that primarily affects older adults. The proposed study aimed to explore the molecular mechanisms underlying lung fibrosis associated with aging. The ultimate goal of the study is to develop novel therapeutic interventions for effective treatment of IPF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Data obtained from this proposal are expected to establish A-FABP as a novel therapeutic target and biomarker for HFD-induced obesity/breast cancer risk. This proposal will not only have basic science ramifications for understanding how A-FABP shapes dysregulated lipid metabolism and functions of TAMs and breast cancer cells, but will also have significant clinical implications for prevention and immunotherapy of obesity-associated BC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Oral cancer is a major public health concern, with 58,450 cases diagnosed in the US each year. Since current preventive and therapeutic approaches have not significantly improved oral cancer outcomes and could potentially be harmful, it is essential that alternative approaches to treatment be developed and tested. We will determine the impact of glucocorticoids and glucocorticoid signaling on oral cancer development, and the effects of the chemopreventive agent gallic acid on this pathway during oral cancer chemoprevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  By 2050, osteoporosis is expected to affect >50% of Americans over the age of 50; further, osteoporotic hip fracture incidence is expected to increase by >200% compared to rates in 1990. Recent studies have identified a large number of loci associated with bone mineral density (BMD), an important clinical marker for osteoporosis diagnosis. This project aims to define causal genes at these loci to understand their biological mechanisms, and in turn, identify new drug targets for osteoporosis therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE UNIV A&M COL BATON ROUGE
PHR: NARRATIVE Many hearing and language disorders arise from pathological alterations to the central auditory pathways. This study is relevant to public health since it will investigate the hitherto overlooked contralateral auditory tectothalamic pathways as a neural substrate in these disorders. Therefore, this research is relevant to part of NIH’s mission, since it develops the basic knowledge that will lead to improved methods for diagnosing, preventing, and treating auditory disorders associated with aging, development, trauma, and neurodegeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative One of the key causes of Parkinson’s disease is the misfolding of a protein called alpha-synuclein to form aggregates. In this application we propose to develop a new concept which uses some small structures referred to as nano scavengers to bind the misfolded protein and report on their presence (diagnosis) and accelerate their clearance from the brain (treatment).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: DIGITAL ORGANIZING POWER-BUILDING AND ENGAGEMENT LABS
PHR: Project Narrative Structural racism is a fundamental cause of African American (AA) and Black Immigrant (BI) health disparities, but there is a lack of understanding of AAs and BIs lived experiences of structural racism and protective factors that mediate the impacts on Black Longevity. Our research contributes to filling the gap left by previous studies that have been slow to quantify and measure the impact of structural racism on Black longevity, by shedding new light on the extent to which compositional and contextual effects interact and impact differences in Black life expectancy across locations in the US. By adopting historical and life course perspectives we will: 1) co-design novel community-led quantitative and qualitative tools, measures, and data sets that more accurately capture the multifaceted nature of structural racism, its intersections with other systems of oppression, and its impact on Black longevity; and 2) develop agent-based models to dynamically assess factors that hinder or promote Black longevity across histories and geographies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Individuals with obesity face a heightened risk of developing breast cancer. Our proposed research will test whether ceramides increase breast cancer growth and whether ceramide-lowering interventions might be suitable for these patients. Thus, the proposed research is of high relevance to public health and perfectly aligns with NCI mission to support cancer research by advancing scientific knowledge and helping people live longer, healthier lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to target a specific tumor marker, EphA2, expressed on the surface of aggressive pancreatic cancers. We propose to develop our potent and effective EphA2 targeting agent, Targefrin, that effectively inhibits tumor metastases. We will also probe Targefrin as an effective drug deliver agent to target chemotherapy selectively to the tumor and circulating cancer cells. Hence the proposed therapeutic strategy would simultaneously eliminate the primary tumor and suppress pancreatic cancer metastases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our research investigates why type 1 diabetes significantly raises heart disease risk. Unlike type 2 diabetes, type 1 involves unique cardiovascular complications not fully explained by usual risk factors. We suspect that diabetes-related immune system irregularities contribute to heart issues. By analyzing immune and heart tissue differences in diabetic versus non-diabetic individuals, we aim to pinpoint these immune interactions' role in heart disease, potentially leading to new treatments that can lower heart disease risk in diabetes patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Narrative. Despite the identification of numerous genes and variants associated with type 2 diabetes (T2D) through genome-wide association studies (GWAS), the interaction network of these GWAS-identified T2D genes/variants remains poorly understood. This proposal aims to use stem cell-derived islet organoids and human islets to systematically evaluate the molecular cascade involving T2D effector genes and variants in human islet cell generation, survival, and function. These proposed studies will not only address several challenges encountered in current T2D GWAS studies but also shed light on new insights into T2D disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: BUCK INSTITUTE FOR RESEARCH ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Molecular details for understanding disease and injury of the musculoskeletal system are particularly needed to develop novel proteomic assays to monitor disease progression in osteoarthritis or meniscal injury. Our innovative approach includes developing Spatial Mass Spectrometry Imaging technologies for joints to spatially visualize proteins of the extracellular matrix and glycans, and applying deep proteomic profiling for bones using robust statistical tests. These technologically novel approaches will also facilitate the development of urgently needed molecular assays to assess efficacy of interventions for the musculoskeletal system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: U54 CENTER: NARRATIVE Metastatic organ colonization by circulating tumor cells depends on a response program in tumor cells, termed mechano-adaptation, to cope with mechanical and molecular stresses. In this U54 MetNet Center, we will integrate mechanical, genomic and ultrastructural information during metatastatic organ colonization and identify mechanical mechanisms of tumor cell fate decisions and identify pathways and potential therapeutic strategies to eliminate tumor cells prior to metastasis.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative  Correlation between antimicrobial susceptibility phenotypes and presence of major groups of antimicrobial resistance genes will be studied. Different mutation types, including point mutations, insertion and deletions, as well as potential segment rearrangement, and mutation rate of each type will be analyzed. Additionally, genetic diversity and phylogenetic relationships of the major AMR genes as well as potential correlation of AMR susceptibility levels to AMR gene diversity will also be studied.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Obesity is associated with changes in immune responses in fat tissue, which may contribute to the development of type 2 diabetes. In this application, we propose to investigate how to improve fat tissue immune responses to protect our bodies from the effects of obesity. At the end of our studies, we expect to uncover new ways to improve the immune system to treat obesity and type 2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Neuropathic pain is a debilitating form of chronic pain afflicting millions of patients worldwide but is poorly responsive to current analgesic therapies. It is hypothesized that increased excitatory/decreased inhibitory signaling in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord results in the initiation, maintenance, and progression of neuropathic pain. This study uses in vivo intraspinal optogenetics, conditional genetic knockout lines combined with behavioral pharmacology, and spinal cord slice electrophysiology to ultimately determine if peripheral nerve injury increases the excitability of excitatory dorsal horn interneurons (those that contain the type 1 receptor for neuropeptide Y) to contribute to the behavioral manifestations of neuropathic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Diseases of the cartilage and joints, including osteoarthritis, are a leading cause of disability in the world, disproportionally affecting women and minorities. Osteoarthritis alone affects approximately 7% of the population worldwide and results in significantly reduced quality of life and negative economic impact, affecting gross national product from 1 to 2.5% in countries with market economies, and the impact of these conditions is expected to rise as life expectancy increases. The primary objective of this meeting is to provide a unique venue to present and discuss interdisciplinary research with an emphasis on exposing new investigators to innovations in cartilage and joint development, maintenance and pathology, bioengineering, and translational research, which will have the potential to impact public health in the area of cartilage-related diseases, including osteoarthritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative This proposal will elucidate how excessive free hemoglobin in circulation binds to von Willebrand factor (VWF) and alters the interaction between VWF and fibrinogen at very high flow conditions. This project will also characterize the function of VWF derived from platelets in the presence of elevated levels of hemoglobin. The proposed work will lay the foundation for the development of anti-thrombotic agents targeting the VWF-hemoglobin interaction.

PHR: Narrative Acquired resistance to therapy contributes to poor survival outcomes in cancer patients. The primary objective of this U54 application is to establish a successful and self-sustaining ARTNet Center for Pancreatic Cancer (ACPC) to explore novel mechanisms and combination therapies to target acquired resistance in pancreatic cancer. We will collaborate and work closely with other ARTNet centers, coordinating center, and the National Cancer Institute to provide novel mechanistic insights and translational opportunities to target therapy resistance with the long-term goal of improving overall patient survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many babies born with Congenital Heart Disease (CHD) require surgical intervention within days of life to survive. Surgery is invasive and can require putting the baby on a heart-lung bypass machine, which can have negative consequences. Starlight Cardiovascular will develop the first branch pulmonary artery flow restrictors designed specifically for babies with CHD that can be delivered minimally-invasively through a catheter, which could replace surgery and improve patient outcomes with an increased safety profile.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: BENAROYA RESEARCH INST AT VIRGINIA MASON
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed ITN UM1 funding addresses major unmet health needs. In the United States, autoimmune diseases affect >5% of the population, and allergic diseases affect another ~15%. Transplantation is a life- saving intervention for organ failure, but risky and burdensome. In each area, pre-clinical studies show that immune tolerance should be an achievable therapeutic prospect, and progress towards that goal is evident in recent clinical trials. Successful tolerance offers long-term freedom from immunosuppressive therapy, radically improving quality of life, disease burden, and health care costs. Sunbeam specific activities are being performed in support of CoFAR. 1 Abstract
